editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A VOYAGE TO THE SOUTH SEAS, In the YEARS 1740-1. CONTAINING, A faithful NARRATIVE of the Lo≈øs of his Maje≈øty's Ship the the WAGER on a de≈øolate I≈øland in the Latitude 47 South, Longitude 81: 40 We≈øt: With the Pro ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ings and Conduct of the Officers and Crew, and the Ha ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ips they endured in the ≈øaid I≈øland for the Space of five Months, their bold Attempt for Liberty, in Coa≈øting the Southern Part of the va≈øt Region of Patagonia; ≈øetting out with upwards of Eighty Souls in their Boats, the Lo≈øs of the Cutter, their Pa≈ø≈øage through the Streights of Magellan; an Account of their Manner of living in the Voyage on Seals, Wild Hor≈øes, Dogs, &c. and the incredible Hard≈øhips they frequently underwent for Want of Food of all Kinds; a De≈øcription of the ≈øeveral Places where they touch'd in the Streights of Magellan, with an Account of the Inhabitants, &c. and their ≈øafe Arrival at the Brazil, after ≈øailing one thou≈øand Leagues in a Long-Boat; their Reception from the Portugue≈øe, an Account of the Di≈øturbances at Rio Grand, their Arrival at Rio Janeiro, their Pa≈ø≈øage and U≈øage on Board a Portugue≈øe Ship to Li≈øbon, their Return to England, their Confinement for the Lo≈øs of the Ship, and their Relea≈øement: the Arrival of the Captain, who had been left behind by his own Reque≈øt where the Ship was lo≈øt; the Officers ≈øecond Confinement, Trial and Acquittance; the Arrival of three of the Crew, who had been left with five others on the uninhabited Part of Patagonia, &c. Interper≈øed with many entertaining and curious Ob≈øervations, not taken Notice of by Sir John Narborough, or any other Journali≈øt, with many Things not publi≈øhed in the fir≈øt Edition.
By JOHN BULKELEY and JOHN CUMMINS, Late Gunner and Carpenter of the WAGER.
The SECOND EDITION, with ADDITIONS.

q.l: Bold were the Men who on the Ocean fir≈øt
Spread the new Sails, when Ship wreck was the wor≈øt:
More Dangers Now from MAN alone we find,
Than from the Rocks, the Billows, and the Wind

div.head: To the Honourable WILLIAM DENNY, E≈øq Lieutenant Governor of the Province of Penn≈øylvania, &c.
div.p:
AS I have the Plea≈øure to re≈øide in the Government over which You have the Admini≈øtration, I thought I could do no le≈øs than lay this Second Edition of the Voyage of the WAGER at Your Feet, not doubting from Your e≈øtabli≈øhed Character for Ju≈øtice, Benevolence, Charity and Peace, it will meet with ≈øuitable Protection. Permit me, dear Sir, to ≈øay, May You long live to enjoy the good Wi≈øhes of the People of Your Government, and Penn≈øylvania, under Your wi≈øe and candid Admini≈øtration, become renowned for Unanimity and Harmony, which will make her the Terror of all her Enemies,
and a Prai≈øe in the Earth:‚ÄîWith what paternal Affection would our gracious Sovereign then look upon her, ≈øhe would de≈øervedly become the Object of His peculiar Care, and That of a Briti≈øh Parliament: How plea≈øing would this be to our PROPRIETARY FRIENDS and GUARDIANS, who≈øe Intere≈øts are in≈øeparable join'd with Ours, and Ours with Theirs? But, more than all, how acceptable would this be to Almighty God, the Father of All, who would make Penn≈øylvania as the Garden of the Lord; and He, by his Providence, which I have experienced in many and great Difficulties, would go with our Armies, and crown them with Succe≈øs, and, in due Time, would re≈øtore the Ble≈ø≈øings of Peace. For the Completion of the≈øe great and glorious Events, Prays, Your Servant,

div.head: The DEDICATION to the FIRST EDITION.
To the Honourable EDWARD VERNON, E≈øq Vice-Admiral of the Blue, &c.
div.p: WE have pre≈øumed to put the following Sheets under your Protection, tho' we have not the Honour of being per≈øonally known to you, nor have applied to you for the Liberty of u≈øing your celebrated Name on this Occa≈øion.
As this Book is a faithful Extract from the Journals of two Briti≈øh Seamen, late Officers in his Maje≈øty's Navy, we thought we could not more properly dedicate it than to a Briti≈øh Admiral.
We know your Dete≈øtation of Flattery; and you know, from long Experience, that a Briti≈øh Seaman hath a Spirit too brave to ≈øtoop to ≈øo degenerate a Practice.
The following Pages we hope will recommend them≈øelves to you, becau≈øe they are written in a plain maritime Stile, and void of Partiality and Prejudice.

The Di≈øtre≈ø≈øes mention'd in this Book have perhaps not been equal'd in our Age; and we que≈øtion whether any Navigators living have, for ≈øo long a Continuance, ≈øuffer'd ≈øuch Variety of Hard≈øhips, as the unfortunate People of the Wager.

After ≈øurviving the Lo≈øs of the Ship, and combating with Famine, and innumerable Difficulties, a Remnant of us are return'd to our Native Country; but even here we are ≈øtill unfortunate, de≈øtitute of Employment,
almo≈øt without Support, or any Pro≈øpect of being re≈øtor'd to our Stations, till ≈øome important Que≈øtions are decided, which cannot be cleared up till the Arrival of our late Captain, or at lea≈øt the Commodore.

We, Sir, who pre≈øent you with this Book, have been ≈øeveral Years in the Navy, and thought our≈øelves well acquainted with its Laws and Di≈øcipline, and have many Certificates to produce, that we have always acted in Obedience to Command; but the Proceedings of the Officers and People, ≈øince the Lo≈øs of the Ship, are reckoned ≈øo dark and intricate, that we know not what to expect, nor what will be the Re≈øult of our Superiors Determination.

The only Con≈øolation we have in our pre≈øent Anxiety, is placed in a Confidence of the unbias'd Integrity,
Ju≈øtice, and Humanity of the Right Honourable Per≈øons who will One Day determine for or again≈øt us.

When you read our Account of the Affair, you'll find the Facts impartially related, the whole Narrative written without the lea≈øt Shadow of Prejudice or Malice, and no more in Favour of our≈øelves than of the other Officers concern'd: We ≈øtand or fall by the Truth; if Truth will not ≈øupport us, nothing can.

In our Voyage from the Brazil to Lisbon, we were oblig'd to you for the generous Treatment we met with from an Enemy, a Subject of Spain, a Per≈øon of Di≈øtinction, and a Pa≈ø≈øenger in the ≈øame Ship: Your Virtues have procured you the E≈øteem even of your Enemies.

Your Zeal for the National Service, de≈øerves the Love of every Hone≈øt Briton: To leave an abundant
Fortune, your Family, and your Country, to hazard your Life in the mo≈øt perilous Expeditions, with no other Motive than to retrieve the Honour of the Nation, ≈øhows the Spirit of a true Briti≈øh Hero, and de≈øerves the highe≈øt Commendations.

That you, SIR, may never deviate from your Integrity, but continue a Terror to the Enemies of Britain, an Honour to his Maje≈øty's Service, and an Ornament to your Country, are the ≈øincere Wi≈øhes of,

closer.signed: Your mo≈øt dutiful, And mo≈øt obedient Humble Servants, JOHN BULKELEY, JOHN CUMMINS.

div.head: THE PREFACE.
div.p: AS an Introduction, we think proper to acquaint the Reader with our Rea≈øons for cau≈øing the following Sheets to be made publick to the World. The chief Motive, which induced us to this Ta≈øk, was to clear our Characters, which have been exceedingly blemi≈øh'd by Per≈øons who (next to Heaven) owe the Pre≈øervation of their Lives to our Skill, and indefatigable Care; and who having an Opportunity of arriving before us in England, have endeavour'd to rai≈øe their Reputation on the Ruin of Ours.

It will appear to the Reader, on Peru≈øal of the following Pages, that this Journal was attempted to he taken from us by Violence at Rio Janeiro; that we have pre≈øerved it, at the Hazard of our Lives; that there was no Journal kept after the Lo≈øs of the Ship, by any Officers but our≈øelves; and if we had not been careful in making Remarks on each Day's Tran≈øactions, Per≈øons mu≈øt have continued in the Dark, in relation to all the ≈øub≈øequent Proceedings.

It is a very u≈øual Thing to publi≈øh Voyages, e≈øpecially when the Navigators have met with any extraordinary Events. We believe, our Expedidition, though it was not a Secret, is allowed to be an extraordinary One, and con≈øequently attended with extraordinary Events: Indeed while the Commodore was with us, every thing went well, but when the Squadron ≈øeparated, Things began to have a new Face; after the Lo≈øs of the Wager, there was a general Di≈øorder and Confu≈øion among the People, who were now no longer implicitly obedient. There were two Seamen particularly, who propogated this Confu≈øion, they ≈øaid they had ≈øuffer'd Ship-wreck in his Maje≈øty's Ship the Biddeford, and received no Wages from the Day that the Ship was lo≈øt; that when they were out of Pay, they look'd upon them≈øelves as their own Ma≈øters, and no longer ≈øubjected to Command. The People however were not altogether infected, but ≈øtill continued to pay a dutiful Re≈øpect to their Commander; but when the Captain had ra≈øhly ≈øhot Mr. Cozens (who≈øe Fate the Reader will find particularly related) they then grew very turbulent and unruly, the Captain daily lo≈øt the Love of the Men, who with their Affection lo≈øt their Duty.

Our confining the Captain is reckoned an audacious and unprecedented Action, and our not bringing him home with us, is reckon'd wor≈øe;
but the Reader will find that Nece≈ø≈øity ab≈øolutely compell'd us to act as we did, and that we had ≈øufficient Rea≈øons for leaving him behind.

Our Attempt for Liberty in ≈øailing to the Southward through the Streights of Magellan with ≈øuch a Number of People, ≈ølow'd in a Long Boat, has been cen≈øur'd as a mad Undertaking: De≈øperate Di≈øea≈øes require de≈øperate Remedies; had we gone to the Northward, there appear'd no Probability of e≈øcaping the Spaniards, and when we had fallen into their Hands, 'tis not unlikely but they might have employed us as Drudges in their Mines for Life, therefore we rather cho≈øe to encounter all Difficulties than to become Slaves to a mercile≈øs Enemy.

Some Per≈øons have objected again≈øt our Capacity for keeping a Journal of this Nature; but ≈øeveral Judges of Maritime Affairs, allow this Work to be exact and regular. We think, Per≈øons with a common Share of Under≈øtanding are capable of committing to Paper daily Remarks of Matters worthy their Ob≈øervation, e≈øpecially of Facts in which they them≈øelves had ≈øo large a Share. We only relate ≈øuch Things as could not po≈ø≈øibly e≈øcape our Knowledge, and what we actually know to be true. We don't ≈øet up for Naturali≈øts and Men of great Learning, therefore have avoided meddling with Things above our Capacity.

We are al≈øo condemn'd by many for being too bu≈øy and active for Per≈øons in our Stations. There was a Nece≈ø≈øity for Action, and a great deal of it too; and had we been as indolent and regardle≈øs for the Pre≈øervation of the People, as others who were ≈øuperior in Command, there would not have been ≈øo many who were ≈øhipwreck'd in the Wager, now in England to give a Relation of the Matter.

The Gentleman who commanded in the Long-Boat on his Arrival before us at Li≈øbon, repre≈øented us to the Engli≈øh Merchants in a very vile Light, we were even advi≈øed by ≈øome of our Friends there not to return to our Country, le≈øt we ≈øhould ≈øuffer Death for Mutiny. But when the Gentlemen of the Factory had perus'd our Journal, they found, if there was any Mutiny in the Ca≈øe, the very Per≈øon who accu≈øed us, was the Ringleader and chief Mutineer. We were confident of our own Innocence, and determin'd to ≈øee our Country at all Events, being po≈øitive that we have acted to the be≈øt of our Under≈øtandings, in all Re≈øpects, for the Pre≈øervation of our Lives and Liberties; and when our Superiors ≈øhall think proper to call us to an Account, which we expect will be at the Commodore's Arrival, we do not doubt but we ≈øhall clear our≈øelves in ≈øpite of all invidious Reflections and malicious Imputations.

It has been hinted to us, as if publi≈øhing this Journal would give Offence to ≈øome Per≈øons of Di≈øtinction. We can't conceive how any Tran≈øactions relating to the Wager, although made ever ≈øo publick, can give Offence to any Great M ‚Ä¢ n at Home. Can it be any Offence to tell the World that we were ≈øhip-wreck'd in the Wager, when all People know it already? Don't they know that the Wager was one of his Maje≈øty's Store-Ships? That we had on Board not only Naval Stores but other Stores of an immen≈øe Value? Don't they al≈øo know that we went abroad with Hopes of acquiring great Riches, but are return'd Home as poor as Beggars? We are guilty of no indecent Reproaches, or unmannerly Reflections; though, it is certain, we cannot but lament our being engaged in ≈øo fatal an Expedition. When Per≈øons have ≈øurmounted great Difficulties, it is a Plea≈øure for them to relate their Story; and if we give our≈øelves this Satisfaction, who has any Cau≈øe to be offended? Are we, who have faced Death in ≈øo many Shapes, to be intimidated, le≈øt we ≈øhould give Offence to the‚ÄîLord knows whom? We never ≈øaw a ≈øatyrical Journal in our Lives, and we though that Kind of Writing was the mo≈øt obnoxious to give Offence.

It has been a Thing u≈øual, in publi≈øhing of Voyages, to introduce abundance of Fiction; and ≈øome Authors have been e≈øteem'd merely for being
marvelous. We have taken Care to deviate from tho≈øe, by having a ≈øtrict Regard to Truth. There are undoubtedly in this Book ≈øome Things which will appear incredible. The Account given of the Patagonian Indians, and our own Di≈øtre≈ø≈øes, tho' ever ≈øo well atte≈øted, will not ea≈øily obtain Credit; and People will hardly believe that Human Nature could po≈ø≈øibly ≈øupport the Mi≈øeries that we have endured.

All the Difficulties related we have actually endur'd, and perhaps mu≈øt endure more: Till the Commodore's Arrival we cannot know our Fate; at pre≈øent we are out of all Employment, and have nothing to ≈øupport our≈øelves and Families, but the Profits ari≈øing from the Sale of our Journal; which perhaps may be the Sum Total we ≈øhall ever receive for our Voyage to the South-Seas By what is added to this Second Edition, it will appear, that after the Arrival of the Captain, the Officers were try'd for the Loft of the Ship, and being all acquitted, except Lieutenant Beans, they were paid their Wages to the Time the Ship was wreck'd..

div.head: A VOYAGE TO THE SOUTH SEAS.
div.p: ON Thur≈øday the 18th of September 1740, ≈øailed from St. Hellens his Maje≈øty's Ship Centurion, Commodore An≈øon, with the Glouce≈øter, Pearl, Severn, Wager, and Tryal, and two Store Ships; this Squadron was de≈øign'd round Cape Horn into the South Seas, to di≈øtre≈øs the Spaniards in tho≈øe Parts. The Ships were all in prime Order, all lately rebuilt. The Men were elevated with Hopes of growing immen≈øely rich, and in a few Years of returning to Old England loaden with the Wealth of their Enemies.

Saturday, the 20th, the Ram-head bearing N. by W. half W. di≈øtant four Leagues, the Commodore hoi≈øted his broad Pendant, and was ≈øaluted by every Ship in the Squadron, with thirteen Guns each. This Day join'd Company with us his Maje≈øty's Ships, Dragon, Winche≈øter, Chatham, South-Sea-Ca≈øtle, and Rye-Galley, with a large Convoy of Merchant Ships.
Thur≈øday, the 25th, we parted Company with the Winche≈øter and the South-Sea-Ca≈øtle, with their Convoys, bound for America.
On Monday, we parted Company with the Streights and Turky Convoys.

Friday, October the 3d, at Eight in the Morning, we ≈øaw two Brigantines to the South Ea≈øt; the Commodore gave a Signal to chace; at Nine fired two ≈øhot to bring 'em to; at Ten ≈øpoke with the Chace, being two Brigs from Li≈øbon, bound for New-York.

Sunday, the 26th, about Five in the Morning, the Severn ≈øhowed Lights, and fired ≈øeveral Guns a-head; ≈øoon after we ≈øaw the Land bearing W. by S. and at Noon the Ea≈øt End of Madeira bore North, di≈øtant five Leagues.

Wedne≈øday we moored in Fonchiale road, ≈øo called from a City of that Name, which
is the Metropolis of the I≈øland of Madeira; here we employ'd mo≈øt of our Time in getting aboard Water, and ≈øtowing our dry Provi≈øions between Decks.

Tue≈øday, November the 4th, Captain Kidd our Commander was removed on board the Pearl, and the Honourable Captain Murray ≈øucceeded him in the Wager. Captain Norris of the Glouce≈øter having obtained Leave to return to England, on account of his ill State of Health, occa≈øioned the above removals.

While we lay at Madeira, we were informed of ten Sail of Ships crui≈øing off and on, to the We≈øtward; the≈øe Ships were judg'd to be French, and had been ≈øeen every Day for a Week before our Arrival: The Commodore ≈øent out a Privateer Sloop, but ≈øhe returned the Day following, without ≈øeeing 'em; ≈øo that we can give no Account of 'em.
On Wedne≈øday the 5th, we ≈øailed from Madeira. On the 20th the Indu≈øtry Store-Ship parted Company; and on Friday the 28th, by Account, we cro≈øs'd the Equinoctial.
On the 17th of December we ≈øaw the I≈øland of St. Catharine, at Noon; the Northmo≈øt Land in Sight bore W. N. W. and the Southmo≈øt S. W. by W. Variation per Amplitude ‚Ä¢ 3.57 Ea≈øterly.
On the 18th, the North End of the I≈øland of St. Catharine bore N. W. by W. di≈øtant ≈øeven Leagues; and the I≈øland of Gaul bore N. W. di≈øtant ≈øix Leagues.

On the 19th we anchor'd in St. Catharine's Bay in upward of twelve Fathom Water, the I≈øland Gaul, on the Coa≈øt of Brazil, bearing N. by E. di≈øtant four Leagues. On the 20th we anchor'd in St. Catharine's road, and the Day following we moored between the I≈øland of St. Catharine's and the Main.
On Monday the 22d, the Commodore ordered fre≈øh Beef for the ≈øick People.
On the 27th came in a Portugue≈øe Brig from Rio Janeiro, for the Rio Grand: While we lay here, the People were generally imploy'd in over-hauling the rigging, and getting aboard Water.
On the 17th of January 1741, we ≈øailed from St. Catharine's; the Commodore ≈øaluted the Fort with eleven Guns, the Fort returned the ≈øame Number.
On Thur≈øday the 22d we lo≈øt ≈øight of the Pearl.

On Tue≈øday the 17th of February, the Pearl join'd the Squadron; and on the 19th we came to Anchor off the river of St. Julian's, on the Coa≈øt of Patagonia, St. Julian's
Hill bearing S. W. by W. and the Southmo≈øt Land in ≈øight S. by E. di≈øtant from the Shore three Leagues. This Day our Captain, the Honourable George Murray, took Command on Board the Pearl, Captain Kidd having died on the Voyage ≈øince we left St. Catharine's.

Captain Kidd was heard to ≈øay, a few Days before his Death, That this Voyage, which both Officers and Sailors had engag'd in, with ≈øo much Cheerfulne≈øs and Alacrity, would prove in the End very far from their Expectations, notwith≈øtanding the va≈øt Trea≈øure they imagined to gain by it; that it would end in Poverty, Vermin, Famine, Death and De≈øtruction. How far the Captain's Words were prophetick, will appear in the Cour≈øe of our Journal. Captain Cheap ≈øucceeded Captain Murray on Board the Wager.

On the 26th of February we ≈øent on Board the Pearl twelve Butts and two Puncheons of Water; the Pearl having, while ≈øhe was ≈øeparated from us, been cha≈øed by five large Spani≈øh Men of War, the Commander in Chief being di≈øtingui≈øh'd by a red broad Pendant with a Swallow's Tail at his Main-top-ma≈øt Head, and a red Flag at his En≈øign-≈øtaff:
During the Chace, the Pearl, in order to clear Ship, threw over-board and ≈øtove fourteen Tons of Water; ≈øhe likewi≈øe ≈øtove the Long Boat, and threw her over-board, with Oars, Sails and Booms, and made all clear for engaging; but Night coming on, at Seven o'Clock lo≈øt Sight of the Enemy; at Five in the Morning ≈øaw the Spani≈øh Ships from the Ma≈øt-head, two Points on the Lee-quarter, ≈øtill giving Chace, and crowding all the Sail they could; but at Nine the Pearl lo≈øt Sight of 'em entirely. We judg'd this to be Admiral P ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ arro's Squadron, ≈øent out in Pur≈øuit of Commodore An≈øon. Had our Ships united fallen in with 'em, 'tis probable we might have given a good Account of 'em. While we lay at St. Julian's, we ≈øaw the Sea full of Shrimps, and red as if they were boiled; the Water appeared tinctured to that Degree, that it look'd like Blood.

On the 27th, we ≈øent on board the Pearl four Puncheons of Water more; at Six in the Morning, the Commodore made Signal to weigh; at Eight weigh'd, and came to Sail; this Day we lo≈øt Sight of the Glouce≈øter.
The 28th, the Glouce≈øter came into the Squadron again.

would purcha≈øe a pretty E≈øtate; there are ≈øeveral hundred Yards of Cloth about it, be≈øides the Curtains and Linings, which are Shalloon and Camblet; in ≈øhort, con≈øidering where we are, we cannot de≈øire a better Habitation. It is the Opinion of the Navigators, that going through the Streights of Magellan is the ≈øafe≈øt and only Way to pre≈øerve Life and Liberty: The Arti≈øts, who have worked the Bearings and Di≈øtance, are very pre≈ø≈øing that it ≈øhould be moved to the Captain, purpo≈øing to have their rea≈øons drawn up, and ≈øigned by all who are willing to go that Way, and to be delivered to the Captain for his Opinion: upon this there was a Paper drawn up, and as ≈øoon as the People heard it, they came flocking to ≈øign fir≈øt, crying all aloud for the Streights, ≈øeeming overjoyed, as if they were going to England directly, without any Affliction or Trouble, but there mu≈øt be a great deal of Hard≈øhip to be encountered before we arrive at our native Country: This Paper was ≈øigned by all the Officers on the Spot, except the Captain, Lieutenant, Pur≈øer, and Surgeon, and by all the Seamen in general, except the Captain's Steward.

Tue≈øday the 4th, at the Time of ≈øerving at the Store-hou≈øe, about Twelve o'Clock, „Äà‚óä„Äâ went to the Captain, with the Ma≈øter, Carpenter, and Boat≈øwain, and read to him the Paper; he an≈øwered, he would con≈øider of it, and give his An≈øwer: Here follows a Copy of the Paper ≈øigned.

WE who≈øe Names are under-mentioned, do, upon mature Con≈øideration, as we have met with ≈øo happy a Deliverance, think it the be≈øt, ≈øure≈øt, and mo≈øt ≈øafe Way, for the Pre≈øervation of the Body of People on the Spot, to proceed through the Streights of Magellan for England. Dated at a de≈øolate I≈øland on the Coa≈øt of Patagonia, in the Latitude of 47 Deg. 00 Min. South, and We≈øt Longitude from the Meridian of London 81 Deg, 40 Min ‚Ä¢ in the South-Seas, this 2d Day of Augu≈øt 1741.
We who≈øe Names are under-mentioned, have had ≈øufficient rea≈øons, from the abovemention'd People, to con≈øent to go this Way, Sign'd by

list.item: Capt. Robert Pemberton, Commander of his Maje≈øty's Land-Forces.

div.p: Wedne≈øday the 5th, this Day I went with the Ma≈øter, Carpenter, Ma≈øter's Mate, and Mid≈øhipmen, to the Captain, to acquaint him with what was done, and re≈øolv'd on; and farther told him, It was a Duty incumbent on us to pre≈øerve Life before any other Intere≈øt. He an≈øwer'd, Gentlemen, I de≈øire Time to con≈øider of it, and will give you my final Determination; on which we took our Leave, and came away.

Thur≈øday the 6th, hard Gales at W. S. W. and rainy Weather. At Noon went with Mr. Cummins to Captain Pemberton's Tent, to have ≈øome farther Conference for our future Deliverance. While we were there, the Captain ≈øent his Service to Capt. Cheap for a Pair of Pocket-Pi≈øtols, his own Property, which had been refu≈øed him on his reque≈øt ≈øome Time before. The Servant
was an≈øwer'd by the Captain's Favourite, and Prime Mini≈øter, the Steward, The Captain is ill, and I can't let you have 'em. This an≈øwer not being ≈øatisfactory to Capt. Pemberton, he ≈øent a ≈øecond Time, and in≈øi≈øted on the Delivery of his Pi≈øtols; but was an≈øwer'd, they could not be come at before the Captain was up; but a little Time after it was judg'd proper to ≈øend Captain Pemberton his Pi≈øtols. From Captain Pemberton's we went to the Lieutenant's Tent; while there, the Lieutenant was ≈øent for to Captain Cheap; about an Hour after the Carpenter and my≈øelf were ≈øent for; when we came to him, he ≈øaid, Gentlemen, I have maturely con≈øider'd the Contents of your Paper, ≈øo far as it regards the Pre≈øervation of the People on the Spot: This Paper has given me a great deal of Unea≈øine≈øs, in≈øomuch that I have not clos'd my Eyes till Eight o'Clock this Morning, for thinking of it; but, I think, you have not weigh'd the Thing rightly; do you know we are above one hundred and ≈øixty Leagues di≈øtant S. W. from the Sreights of Magellan, with the Wind again≈øt us? Then think on the Di≈øtance to be run afterwards on the other Side the Streights, with the Wind always again≈øt us, and where no Water is to be
had. I an≈øwer'd, Sir, you ≈øay it is above one hundred and ≈øixty Leagues to the Streights; but let the Navigators work it, and they will find it not above ninety Leagues; your≈øelf and Lieutenant are undoubtedly Navigators and Judges, therefore will certainly find it as I ≈øay. Mr. Cummins acquainted him, according to his Calculation, the Ve≈ø≈øel would carry a Month's Water at a Quart a Man per Diem; and, Sir, do you con≈øider, after running a-long Shore to the Northward this Side the Land, that we have one hundred Leagues to run right out to Sea to the I≈øland of Juan Ferdinandez; and five hundred Chances to one, if we meet the Commodore there, or any of the Squadron; nor do we know but the Commodore may have ≈øhared the ≈øame Fate with our≈øelves, or perhaps wor≈øe? The Captain an≈øwer'd, It's a thou≈øand to one if we ≈øee the Commodore at Juan Ferdinandez; for, Gentlemen, to let you into a Secret which I never di≈øcover'd before, we ≈øhall meet him at Baldavia, his Orders were from‚Äîto go there with the Squadron, it being a Place of little or no Force. Mr. Cummins an≈øwer'd, Sir, 'tis agreed, the Commodore is at Baldavia; but we make it in our Bargain, when we go from hence, that we
wi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ put a≈øhore at every Place when we want Water, whenever the Weather will permit, without any Ob≈øtruction. The Captain reply'd, There is no Occa≈øion for that; we will water at the I≈ølands, and take a Ve≈ø≈øel going along. Mr. Cummins ≈øaid, Sir, what ≈øhall we do with a Ve≈ø≈øel, without Provi≈øions, for ninety Souls? The Captain an≈øwer'd, We will take a Ve≈ø≈øel loaden with Flour from Chili, there being a great many Trading Ve≈ø≈øels that Way; and then we will proceed through the Streights of Magellan. Mr. Cummins ≈øaid, How ≈øhall we take a Ve≈ø≈øel without Guns not having any but Mu≈økets, and our Enemies know as well as our≈øelves, that we have a Squadron in the≈øe Seas, therefore undoubtedly are well arm'd, and keep a good Look-out. The Captain's An≈øwer to this was, What are our ≈ømall Arms for, but t ‚Ä¢ board 'em? The Carpenter ≈øaid, Sir, if a Shot ≈øhould take the Beat under Water, it would not be in my Power to ≈øtop a Leak of that kind, where the Plank is ≈øo thin, that in ≈øome Places it is not above three Quarters of an ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ch thick. The Captain then ≈øaid, Gentlemen, I am agreeable to any Thing, and willing to go any Way, for the Pre≈øervation of the People; but at the ≈øame Time
would have you con≈øider of it, the Wind being always again≈øt us on the other Side the Land, and we have above ≈øeven hundred Leagues to the river Plate. I an≈øwer'd the Captain, 'Tis not above five hundred and ninety Leagues from hence to Cape St. Antonio's; and, as I have before ≈øaid, let the Navigators work it, and rea≈øon take Place, which is what we chiefly de≈øire to be govern'd by: Another Inducement we have to go the Way propos'd is, that we may be a≈ø≈øur'd of Water and Provi≈øion. I allow that, ≈øays the Captain, and we may ≈øave our own; but how do you know whether we may not meet Enemies in the Streights? I reply'd to the Captain, We can have no Enemies to encounter there but Indians in their Canoes, and tho≈øe we can ma≈øter at our Plea≈øure. The Captain then ≈øeem'd to countenance our Opinion again, and ≈øaid, When we come to St. Julian's we ≈øhall be ≈øure of Salt in Plenty for our Provi≈øions, without which our Fowls will not keep above two or three Days: Be≈øides, when we come to the river Plate, we may meet with a Prize, they not being acquainted with any Engli≈øh Ve≈ø≈øel like ours, with Schooner Sails; by which Means we may run up the river, and take a larger
Ve≈ø≈øel: If we fail here, we may go a≈øhore, and get what Cattle we plea≈øe; but what Bu≈øine≈øs have we at the Rio Grand? We mu≈øt go to the Rio Janeiro. I told him, we ≈øhould be oblig'd to ≈øtop at every Place a-long Shore for Supplies; at St. Catharine's the Governor will give us a Certificate, ≈øo that we ≈øhall be known to be the People that were there in the Squadron. The Captain ≈øaid, That's true, and I can get Bills of Credit in any Part of Brazil; be≈øides, the People may be ≈øeparated, ≈øome in the Flota, and ≈øome in other Ships; with le≈øs Hands we may go to Barbados. Mr. Cummins told him, We might venture to England with twelve Hands. Yes, you may, ≈øays the Captain, with thirty. It is to be ob≈øerv'd, during all this Debate, the Lieutenant ≈øpoke not a Word. The Carpenter a≈øking him the rea≈øon of his Silence i ‚Ä¢ all the Con≈øulation he; an≈øwer'd, I'll give my Opinion hereafter. The Captain ≈øaid, I knew nothing of his being acquainted with it, till Mr. Bulkeley told me Ye≈øterday; but at the ≈øame Time, Mr. Beans, I expect you will be the fir≈øt that will ≈øign the Paper. I imagin'd the Captain meant our Paper, and immediately an≈øwer'd with ≈øome Warmth, As he had refus'd ≈øigning at fir≈øt, and at the
≈øame Time agreed to the Propo≈øal, that I had ≈øign'd ≈øo clo≈øe, that there was no room left for his Name, and now it was too late for him to ≈øign. The Captain ≈øurpriz'd me, by ≈øaying, I don't mean your Paper. I told him, Any other, which ≈øhould be contrary to ours, would never be ≈øign'd by us. Mr. Cummins ≈øaid to the Captain, Sir, 'tis all owing to you that we are here; if you had con≈øulted your Officers, we might have avoided this Misfortune; con≈øidering the Condition the Ship was in, ≈øhe was not fit to come in with the Land, all our Men being ≈øick, and not above three Seamen in a Watch; ≈øuppo≈øe the Ma≈øt had gone by the Board, as was every Moment expected. The Captain made An≈øwer, Gentlemen, you do not know my Orders, there never were any ≈øo ≈øtrict given to a Commander before; and had I but two Men living be≈øides my≈øelf, I mu≈øt, and was obliged to go to the fir≈øt rendezvous, which was the I≈øland of No≈øtra Senhora di Socora: I was obliged to go there at all Events. I made An≈øwer to this, Sir, if that is the Ca≈øe, it ≈øeems plain, the Thing was de≈øign'd we ≈øhould be here; But, Sir, I am of Opinion, notwith≈øtanding the Commodore had his Orders from ‚Äîto go with the Squadron to Baldavia,
that at the ≈øame Time tho≈øe Orders were ≈øo far di≈øcretional, that if the Squadron was di≈øabled, Care was to be taken not to endanger his Maje≈øty's Ships. Yes, that (≈øays the Captain) was ≈øettled at St. Julian's: Notwith≈øtanding what has been ≈øaid, Gentlemen, I am agreeable to take any Chance with you, and to go any Way; but would have you con≈øider of it, and defer your Determination till all is ready to go off the Spot. I then told the Captain, You have known, Sir, from the Time you ≈øaw the Propo≈øal, that the People are unea≈øy, and the Work is at a Stand, and in this Situation Things will be until this Affair is ≈øettled; therefore the ≈øooner you re≈øolve, the better. The Captain reply'd, I de≈øign to have a Con≈øultation among my Officers: Have you any more Objections to make? I an≈øwer'd, Yes, Sir, one more; which is, When you go from hence, you are not to weigh, come to an Anchor, or alter Cour≈øe, without con≈øulting your Officers. The Captain ≈øaid, Gentlemen, I was your Commander till the Ship parted, or as long as any Stores or Provi≈øions were getting out of her. We told him, we had always taken Care to obey his Orders in the ≈øtricte≈øt Manner; which he allow'd us to have done; and
he added, You were the Officers that I placed my whole Dependence in. We an≈øwer'd, Sir, we will ≈øupport you with our Lives, at long as you ≈øuffer rea≈øon to rule; and then we parted. After this Con≈øultation the Captain ≈øeldom came out of his Tent, which occa≈øion'd great Di≈øturbances among the People.

Friday the 7th, the Wind at W. N. W. with rain. This Day the Navigators work'd the Bearings and Di≈øtance along Shore, from one Place to another, to know the true Di≈øtance: Hereupon it was agreed to proceed through the Streights of Magellan, according to Sir John Narborough's Directions, which give us great Encouragement to go that Way. Captain Pemberton draw'd his Men up, and di≈ømi≈øs'd 'em again. Great Unea≈øine≈øs among the People.

Saturday the 8th, this Morning went to the Lieutenant, for him to acquaint the Captain all his Officers were ready to give ≈øufficient rea≈øons for going through the Streights of Magellan, de≈øiring a Con≈øultation might be held in the Afternoon. At Three o'Clock the Captain ≈øent for me and Mr. Cummins; when we came, the Ma≈øter and Bort≈øwain were ≈øent for, but they were gone in Search of Sub≈øi≈øtence, as Limpets, Mu≈øcles, &c.
The Captain ≈øaid, Gentlemen, I don't doubt but you have con≈øider'd upon the Bu≈øine≈øs you are come about; therefore I am determin'd to take my Fate, with you, or where the Spirit of the People leads, and ≈øhall u≈øe my be≈øt Endeavours for their Pre≈øervation; but I am afraid of meeting contrary Winds, for after the Sun has cro≈øs'd the Line we mu≈øt expect to meet 'em. I made An≈øwer, By all Accounts, the Wind hangs from N. W. to the S. W. above three Parts of the Year; which is in our Favour. Mr. Cummins told him, There was fre≈øh Water to be got as well on one Coa≈øt as the other; and if Sir John Narborough's Treatment was ≈øo ill in a profound Peace, what mu≈øt we expect in a Time of open War? The Captain ≈øaid, I am afraid very bad. Then Mr. Cummins ≈øpoke in this Manner to the Captain: Sir, I always took you for an honourable Gentleman, and I believe you to be ≈øuch; on your Honour, Sir, I beg you will give the true Sentiments of your Mind, whether thro' the Streights is not the ≈øure≈øt and ≈øafe≈øt Way to pre≈øerve our Lives, notwith≈øtanding we have a Thou≈øand Difficulties to encounter with any Way? The Captain an≈øwer'd, I really think going to the Northward is the
≈øafe≈øt Way; for ≈øuppo≈øe we ≈øhould be drove off to Sea, when on the other Side the Land, what is to be done then? I ≈øaid, Sir, it is our Bu≈øine≈øs to keep the Shore, to prevent all Accidents that may happen that Way. Then Lieutenant Beans made an Objection, Suppo≈øe you have the Wind blowing right in, and a tumbling Sea, ≈øo as to endanger the Boat, what are we to do? I made An≈øwer, Sir, If you remember, when we were riding at St. Julian's, it blow'd a very hard Gale of Wind right in from the Sea, yet, even then, the Sea did not run ≈øo high as to endanger a Boat riding at Anchor: Another In≈øtance I bring you from St. Catherine's, when we had ≈øuch hard Gales, that the Tryal lo≈øt her Ma≈øts, and the Pearl ≈øeparated from the Squadron; yet, at that Time, there was no Sea comparable to what we have met with this Side the Land. The Lieutenant allow'd this to be Fact. Then the Captain ≈øaid, I will allow you to have Water at Port De≈øire; but do you con≈øider the lengthening your Di≈øtance, by keeping along Shore, and rounding every Bay, and ≈øome of tho≈øe Bays are very deep. I told him, That undoubtedly there was Water all along the Coa≈øt, and that we had no Bu≈øine≈øs to round the Bays, but to ≈øteer from
one Head-land to the other. Then Lieutenant Beans made a ≈øecond Objection, Suppo≈øe we are forced into a Bay, and Shoal-Water? I an≈øwer'd, We ≈øhould always have a Boat a-head, and our Draught of Water will not be above four or five Feet at mo≈øt; and if we ≈øhould be ≈øo unfortunate as to lo≈øe our Boat, we mu≈øt keep the Lead a going. The Lieutenant reply'd, That was true, and there could not be a great deal of Difficulty in it. This was the only Time the Lieutenant ever ≈øpoke in Publick on the Affair; he always allow'd, when ab≈øent from the Captain, that going through the Streights was the be≈øt Way; but in the Captain's Pre≈øence he ≈øided with him, and was for going to the Northward.

Sunday the 9th, at Three this Afternoon, I went with Mr. Cummins, the Ma≈øter, and Boat≈øwain, as de≈øir'd, to the Captain, to give him our Opinions, believing, going thro' the Streights the ≈øure≈øt Way to pre≈øerve Life: It was therefore agreed, That if the Wind did not ≈øet in again≈øt us, at the Sun's Cro≈ø≈øing the Line, that the Captain would go that Way. The Captain ask'd every Man's Opinion, and found the People unanimous for the Streights of Magellan. To-day, being
fair Weather, launch'd the Yawl to go a Fowling; ≈øhot ≈øeveral Gee≈øe, Ducks, Shaggs, and Sea-pies. Heel'd the Long-Boat for planking.

Monday the 10th, Wind at N. and N.N.W. rainy Weather. Eat Slaugh and Sea-weed fry'd with Tallow-Candles, which we pick'd up along Shore; this we reckon at pre≈øent exceeding good Eating, having nothing to live on but a Quarter of a Pound of Flour a Man per Day, and what we can get off the rocks; for many Days the Weather has been ≈øo bad, that we have not been able to ≈øtir abroad, though almo≈øt ≈øtarv'd for want of Food.

Tue≈øday the 11th, hard Gales at S. W. with heavy rains. This Afternoon the People came in Arms to acquaint us of the Stores being robbed; they therefore wanted our Con≈øent for moving the Stores to our Tent; on which we de≈øir'd they would de≈øi≈øt from offering any Violence; we told 'em of the ill Con≈øequence of Mutiny, which, as we always abhorr'd, we took all imaginable Care to prevent: The People, on our Per≈øua≈øions, in≈øtantly quitted their Arms. The Captain pre≈øently ≈øent for me and Mr. Cummins, to acquaint us with what had happen'd: He
told us, the Pur≈øer accidentally coming by, ≈øaw the Pri≈øoner, Rowland Cru≈ø≈øet, a Marine, crawling from the Bu≈øhes, and from under the Store-Tent, and found on him upwards of a Day's Flour for Ninety Souls, with one Piece of Beef under his Coat, and three Pieces more, which were conceal'd in the Bu≈øhes, to carry off when an Opportunity offer'd; and the Centry, Thomas Smith, his Me≈øs-mate, a Marine, undoubtedly was privy to the robbery. The Captain farther ≈øaid, We have nothing to do with them; but I ≈øhall ≈øend to Captain Pemberton to in≈øi≈øt on a Court-Martial: I really think, that for robbing the Store-Tent (which, in our pre≈øent Circum≈øtances, is ≈øtarving the whole Body of People) the Pri≈øoners de≈øerve Death. This was not only the Captain's Opinion, but indeed the Sentiments of every Per≈øon pre≈øent. After we parted from the Captain, we were ≈øent for by Capt. Pemberton: He acquainted us, he would go as far as the Martial Law would allow him, and in Conjunction with the Sea-Officers: I look (≈øaid he) on the Lieutenant as nothing, and the Captain in the ≈øame Light: As for you two (meaning the Gunner and Carpenter) I confide in, and ≈øhall have regard to your Opinions. When the Articles
of War were read, we found their Crime did not touch Life, but that they were to ≈øuffer Corporal Puni≈øhment. Whil≈øt Mr. Cummins was laying open the Nature of their Guilt, and the ill Con≈øequence of Lenity in the Circum≈øtances we were in, I propos'd a Way, next to Death; which was, if judg'd proper by Captain Pemberton and Captain Cheap, to carry them off to an I≈øland where the Ship parted, there being Mu≈øcles, Limpets, and Clams in Abundance, and no want of Water, and there to be left till we ≈øhould be ready for ≈øailing; and, to ≈øtrike a Terror in all for the future, that if any Man ≈øhould be guilty of the like Offence, without any re≈øpect of Per≈øon, he ≈øhould ≈øhare the ≈øame Fate. This Propo≈øal was approved of by both the Captains. At Night Lieutenant Beans ≈øurpriz'd us with a new kind of Propo≈øal we little dreamt of, which was, to have a proper Place of Devotion to perform Divine Service in every Sabbath-Day: For this Sacred Office our Tent was judg'd the mo≈øt commodious Place. The Duty of publick Prayer had been entirely neglected on board, though every Seaman pays Four-pence per Month towards the Support of a Mini≈øter; yet Devotion, in ≈øo ≈øolemn a Manner, is ≈øo rarely
perform'd that I know but one In≈øtance of it during the many Years I have belong'd to the Navy. We believe religion to have the lea≈øt Share in this Propo≈øal of the Lieutenant. If our Tent ≈øhould be turn'd into a a Hou≈øe of Prayer, and this Project takes, we may, perhaps, in the Mid≈øt of our Devotion, be ≈øurpriz'd, and our Arms taken from us, in order to fru≈øtrate our De≈øigns, and prevent our return to England through the Streights of Magellan, or any other Way.

Wedne≈øday the 12th, hard Gales from S.W. to W. with heavy Showers of Hail and rain. Serv'd out Provi≈øions To-day, a Piece of Beef for four Men; ≈øome Time pa≈øt we have had but a Quarter of a Pound of Flour per Man per Day, and three Pieces of Beef; we live chiefly on Mu≈ø≈øles, Limpits, and Clams, with Saragraza and Thromba; one is a green broad Weed, common on the rocks in England; the other is a round Sea-Weed, ≈øo large, that a Man can ≈øcarce gra≈øp it; it grows in the Sea, with broad Leaves; this la≈øt we boil, the Saragraza we fry in Tallow; in this Manner we ≈øupport Life: Even tho≈øe Shell-Fi≈øh and Weeds we get with great Difficulty; for the Wind, the rain, and Coldne≈øs of the Climate in this Sea≈øon, are ≈øo extremely ≈øevere,
that a Man will pau≈øe ≈øome Time whether he ≈øhall ≈øtay in his Tent and ≈øtarve, or go out in Que≈øt of Food.

Friday the 14th, very hard Gales at W. and N. W. with Showers of rain and Hail, which beat with ≈øuch Violence again≈øt a Man's Face, that he can hardly with≈øtand it; however, one of our Me≈øs-mates To-day ≈øhot three Gulls and a Hawk; which gave us a very elegant repa≈øt. This Day was held a Court-Martial on the Centry who was believ'd confederated with the Marine that robbed the Store-Tent: Sentence was pa≈øs'd on 'em to receive ≈øix hundred La≈øhes each: Captain Cheap, not thinking the Puni≈øhment adequate to the Crime, cut 'em ≈øhort of their Allowance; ≈øo that they have now but half the Provi≈øions they had before: The Day following the Offenders receiv'd Two Hundred La≈øhes each, as Part of their Puni≈øhment. We hawl'd the Long-Boat higher up, for fear the Sea ≈øhould wa≈øh the Blocks from under her. We have found out a new Way of managing the Slaugh; we fry it in thin Batter with Tallow, and u≈øe it as Bread.

Sunday the 16th, Fre≈øh Gales of Wind at S. W. with heavy Showers of Hail: The People generally complain of a Malady in
their Eyes; they are in great Pain, and can ≈øcarce ≈øee to walk about. The la≈øt Tide flowed nine Feet perpendicular; To-day we picked up Shell-Fi≈øh in Abundance, with Pieces of Beef and Pork. The Pri≈øoners received two Hundred La≈øhes more.

Tue≈øday the 18th, this Day the Carpenter, who has all along been indefatigable in working about the Long-Boat, ≈øaw one of the Seamen cutting up an Anchor Stock for Fire-Wood, which had been de≈øigned for a particular U≈øe for the Boat; at Sight of the Fellow's Folly be could not contain him≈øelf: This Affair, added to the little Concern and intollerable Indifference that appeared in the Generality of the People, for ≈øome Time impaired his Under≈øtanding, and made him delirious; all po≈ø≈øible Methods are u≈øed to re≈øtore him, as he is the only Man, who, through the A≈ø≈øi≈øtance of Providence, can compleat the Means of our Deliverance.

Wedne≈øday the 19th, The Carpenter was ≈øo much recovered, that he went to work as u≈øual; at Night, the Lieutenant acquainted us, that the Captain de≈øired to ≈øpeak with the Carpenter and me To-morrow at Noon, to con≈øult what ≈øhould be done with the Two Pri≈øoners, having received but Four Hundrrd
La≈øhes out of the Six, to which they were ≈øentenced by a Court-Martial, the other Two Hundred being remitted by their own Officers.

Thur≈øday the 20th, We waited on the Captain, who acquainted us with what the Lieutenant had mentioned la≈øt Night relating to the Pri≈øoners: We told him the People were very unea≈øy about this Mitigation of the Puni≈øhment inflicted on them by a Court Martial; therefore it was agreed they ≈øhould provide for them≈øelves as well as they could; but to have no Sort of Provi≈øions out of the Store-Tent for the future.
Saturday the 22d, we begun upon ≈øeveral Contrivances to get Provi≈øions, ≈øuch as building Punts, Ca≈øk-Boats, Leather-Boats, and the like.

Tue≈øday the 25th, This Day felt Four great Earthquakes, three of which were very terrible; notwith≈øtanding the≈øe violent Shocks and Tremblings of the Earth, we find no Ground ≈øhifted. Hard Gales of Wind at the North, with heavy Showers of rain.

He was an≈øwer'd, Yes, Sir, our A≈ø≈øi≈øtance was demanded by Captain Pemberton, to ≈øecure you as a Pri≈øoner for the Death of Mr. Cozens; and as we are Subjects of Great-Britain, we are oblig'd to take you as ≈øuch to England. The Captain ≈øaid, Gentlemen, Captain Pemberton hath nothing to do with me; I am your Commander ≈øtill; I will ≈øhew you my In≈øtructions; which he did to the People; on this we came out. He then call'd his Officers a ≈øecond Time, and ≈øaid, What is this for? He was an≈øwer'd, as before, That A≈ø≈øi≈øtance was demanded by Captain Pemberton to take him Pri≈øoner for the Death of Mr. Cozens. He ≈øtill in≈øi≈øted, Captain Pemberton has no Bu≈øine≈øs with me; I could not think you would ≈øerve me ≈øo. It was told him, Sir, it is your own Fault: you have given your≈øelf no manner of Concern, for the Publick Good, on our going from hence; but have acted quite the rever≈øe, or el≈øe been ≈øo carele≈øs and indifferent about it, as if we had no Commander; and if other Per≈øons had given them≈øelves no more Trouble and Concern than you have, we ≈øhould not be ready to go from hence as long as Provi≈øions la≈øted. The Captain ≈øaid, Very well, Gentlemen, you have
caught me Napping; I do not ≈øee any of you in Liquor; you are a Parcel of brave Fellows, but my Officers are Scoundrels: Then turning him≈øelf to me, he ≈øaid, Gunner, where's my Lieutenant? Did not he Head You? I told him, No, Sir; but was here to ≈øee it executed, and is here now. One of you (≈øays the Captain) call Mr. Beans. When Mr. Beans came, he ≈øaid, What is all this for, Sir? Sir, it is Captain Pemberton's Order. Captain Pemberton hath no Bu≈øine≈øs with me, and you will an≈øwer for it hereafter; if I do not live to ≈øee England, I hope ≈øome of my Friends will. On this the Lieutenant left him. The Captain then addre≈øs'd him≈øelf to the Seamen, ≈øaying, My Lads, I do not blame you; but it is the Villany of my Officers, which they will an≈øwer for hereafter. He then call'd Mr. Beans again, and ≈øaid, Well, Sir, what do you de≈øign to do by me? The Lieutenant an≈øwer'd, Sir, your Officers have de≈øign'd the Pur≈øer's Tent for you. Hum! I ≈øhould be obliged to the Gentlemen, if they would let me ≈øtay in my own Tent. The Lieutenant came to acquaint the Officers of the Captain's reque≈øt; but they judg'd it inconvenient; as Mr. Hamilton's Tent join'd the Pur≈øer's, one Guard might ≈øerve
'em both; accordingly all his Things were mov'd to the Pur≈øer's Tent: As he was coming along, he ≈øaid, Gentlemen, you mu≈øt excu≈øe my not pulling my Hat off, my Hands are confin'd. Well, Captain Beans! you will be call'd to an Account for this hereafter. The Boat≈øwain, after the Captain's Confinement, mo≈øt barbarou≈øly in≈øulted him, reproaching him with ≈øtriking him, ≈øaying, Then it was your Time; but now, G‚Äîd d‚Äîn you, it is mine. The Captain made no reply but this, You are a Scoundrel for u≈øing a Gentleman ill when he is a Pri≈øoner. When the Captain was a Pri≈øoner, he declared, he never intended to go to the Southward, having more Honour than to turn his Back on his Enemies; and farther, he ≈øaid, Gentlemen, I do not want to go off in any of your Craft; for I never de≈øign'd to go for England, and would rather chu≈øe to be ≈øhot by you; there is not a ≈øingle Man on the Beach dare engage me; but this is what I fear'd.

It is very odd, that Capt. Cheap ≈øhould now declare he never intended to go to the Southward, when he publickly gave his Word and Honour he would go that Way, or any Way where the Spirit of the People led: But he
afterwards told his Officers, he knew he had a ≈øevere Trial to go through, if ever he came to England; and as for tho≈øe who liv'd to return to their Country, the only Favour he reque≈øted from them, was to declare the Truth, without Favour or Prejudice; and this we promis'd faithfully to do: His Words, in this re≈øpect, were as much regarded by us as the Words of a dying Man, and have been mo≈øt punctually ob≈øerv'd.

Saturday the 10th, little Wind at N. and N. W. Getting all ready for going off this Afternoon, the Captain ≈øent for the Lieutenant and me, de≈øiring us both to go to Captain Pemberton, to know what he intended to do with him. We accordingly came, and both promis'd to go directly, and bring him his An≈øwer. When we came out, went to the Lieutenant's Tent; from thence I expected, and made no doubt, but he would go to Captain Pemberton's: But when I a≈øk'd him; he refus'd; which very much ≈øurpriz'd me. I thought it very ungenerous to triflle with Captain Cheap, or any Gentleman in his unhappy Situation; therefore went alone to Captain Pemberton. When I deliver'd him Captain Cheap's Me≈ø≈øage, the An≈øwer was, I de≈øign, and mu≈øt carry him Pri≈øoner to
England. I return'd, and acquainted Captain Cheap with Captain Pemberton's An≈øwer: He ask'd me then, if the Lieutenant was with me. I told him, No; and I believe did not de≈øign it. He ≈øaid, Mr. Bulkeley, I am very much oblig'd to you, and could not think the Lieutenant would u≈øe me thus. In the Evening the Lieutenant and I were ≈øent for again: The Captain ≈øaid to the Lieutenant, Sir, have you been with Captain Pemberton? He an≈øwer'd, No, Sir. I thought, Sir, you promis'd me you would: However, I have his An≈øwer from Mr. Bulkeley; I am to be carry'd a Pri≈øoner to England. Gentlemen, I ≈øhall never live to ≈øee England, but die by Inches in the Voyage; and it is ≈øurprizing to me to think, what you can expect by going to the Southward, where there are ten Thou≈øand Difficulties to be encounter'd with: I am ≈øorry ≈øo many brave Fellows ≈øhould be led to go where they are not acquainted, when, by going to the Northward, there is the I≈øland of Chili, not above ninety Leagues, where we need not fear taking Prizes, and may have a Chance to ≈øee the Commodore. I made An≈øwer, Sir, you have ≈øaid, that we ≈øhall be call'd to an Account for this in England: I mu≈øt tell you, for my Part, had I
been guilty of any Crime, and was ≈øure of being hang'd for it in England, I would make it my Choice to go there, ≈øooner than to the Northward: Have not you given your Word and Honour to go to the Southward? It is true, there is a Chance in going to the Northward, by delivering us from this unhappy Situation of Life to a wor≈øe, viz. a Spani≈øh Pri≈øon. The Captain ≈øaid no more but this, Gentlemen, I wi≈øh you well, and ≈øafe to England.

Sunday the 11th, this Morning the Captain ≈øent for me, and told me, he had rather be ≈øhot than carried off a Pri≈øoner, and that he would not go off with us; therefore de≈øired me to ask the People to ≈øuffer him to remain on the I≈øland: The People readily agreed to his reque≈øt; and al≈øo con≈øented to leave him all Things needful for his Support, as much as could be ≈øpar'd. Lieutenant Hamilton and the Surgeon cho≈øe to ≈øtay with him. We offer'd him al≈øo the Barge and Yawl, if he could procure Men to go with him. The Que≈øtion was propos'd before the whole Body; but they all cry'd aloud for England, and let him ≈øtay and be d‚Äîn'd; does he want to carry us to Pri≈øon? There is not a Man will go. The Captain being
depriv'd of his Command in the Manner above-mentioned, and for the rea≈øons already given, it was re≈øolv'd to draw ≈øome Articles to be ≈øign'd for the Good of the Community, and to give the Lieutenant a limited Command. The Paper was drawn up in this Manner:

WHereas Captain David Cheap, our Commander in his Maje≈øty's Ship the Wager, never con≈øulted any of his Officers for the Safety and Pre≈øervation of the ≈øaid Ship, and his Maje≈øty's Subjects thereto belonging; but ≈øeveral Times, ≈øince the unhappy Lo≈øs of the ≈øaid Ship, he has been ≈øolicited in the mo≈øt dutiful Manner, promi≈øing him at the ≈øame Time to ≈øupport his Command with our Lives, de≈øiring no more than to go off Heart in Hand from this Place to the Southward, which he gave his Word and Honour to do; and being almo≈øt ready for ≈øailing, did apply to him, ≈øome few Days pa≈øt, to draw up ≈øome proper Articles, in order to ≈øuppre≈øs Mutiny, and other material Things, which were thought nece≈ø≈øary to be agreed to before we went off; but he, in the mo≈øt ≈øcornful Manner, hath rejected every Thing propos'd for the Publick Good; and
as he is now a Pri≈øoner, and the Command given to the Lieutenant, upon his Approbation of the following Articles.

Fir≈øt, As we have no Conveniency for dre≈ø≈øing Provi≈øions on Board the Ve≈ø≈øel for a third Part of the Number to be carried off the Spot, therefore this Day ≈øerv'd ou ‚Ä¢ to every Man and Boy twelve Days Provi≈øion, for them to dre≈øs before we go off; and al≈øo it is agreed, that whoever is guilty of defrauding another of any Part of his Allowance, on ≈øufficient Proof thereof, the Per≈øon found guilty (without any re≈øpect of Per≈øon) ≈øhall be put on Shore at the fir≈øt convenient Place, and left there.

Secondly, In regard to the Boats going off with us, we think proper to allow one Week's Provi≈øion for each Man appointed to go in them, in order to prevent Separation from each other, which would be of the wor≈øt Con≈øequence of any Thing that can happen to us; to prevent which we do agree, that when under-way they ≈øhall not ≈øeparate, but always keep within Musket-≈øhot, and on no Pretence or Excu≈øe what≈øoever go beyond that reach. The Officer, or any other Per≈øon, that ≈øhall attempt a Separation, or exceed
the above mention'd Bounds, ≈øhall, on Proof, be put on ≈øhore and left behind.

Thirdly, It is agreed, in order to ≈øuppre≈øs Mutiny, and prevent Broils and Quarrels on Board the Ve≈ø≈øel, that no Man ≈øhall threaten the Life of another, or offer Violence in any Shape; the Offender, without any re≈øpect of Station or Quality, being found guilty, ≈øhall be put on Shore, and left behind.

Fourthly, We do agree, whatever Fowl, Fi≈øh, or Nece≈ø≈øaries of Life, we ≈øhall happen to meet with in our Pa≈ø≈øage, the ≈øame ≈øhall be divided among the whole; and if Captain David Cheap ≈øhall be put on Board a Pri≈øoner, it ≈øhall not be in the Lieutenant's Power to relea≈øe him.

The afore≈øaid Articles were agreed to, and ≈øign'd by the under-mentioned.
