Monday the 12th, at Day-light, launch'd the Long-Boat, and gave her the Name of the Speedwell (which God pre≈øerv'd to deliver us;) we got all the Provi≈øion on Board, and other Nece≈ø≈øaries. The Captain ≈øent for the Lieutenant, my≈øelf, and the Carpenter, de≈øiring us to leave him what could be ≈øpar'd, and to ≈øend to the De≈øerters to know if they will go in the Yawl to the Northward; we promis'd to grant him his reque≈øt. To-day every Body got on Board. The Captain, Surgeon, and Mr. Hamilton, had their Share of Provi≈øion equal with us.

Tue≈øday the 13th, we ≈øent the Barge to the De≈øerters, with Mr. Snow the Mate, to know if they were willing to tarry, and go
with the Captain to the Northward; to acquaint them what Provi≈øions and Nece≈ø≈øaries ≈øhould be allow'd 'em: They readily agreed to tarry. On the return of the Boat, deliver'd to the Captain the Share of Provi≈øion for the De≈øerters, and ≈øundry Nece≈ø≈øaries, as under-mention'd, viz.

list.item: One Pair of Pi≈øtols for the Captain.
Half a Pint of Sweet Oil.
Two Swords of the Captain's own.

div.p:
Provi≈øion deliver'd to the Captain, Surgeon, and Lieutenant Hamilton, with eight De≈øerters; which la≈øt are to be at half Allowance of the Quantity made out to the
People, which make the whole Number ≈øeven at whole Allowance.
To the Captain, Surgeon, and Lieutenant Hamilton.

For the De≈øerters:
Eight Pieces of Beef.
Eight Pieces of Pork.
Flower one hundred Weight.

As ≈øoon as the above Things were deliver'd, we got ready for ≈øailing. I went and took my Leave of the Captain: He repeated his Injunction, That at my return to England, I would impartially relate all Proceedings: He ≈øpoke to me in the mo≈øt tender and affectionate Manner; and as a Token of his Friend≈øhip and regard for me, de≈øir'd me to accept of a Suit of his be≈øt Wearing Apparel: At parting, he gave me his Hand with a great deal of Chearfulne≈øs, wi≈øhing me well and ≈øafe to England. This was the la≈øt Time I ever ≈øaw the u ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ortunate Captain Cheap. However, we hope to ≈øee him again in England,
that Mr. Cummins and my≈øelf may be freed from ≈øome heavy Imputations to our Prejudice laid on us by the Gentleman who ≈øucceeded him in Command, and who, having an Opportunity of arriving before us in England, not only in the Places he touch'd at Abroad, but at Home, has blacken'd us with the greate≈øt Calumnies; and by an imperfect Narrative, has not only traduc'd us, but made the whole Affair ≈øo dark and my≈øtical, that, till the Captain's Arrival, the Lords of the Admiralty will not decide for or again≈øt us. But if that unfortunate Captain never returns to his Country, let us do ≈øo much Ju≈øtice to his Character, to declare, that he was a Gentleman po≈ø≈øe≈øs'd of many Virtues; he was an excellent Seaman him≈øelf, and lov'd a Seaman; as for per≈øonal Bravery, no Man had a larger Share of it; even when a Pri≈øoner, he pre≈øerv'd the Dignity of a Commander; no Misfortunes could di≈øpirit or deject him, and Fear was a Weakne≈øs he was intirely a Stranger to; the Lo≈øs of the Ship, was the Lo≈øs of him; he knew how to govern while he was a Commander on Board, but when Things were brought to Confu≈øion and Di≈øorder, he thought to e≈øtabli≈øh his Command a≈øhore by his Courage, and to
≈øuppre≈øs the lea≈øt In≈øult on his Authority on the fir≈øt Occa≈øion; an In≈øtance of this was ≈øeen on the Boat≈øwain's fir≈øt appearing a≈øhore; ≈øhooting Mr. Cozens, and treating him in the Manner he did after his Confinement, was highly re≈øented by the People, who ≈øoon got the Power in their own Hands, the Officers only had the Name, and they were often compell'd, for the Pre≈øervation of their Lives, to comply ≈øometimes with their mo≈øt unrea≈øonable Demands; and it is a Miracle, amid≈øt the Wildne≈øs and Di≈øtraction of the People, that there was no more Blood≈øhed.

At Eleven in the Forenoon, the whole Body of People embark'd, to the Number of eighty-one Souls; fifty-nine on Board the Ve≈ø≈øel, on Board the Cutter twelve, and in the Barge ten: At Noon got under Sail, the Wind at N. W. by W. The Captain, Surgeon, and Mr. Hamilton, being on the Shore-≈øide, we gave them three Cheers; which they return'd. Coming out of Wager's Bay ≈øplit the Fore-≈øail, and very narrowly e≈øcap'd the rocks; with the A≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Barge, and our own Oars, tow'd her clear, and bore away, into a large ≈øandy Bay, on the South≈øide of the Lagoon, which we call'd by the Name of the Speedwell Bay. At Four in the
Afternoon anchor'd in ten Fathom, fine Sand; the Barge and Cutter went a≈øhore, there not being room on Board the Boat to lodge the People.

Wedne≈øday the 14th, fre≈øh Gales at S. W. and W. with rain. At three this Afternoon, being fair Weather, weigh'd, and came to Sail; to take a Cruize up the Lagoon, to try the Ve≈ø≈øel, it being ≈ømooth Water, ≈øhe work'd very well; after three or four Trips return'd, and anchor'd where we came from.

body.p:
THESE are to certify the Right Honourable the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners for Executing the Office of Lord High Admiral of Great-Britain, That we, who≈øe Names are under mention'd, do beg Leave to acquaint your Lord≈øhips, that Captain David Cheap, our late Commander in his Maje≈øty's Ship Wager, having publickly declar'd, that he never will go off this Spot, at his own Reque≈øt de≈øires to be left behind, but Captain Pemberton, of his Maje≈øty's Land Forces, having confined him a Pri≈øoner for the Death of Mr. Henry Cozens Mid≈øhipman, with Lieutenant Hamilton for breaking his Confinement, did in≈øi≈øt on delivering them up on the Beach to the Charge of Lieutennant Beans;
but he, with his Officers, and People, con≈øulting the ill Con≈øequences that might attend carrying two Pri≈øoners off in ≈øo ≈ømall a Ve≈ø≈øel, and for ≈øo long and tedious a Pa≈ø≈øage as we are likely to have, and that they might have Opportunities of acting ≈øuch Things in Secret as may prove de≈øtructive to the whole Body; and al≈øo in Regard to the chief Article of Life, as the greate≈øt Part of the People mu≈øt be oblig'd, at every Place we ≈øtop, to go on Shore in Search of Provi≈øions, and there being now no le≈øs than eighty-one Souls in this ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øel, which we hope to be deliver'd in; we therefore, to prevent any Difficulties to be added to the unfore≈øeen we have to encounter with, think proper to agree, and in order to prevent Murder, to comply with Captain David Cheap's Reque≈øt: The Surgeon al≈øo begs Leave to be left with him.

closer.dateline: Dated on Board the Speedwell Schooner in Cheap's Bay, this 14th Day of October, 1741.

list.item: Captain Pemberton, of his Maje≈øty's Land Forces

div.p:
Thur≈øday the 15th, This Morning, it being Calm, made a Signal for the Boats to come off, by firing five Mu≈økets. At Day-light came to Sail, with the Wind at W. by N. It blowing hard, and a great Swell, the Ve≈ø≈øel would not work; therefore we were oblig'd to put into a ≈ømall Bay, lying S. W. of Harvey's Bay, where we had a very good Shelter, there being a large Ledge of rocks without us, which broke the Sea off. At Eleven we ≈øent the Barge to Cheap's Bay for what Canva≈øs could be found ≈øerviceable, having left a ≈øufficient Quantity behind, to ≈øupply us with Sails, in Ca≈øe we wanted 'em. Went in the Barge the Hon. John Byron, at his own reque≈øt, Alexander Campbell Mid≈øhipman, William Harvey Quarter-Gunner, David Buckley ditto, William Ro≈øe Quarter-Ma≈øter, Richard Noble ditto, Peter Pla≈øtow Captain's Steward, Jo≈øeph Clinch Seaman, and Rowland Cru≈ø≈øet Marine. This Afternoon the Carpenter want a≈øhore in the Cutter, with
≈øeveral of the People, to look for Provender. Shot ≈øeveral Gee≈øe, and other Sea-Fowl; rainy Weather. Wind W. N. W.

Friday the 16th, continual rain, and hard Gales all Night at S. W. This Morning the Carpenter came on Board, and acquainted us that he ≈øaw an Anchor of ≈øeven Feet in the Shank, the Palm of each Arm filed off ju≈øt above the Crown: This Anchor we ≈øuppo≈øe to have belong'd to ≈øome ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øel wreck'd on the Coa≈øt. The Cutter brought off Abundance of Shell-fi≈øh ready dre≈øs'd for the People.

Sunday the 18th, at Noon, the Cutter came off, and brought aboard Plenty of Shell-fi≈øh and Greens. The Honourable Mr. Byron Mr. Campbell and three of the Barge's Crew, came from where the Barge lay. Mr. Byron came aboard, and inform'd us of the Barge's being ≈øafe in the Bay, where we left her, and only waited the Opportunity of Weather to come round with her: At the ≈øame Time he de≈øired to know, if we would give him, and tho≈øe who would ≈øtay with Captain Cheap, their Share of Provi≈øions. This Que≈øtion of Mr. Byron's very much ≈øurpriz'd us; and what ≈øurpriz'd us more was, that he ≈øhould be influenc'd by Mr. Campbell, a Per≈øon whom he always held in Contempt. As for my
Part, believe Mr. Byron left us becau≈øe he could not get any Accomodation aboard the Ve≈ø≈øel that he lik'd, being oblig'd to lie forward with the Men; as were al≈øo the Carpenter and my≈øelf, when below: It is very certain, that we are ≈øo clo≈øely pent up for want of room, that the wor≈øt Jail in England is a Palace to our pre≈øent Situation.
Tue≈øday the 20th, ≈øerv'd out to the People eight Days Flour, to be dre≈øs'd a≈øhore. I went in the Cutter to Command in my Turn for a Week.

Wedne≈øday the 21≈øt, clo≈øe Weather; the Wind from W. to N. W. with rain and Hail. Brought aboard Shell-fi≈øh in abundance. At Noon the Honourable Mr. Byron came with ≈øome of the Crew Over-land; he a≈øk'd me, whether the Boat's Crew were gone off, and if we had ≈øerv'd the Provi≈øion, for he wanted to return to the Barge. I told him all the People were out a Fi≈øhing, and that the fir≈øt who came in ≈øhould carry him off. On which he ≈øaid, I think we will go and get ≈øome Fi≈øh too, having nothing el≈øe to live on. This was the la≈øt Time I ever ≈øaw his Honour. When the People return'd from fi≈øhing, they told me Mr. Byron had lo≈øt his Hat, the Wind blowing it off his Head,
I ≈øaid, rather than he ≈øhould want a Hat, I would give him my own. One of the Seamen forced a Hat on his Head; his Name was John Duck: But Mr. Byron would by no Means wear it; ≈øaying, John! I thank you; if I accept of your Kindne≈øs, you mu≈øt go bare-headed; and, I think, I can bear Hard≈øhips as well as the be≈øt of you, and mu≈øt u≈øe my≈øelf to them. I took eight People, and went over Land to the Place where the Barge lay, to get the Canva≈øs that we ≈øtood ≈øo much in Need of; but found ≈øhe was gone from thence. The People in the Barge told our Men, that they would return to us again; but it is plain they never intended it.

Thur≈øday the 22d, This Day we ≈øaw Sea-Fowl in va≈øt Flocks flying to the Southward, where was a dead Whale. Look'd out all this Day for the Barge, but to no Purpo≈øe. The Barge not returning was a very great Misfortune, having no Boat but the Cutter; and if by an unlucky Accident we lo≈øe her, we mu≈øt be reduced to the greate≈øt Extremities to get Provi≈øion. The Per≈øons in the Barge, except the Captain's Steward, always approv'd of going to the Southward; but it ≈øeems Mr. Campbell the Patroon prevail'd on 'em to return to Captain Cheap.

Friday the 23d, Saw Thou≈øands of Sea-Fowl; in the Morning they fly to the Northward, and in the Evening come back to the South; they are Birds of a very large Size, but of what Kind we do not know. Since we have been here we ≈øaw ≈øeveral Indian Graves; they are dug ju≈øt within the Surface of the Earth, with a Board on each Side, and a Cro≈øs ≈øtuck up at the Head. The Day following a Gun, a four Pounder, was ≈øeen near the Anchor in Clam Bay; we call it by this Name, becau≈øe of the va≈øt Quantities of this Sort of Shell-fi≈øh which are found there.

Monday the 26th, it being very calm, and fair Weather, I went a≈øhore to bring off the People; weigh'd the Long-Boat, and took her in Tow over a Bar, where was ten Feet Water, but a great Swell; as ≈øoon we got over the Bar, there ≈øprung up a Breeze of Wind at N. W. ≈øteer'd away S. half E. for the Southmo≈øt Part of Land, which bore S. by E. di≈øtant fourteen Leagues. The two Points of Land make a large and deep ≈øandy Bay; we ≈øounded, but found no Ground; it is a bold Shore clo≈øe to. I kept a-head in the Cutter, in order to provide a Harbour for the Long-Boat; Providence directed us to a very good one: It blew ≈øo hard, with thick
hazy Weather, that we could not keep the Sea. At Eight at Night we anchor'd in eight Fathom Water a-brea≈øt of a fine ≈øandy Bay, and Land lock'd not above three Boats Length from the Shores: At the Entrance of the Harbour, which lies about a League up the Lagoon, I ≈øet the Land; the Northmo≈øt Point bore by the Compa≈øs N. by E. di≈øtant twelve Leagues, and the Southmo≈øt S. by W. di≈øtant five Leagues, the Entrance lies E.

Tue≈øday the 27th, Fre≈øh Gales at W. and cloudy Weather, with a great Swell without, in≈øomuch that we could not put out to Sea; we therefore ≈øent the People a≈øhore to dre≈øs their Provi≈øions: each Man is allow'd but a Quarter of a Pound of Flour per Day, without any other Sub≈øi≈øtence, but what Providence brings in our Way.

Thur≈øday the 29th, Early this Morning, it being calm and thick Weather, with ≈ømall rain, we rowed out of the Lagoon; at Five it cleared up, with a fre≈øh Breeze at S. S. E. ≈øteer'd S. W. and S. W. by W. ≈øaw a ≈ømall I≈øland bearing S. by W. the Southmo≈øt End S. by E. This I≈øland we call the rock of Dundee, it being much like that I≈øland in the We≈øt-Indies; but not ≈øo large, it lieth about four Leagues di≈øtant from the Southmo≈øt
Point of Land out at Sea. This Day it blow'd ≈øo hard, that we were oblig'd to take the Cutter in Tow.

Friday the 30th, Hard Gales, and a great Sea; ≈øaw ≈øome I≈ølands and ≈øome ≈øunken rocks; at Six ≈øaw the Main in two Points of Land, with a large Opening; on each Side ‚Ä¢ he ≈øunken rocks are innumerable; the Entrance is ≈øo dangerous, that no Mortal would attempt it, unle≈øs his Ca≈øe was de≈øperate, as ours; we having nothing but Death before our Eyes in keeping the Sea, and the ≈øame Pro≈øpect in running in with the Land: We ran in before the Wind to the Opening that appear'd between the two Points, the Northmo≈øt of which bore N. by E. and the Southmo≈øt S. by E. We ≈øteer'd in E. and found the Opening to be a large Lagoon, on the Southmo≈øt Side, running into a very good Harbour; here our ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øel lay ≈øecure in a Cove, which Nature had form'd like a Dock; we had no Occa≈øion to let go an Anchor, but ran along-≈øide the Land, and made fa≈øt our Head and Stern. The People went a≈øhore in Search of Provi≈øion; here we found Plenty of Wood and Water, and fine large Mu≈ø≈øels in great Quantities. Serv'd to each Man half a Piece of Beef.

Saturday the 31≈øt, This Morning ca≈øt loo≈øe, and row'd towards the Mouth of the Lagoons, de≈øigning to put out to Sea; but the Wind blew ≈øo hard, that we were oblig'd to come to an Anchor. This Afternoon, in weighing the Grapenel, in order to go to the Cove, we found it foul among ≈øome rocks; all Hands haul'd, took a turn round the Main-ma≈ø ‚Ä¢ and went aft; which weigh'd the Grapenel, but ≈øtreighten'd one of the Flukes: Here the Land is very high and ≈øteep on each Side; the Carpenter and Cooper were on the highe≈øt of the≈øe Hills, and found deep Ponds of Water on the Top of them; the≈øe Hills are very rocky, and there are great Falls of Water all along the Coa≈øt: The whole Navy of England may lay with Safety in many of tho≈øe Lagoons; but the Coa≈øt is too dangerous for any Ship to fall in with the Land. The People To-day were very much afflicted with the Gripes, and Pains in their Side. Here are Abundance of Trees, not unlike our ‚Ä¢ ew Trees: they are not above ≈øeven or eight Inches in Diameter, and the Bark is like Cedar. The Land is to Appearance very good; but on digging beneath the Surface, we find it almo≈øt an entire Stone. We ≈øaw no People here, tho', it is plain, here have been ≈øome
lately, by their Wigg-wams or Huts. We are ≈øo clo≈øely pent up for want of room, that our Lodging is very uncomfortable; the Stench of the Mens wet Cloaths makes the Air we breathe nau≈øeous to that Degree, that one would think it impo≈ø≈øible for a Man to live below. We came to ≈øail, and ≈øteer'd out of the Lagoon We≈øt; went into a ≈øandy Bay, one League to the Southward of the Lagoon, Indian Huts to be ≈øeen, but no Natives.

Monday, November the 2d, at Five in the Morning, came to ≈øail with the Wind at S. and S. by E. At Noon the Wind came to the W. and W.N.W. in ≈ømall Breezes: This Day I had a very good Ob≈øervation, it being the fir≈øt ≈øince we left Cheap's I≈øland. We found our≈øelves in the Latitude of 50:00 S. After ob≈øerving, bore away, and ran into a fine ≈ømooth Pa≈ø≈øage between the I≈øland and the Main. The≈øe I≈ølands I believe to be the ≈øame that are taken Notice of in Cook's Voyage. From the Entrance to the Northward, to the going out of the Cape of Good Hope (as we call it) the Di≈øtance is about ≈øix Leagues, and the Depth of Water is from two Fathom to twelve; the Northmo≈øt Land before we came into the Pa≈ø≈øage bore N. by W.
and the Southmo≈øt, or Cape of Good Hope bore S. by E. In the Evening anchored in a fine ≈øandy Bay: Here we al≈øo ≈øaw Indian Huts, but no People; To-day we ≈øhot wild Gee≈øe in Abundance, and got of Shell-Fi≈øh, as Limpets and Mu≈ø≈øels.

Tue≈øday the 3d, At Four this Morning weighed, and came to ≈øail with the Wind at W. till we got about the Cape of Good Hope, then at W. N. W. ≈øteering S. and a tumbling Sea from the W. The Cutter ≈øteer'd S. by E. into a deep Bay; ≈øuppo≈øing them not to ≈øee the Southmo≈øt Land, we made the Signal for her, by hoi≈øting an En≈øign at the Topping-Lift; as the Cutter was coming up to us, her ≈øquare Sail ≈øplitted; we offered to take them in Tow, but they would not accept it; we lay with our Sails down ≈øome time before they would ≈øhow any Signal of making Sail; coming before the Wind, and a large Sea, we ordered them to ≈øteer away for the Southmo≈øt Point of Land after us, and to keep as near as po≈ø≈øible: but in≈øtead of ob≈øerving our Directions, they ≈øteered away into the Cod of a deep Bay, ≈øuppo≈øed to be King's Bay: The Cutter being much to Leeward, and the Weather coming on very thick, we were obliged to ≈øteer after her, but ≈øoon
lo≈øt Sight of her. The Place being exceeding dangerous, we could not venture any farther after the Cutter; therefore we hauled by the Wind to the Southward; it continued blowing hard, with thick Weather, with ≈øunken rocks, and Breakers, ≈øo that we were obliged to bear away before the Wind into a large Bay, the Tide running rampant, and in a great Swell, every where ≈øurrounded with ≈øunken rocks, that we thought nothing but a Miracle could ≈øave us; at la≈øt we got ≈øafe into the Bay, and came to in two Fathom Water, we ≈øteered in E. At four this Morning rowed out between the I≈ølands; after we got out, had a fre≈øh Breeze at N. W. ≈øteered out S. S. W. then S. and S. by E. the Cutter a-head. At ≈øeven in the Morning a-brea≈øt of Cape Good-Hope, ≈øaw a large high rock bearing S. ≈øteered S. by E. going within it, and the Main a-brea≈øt of the rocks; ≈øaw a long Point making into I≈ølands bearing S. by E. ≈øteer'd S. until a-brea≈øt of them: The ≈øame Day ≈øaw a very high Land, with a low Point running off, in ≈ømall Hommacoes, bearing from the Northmo≈øt Point S. by E. about eighteen Leagues; between tho≈øe two Points, is a large deep Bay, all within ≈øurrounded with rocks and ≈ømall I≈ølands; ≈øteered S. and S. by W. for the outermo≈øt
Point, the Cutter keeping within, and we con≈øidering the ill Con≈øequence of being embay'd, to prevent which we haul'd the Main≈øail and Fore≈øail down, and kept the Ve≈ø≈øel before the Wind; at Eleven the Cutter came along-≈øide, with her Main≈øail ≈øplit; we called to them to take hold of a Tow-rope, but they refu≈øed, telling us that the Boat would not bear towing, by rea≈øon of the Swell of the Sea, therefore they would have us nearer the Shore, where we ≈øhould have ≈ømooth Water; we an≈øwered them that the Water was ≈ømoother without, and nothing nigh the Sea that runs within; be≈øides, we ≈øhall be embay'd, therefore we de≈øire you to come on board the Ve≈ø≈øel, and we'll take the Boat in Tow: They had no regard to what we ≈øaid, we at the ≈øame Time, for above a Quarter of an Hour, lay in the Trough of the Sea, with a fair Wind: The People in the Cutter would neither make Sail, nor row; at la≈øt, finding them ob≈øtinate, we hoi≈øted a ≈økirt of the Main≈øail, and edged farther off, S. by W. When they found we would not go into that Bay, they hoi≈øted their Main≈øail, and went a-head; being ≈øome Di≈øtance a-head, we made ≈øail, the Cutter ≈øtill keeping a-head till One o'Clock, then ≈øhe bore away
S. by E. and S. S. E. the rea≈øon of which we could not tell, it blowing very hard, with a great Sea, nothing before us but rocks and Breakers, therefore of Con≈øequence the farther in, the Sea mu≈øt be the greater. At half an Hour pa≈øt Two, the Cutter being on the Beam, and four Miles within us, we bore away after them; and in a very heavy Squall of Wind and rain we lo≈øt ≈øight of her: After the Squall was over, it cleared up, but we ≈øaw nothing of the Cutter, nor could we clear the Shore to the Northward, being not above two Miles off the Breakers; therefore we were under a Nece≈ø≈øity of hauling to the ≈øouthward for Self-pre≈øervation, and very narrowly e≈øcaped clearing the rocks: After running about three Lragues, ≈øaw an Opening, where we hoped to find a good Harbour; bore away for the Opening, we were here again ≈øurrounded with rocks and Breakers, with a hard Gale of Wind, and a great Sea, the olde≈øt Seaman on board never ≈øaw a more di≈ømal Pro≈øpect; we ran in before the Wind for about two Leagues, expecting every ri≈øe and Fall of the Sea to be a Wreck, but Providence at length conducted us to an indifferent Place of Shelter: We are now in a mo≈øt wretched Condition, having no Boat to go
a≈øhore in, to ≈øeek for Provender: And the greate≈øt Part of the People on board are ≈øo regardle≈øs of Life, that they really appear quite indifferent whether they ≈øhall live or die; and it is with much Intreaty that any of them can be prevailed on to come upon Deck, to a≈ø≈øi≈øt for their Pre≈øervation.
The People's Names in the Cutter are as follow, viz.

Wedne≈øday the 4th, Hard Gales at W. N. W. and a great Sea without; ≈øerved out Flour and a Piece of Beef to two Men for a Week's Sub≈øi≈øtence; the Weather is ≈øo bad that there is no other Food to be got.

Thur≈øday the 5th, Little Wind at S. W. with heavy rains, at ≈øix this Morning went under Sail, but could make no hand of it, therefore were obliged to put back again: As ≈øoon as we came to an Anchor, the Boat≈øwain employed him≈øelf in making a raft to get A≈øhore with; this raft was made with Oars and Water Barrels, when it was made, and over the Side it would carry three Men; but it was no ≈øooner put off from the Ve≈ø≈øel's Side but it canted, and obliged the People to ≈øwim for their Lives; the Boat≈øwain got hold of the raft, and with ≈øome Difficulty, reached the Shore; when he c ‚Ä¢ me off in the Evening, he informed us he had ≈øeen a Beef Puncheon, which gave us ≈øome ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øon to apprehend ≈øome other Ship of the Squadron had ≈øuffered our Fate.

Friday the 6th, This Morning went under Sail, the Wind at W. N. W. with fre≈øh Gales and heavy rain; the Wind came to the We≈øtward, and a great Sea, ≈øo that we could not turn out over the Bar: In our putting back we ≈øaw the Cutter, a very agreeable Sight, which gave us new Life; in the Evening anchored at the Place ≈øailed from; the Carpenter and others went a≈øhore to get Shellfi≈øh, which we ≈øtood in great Need of; at
Night the proper Boat's Crew would not go A≈øhore with the Boat as u≈øual, but made her fa≈øt a-≈øtern of the Ve≈ø≈øel, with only two Men in her, ≈øhe never being left without four before; at Eleven at Night one of the Men came out of her into the Ve≈ø≈øel, it blowing very hard at N. N. E. in half an Hour ≈øhifted to N. W. and rainy Weather, that we could not ≈øee a Boat's Length: At Two the next Morning the Cutter broke loo≈øe from the Stern of the Ve≈ø≈øel; we called from on Board to James Stewart, the Man that was in her, but he could not hear us; in a ≈øhort Time we lo≈øt ≈øight of her, believing ≈øhe mu≈øt ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ove ≈øtove among the rocks. The Lo≈øs of the Cutter gives the few thinking People aboard a great deal of Unea≈øine≈øs; we have ≈øeventy-two Men in the Ve≈ø≈øel, and not above ≈øix of that Number that give them≈øelves the lea≈øt Concern for the Pre≈øervation of their Lives, but are rather the rever≈øe, being ‚Ä¢ ipe for Mutiny and De≈øtruction; this is a great Affliction to the Lieutenant, my≈øelf, and the Carpenter; we know not what to do to bring them under any Command; they have troubled us to that Degree, that we are weary of our Lives; therefore this Day we have told the People, that, unle≈øs they alter their
Conduct, and ≈øubject them≈øelves to Command, that we will leave them to them≈øelves, and take our Chance in this de≈øolate Part of the Globe, rather than give our≈øelves any farther Concern about ≈øo many thoughtle≈øs Wretches: Divided the People into four Watches, to make more room below. The People have promis'd to be under Government, and ≈øeem much ea≈øier.

Sunday the 8th, This Morning the People reque≈øted Provi≈øions to be ≈øerv'd; it being four Days before the u≈øual Time, we think the reque≈øt very unrea≈øonable. We laid the Inconveniencies before them of breaking in upon our Stores, con≈øidering the ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ dne≈øs of the Wearher, and the Length of our Pa≈ø≈øage; that if we are not exceedingly provident in regard of ≈øerving our Provi≈øions, we mu≈øt all inevitably ≈øtarve. They will not hearken to rea≈øon; therefore we are obliged to comply with their Demands, and ≈øerve out Provi≈øions accordingly. Several of the People have de≈øired to be put on Shore, de≈øiring us to allow them ≈øome few Nece≈ø≈øaries: We wanted to know what could induce them to reque≈øt our putting them a≈øhore in this remote and de≈øolate Part of the World: They an≈øwer'd, they did not fear doing well, and
doubted not but to find the Cutter, which if they did, they would go back to the Northward, otherwi≈øe they would make a Canoe; therefore in≈øi≈øted on going a≈øhore. On their earne≈øt Intreaties, the Body of People agreed to their reque≈øt: We haul'd the Boat clo≈øe in Shore; the People who cho≈øe to ≈øtay behind were eleven in Number; we ≈øupply'd them with proper Nece≈ø≈øaries, and they ≈øign'd a Certificate, to inform the Lords of the Admiralty that they were not compell'd to ≈øtay, but made it their own Choice, and that they did it for the Pre≈øervation of them≈øelves and us.

body.head: A Copy of their Certificate.
body.p:
THESE are to certify the Right Honourable the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners for Executing the Office of Lord High Admiral of Great Britain, &c. That we, who≈øe Names are under mention'd, ≈øince the Misfortune of lo≈øing the Cutter, have con≈øidered the ill Conveniencies and Difficulties to be attended, where ≈øo great a Number of People are to be carried off; therefore we have reque≈øted, and de≈øired the Officers and Company remaining of the ≈øame Ve≈ø≈øel to put us on Shore with ≈øuch Nece≈ø≈øaries of Life as can be conveniently ≈øpared out of the
Ve≈ø≈øel. We, of our own free Will and Choice, do indemnify all Per≈øons from ever being call'd to an Account for putting us on Shore, or leaving us behind, contrary to our Inclinations.

closer.dateline: Witne≈øs our Hands, on Board the Speedwell Schooner, in the Latitude 50: 40 S. this 8th Day of November, 1741.
closer.signed:
Which was ≈øign'd by the following People, viz.
Matthew Langley, Gunner's Mate
John Ru≈ø≈øel, Armourer
George Smith, Cook's Mate
William Callicut, Wa≈øherman
John William≈øon, Marine
John McLeod, Boat≈øwain's Servant
John Hart, Joiner
Jo≈øeph Turner, Captain's Servant
Luke Lyon, Gunner's Servant
Richard Phipps, Boat≈øwain's Mate
Henry Mortimer, Marine
Witne≈øs
John Cummins, Carpenter
John Snow, Ma≈øter's Mate
Vincent Oakley, Surgeon of the Army.

div.p:
Monday the 9th, at Ten at Night, we weigh'd, and row'd out of the Bay; at Daylight
got about four Leagues right out, every Way ≈øurrounded with rocks and Breakers, with a great We≈øtern Swell: We found it a very difficult Matter to get clear of tho≈øe rocks and Breakers, they reach along ≈øhore eighteen Leagues, and without us at Sea eight Leagues, I take it, that from the Land they are fourteen Leagues in the Offing; tho≈øe ≈øunken rocks appear like a low level Land. This Coa≈øt is too dangerous for Shipping, the Wind being three Parts of the Year to the We≈øtward, which blows right on the Shore, with a large We≈øtern ≈øwell, that ≈øeldom or never cea≈øes; it always blows and rains; it is wor≈øe here than in the rainy ≈øea≈øon on the Coa≈øt of Guinea; nor can we as yet di≈øtingui≈øh Summer from Winter, only by the Length of the Days. Steer'd out of the Bay W. by N. then S. by W. then S. At Noon I had a good Ob≈øervation in the the Latitude of 50: 50 South; the Northmo≈øt Part of the Bay bore N. E. by E. ≈øeven Leagues; the Southmo≈øt Point of Land S. S. E. twelve Leagues. This Coa≈øt, as far as we have come, lies N. by E. and S. by W. by the Compa≈øs.

Tue≈øday the 10th, At Four this Morning made all the ≈øail we could, ≈øteering S. E. in order to make the Land; at ≈øix ≈øteer'd in
E. S. E. at ≈øeven made the Land; at Eight ≈øaw a Point of Land bearing S. E. di≈øtant ≈øix Leagues, which, when a-brea≈øt, ≈øeeing no Land to the S. I take the Point for Cape Victory, and the four I≈ølands we ≈øee I believe to be the I≈ølands of Direction, which Sir John Narborough gives an Account of; excepting the Di≈øtance, they exactly an≈øwer his De≈øcription; therefore, by the Latitude in Ye≈øterday's Ob≈øervation, and by the Di≈øtance we have run ≈øince, we are now at the Opening of the Streights of Magellan. At Ten in the Morning, hard Gales at N. W. ≈øteer'd S. E. the Cape bearing E. di≈øtant four Leagues; at Noon bore E. by N. di≈øtant ≈øix Leagues; haul'd the Main≈øail down, and went under a Fore≈øail. I never in my Life, in any Part of the World, have ≈øeen ≈øuch a Sea as runs here; we expected every Wave to ≈øwallow us, and the Boat to founder. This Shore is full of ≈ømall I≈ølands, rocks and Breakers; ≈øo that we can't haul further to the Southward, for fear of endangering the Boat; we are oblig'd to keep her right before the Sea. At Five broach'd to, at which we all believ'd ≈øhe would never ri≈øe again. We were ≈øurrounded with rocks, and ≈øo near that a Man might to≈øs a Bi≈øket on them: We had
nothing but Death before our Eyes, and every Moment expected our Fate. It blew a Hurricane of Wind, with thick rainy Weather, that we could not ≈øee twice the Boat's Length; we pray'd earne≈øtly for its clearing up, for nothing el≈øe could ≈øave us from peri≈øhing; we no ≈øooner a≈øk'd for Light, but it was granted us from above. At the Weather's clearing up, we ≈øaw the Land on the North-Shore, with I≈ølands, Rocks, and Breakers all around us; we were obliged to put in among 'em for Shelter, finding it impo≈ø≈øible to keep the Sea; we were in with the Land among≈øt them, and compell'd to pu≈øh thro', looking Death in the Face, and expecting every Sea to bury us; the bolde≈øt Men among us were di≈ømay'd, nor can we po≈ø≈øibly give an Account in what Manner we have been this Day deliver'd. After ≈øailing amid≈øt I≈ølands, rocks, and Breakers, for above a League, we got ≈øafe into a good Harbour, ≈øurrounded with ≈ømall I≈ølands, which kept the Sea off; here the Water was as ≈ømooth as in a Mill-pond. We call this Harbour the Port of God's Mercy, e≈øteeming our Pre≈øervation this Day to be a Miracle. The mo≈øt abandon'd among us no longer doubt of an
Almighty Being, and have promis'd to reform their Lives.

Wedne≈øday the 11th, The Wind much abated, with rain. This Morning weigh'd and ran farther in. In the Evening we ≈øaw two Indians lying on their Bellies on the Top of a ≈øteep rock, ju≈øt over the Ve≈ø≈øel, peeping with their Heads over the Hill. As ≈øoon as we di≈øcover'd them, we made Motions to them to come down; they then ro≈øe up, and put on their Heads white feather'd Caps; we then hoi≈øted a white Sheet for an En≈øign; at this they made a Noi≈øe, pronouncing Orza, Orza; which we took for a Signal to come a≈øhore. We would not ≈øuffer above two Men to go a≈øhore, and tho≈øe di≈øarm'd, le≈øt we ≈øhould put them in Fear. The Indians had nothing in their Hands but a Club, like to our Cricket-Batts, with which they kill their Seal. As ≈øoon as they ≈øaw the two Men come a≈øhore, they walk'd away; and when they perceiv'd our Men follow'd them, and gain'd Ground of them, they took to their Heels, frequently looking back, crying Orza, Orza, beckoning the People to follow, which they did for a Mile or two along Shore, out of Sight of the Ve≈ø≈øel: Then the Indians fled to the Woods, ≈øtill wanting our
People to follow them; but being di≈øarm'd, they were apprehen≈øive the Indians would Bu≈øh-fight them; ≈øo they thought proper to give over the Pur≈øuit, and to return to the Boat.

Thur≈øday the 12th, Hard Gales at W.N.W. with rain. At Six this Morning we again ≈øaw the two Indians; they made the ≈øame Noi≈øe and Motions to come a≈øhore; at which I went with four of the People; the Indians walk'd and ran as before, looking back, and making Signs to follow, which we did till we got to the Place where the Canoe lay with four Indians in her. The two Indians got into the Canoe, and put her off the Shore before we could get nigh them; as ≈øoon as we got a-brea≈øt of the Canoe, they made Signs as if they wanted Cloathing; we endeavour'd to make them under≈øtand we wanted Fi≈øh, and would truck with them; they had none, but ≈øignified to us they would go and get ≈øome: They had a mangey Dog, which they parted with to one of the People for a Pair of Cloth Trow≈øers; this Dog was ≈øoon kill'd, dre≈øs'd, and devour'd. Here we found Plenty of Mu≈ø≈øels, which gave us great relief, having ≈øcarce any Thing to ≈øub≈øi≈øt on for this Week pa≈øt.

Friday the 13th, Very uncertain Weather, and ≈øqually; the Wind variable from W.N.W. to S.S.W. This Morning all Hands a≈øhore a fi≈øhing. Lieutenant Ewers of the Marines kill'd a large Seal or Sea-Dog; it is exceeding good Food, and we judg'd it to have weigh'd ≈øeventeen Score.

Saturday the 14th, Little Wind at W.N.W. and clo≈øe Weather, with rain. At Five this Morning ca≈øt loo≈øe, and ≈øteer'd South out between the I≈ølands; the Weather clearing up, we ≈øaw the South Shore; it fir≈øt appear'd like a large I≈øland, ≈øtretching away to the We≈øtward, and at the We≈øt-End two Hommacoes like Sugar-loaves, and to the Southward of them a large Point of rocks; ≈øteer'd S.E. until the Point bore W. then ≈øteer'd S.E. by E. I took the Point for Cape Pillar, and was fully a≈ø≈øur'd of our being in the Streights.

Sunday the 15th, At Three this Morning ca≈øt loo≈øe, and row'd, but could not get out, ≈øo were oblig'd to put back, and make fa≈øt, it blowing hard, with thick Weather all Day: in the Evening it clear'd up. This Day ≈øeveral People drove a Trade with their Allowance, giving Silver Buckles for Flour, valued at twelve Shilling per Pound, and before Night it reach'd to a Guinea, the
People crying aloud for Provi≈øions, which are now ≈øo ≈øcarce, that ≈øeveral on Board are actually ≈øtarving through Want.

Monday the 16th, At Three this Morning ca≈øt loo≈øe, being little Wind, and ≈øteer'd up the Streights S. E. by E. the Wind at N. W. At Eight o'Clock got a-brea≈øt of Cape Monday; at Nine the Cape bore W. di≈øtant four Leagues; at Noon running along Shore, made two Openings, which put the re≈øt of the Officers to a Stand, not knowing which to take for the right Pa≈ø≈øage. found here a Parcel of Bricks, ≈øome of 'em with Letters cut in them; on one of tho≈øe Bricks the≈øe Words were very plain and legible, viz. Capt. Straiton, 16 Cannons, 1687. Tho≈øe we imagine have been laid here from a Wreck. The Carpenter with ≈øix Men went in Search of Water; a Mile up the Water's Side they found Peckett's Well, mention'd in Sir John Narborough's Book; the Spring is ≈øo ≈ømall, that it doth not give above thirty Gallons per Day; but the Well being full, ≈øupplied us. The People grow very turbulent and unea≈øy, requiring Flour to be ≈øerv'd out; which, in our pre≈øent Circum≈øtances, is a mo≈øt unrea≈øonable reque≈øt; we have but one Ca≈øk of Flour on Board, and a great Di≈øtance to run into the Brazil, and no other Provi≈øion in the Boat but the Seal we have kill'd here: Nay, they carry their Demands much higher, in≈øi≈øting that the Marine Officers, and ≈øuch People as cannot be a≈ø≈øi≈øting in working the Boat, ≈øhall have but half the Allowance of the re≈øt; accordingly they have pitch'd upon twenty to be ≈øerv'd half a Pound of Flour each Man, and them≈øelves a Pound. This Di≈øtinction the Half-Pounders complain of, and that twenty are ≈øelected to be ≈øtarv'd. While we were at Port De≈øire, one Day dre≈ø≈øing
our Victuals we ≈øet Fire to the Gra≈øs; in≈øtantly the Flames ≈øpread, and immediately we ≈øaw the whole Country in a Conflagration; and the next Day, from the Wateringplace, we ≈øaw the Smoak at a Di≈øtance; ≈øo that then the Fire was not extingui≈øh'd.

Friday the 25th, Little Wind, and fair Weather, went up to our Slaughter-Hou≈øe in Seal I≈øland, and took on Board our Sea-≈øtore, which we compleated in half an Hour's Time; turn'd down the Harbour with the Tide of Ebb; in the Evening, the Wind at N. E. could make no Hand of it; ≈øo bore away for the Harbour again, and came to an Anchor.

Saturday the 26th, at Three in the Morning ≈øail'd out of Port De≈øire Harbour; ≈øteer'd out E. N. E. At ≈øix Penguin I≈øland bore S. by E. di≈øtant ≈øix Leagues, and Cape Blanco N. W. by N. four Leagues. This Day I took my Departure from Cape Blanco; I judge the Cape to lie in the Longitude of 71.00 W. from the Meridian of London.

Monday the 28th, Moderate Gales, and fair. This Day ≈øerv'd out all the Flour in the Boat, at three Pound and half each Man. We have nothing now to live on but Seal, and what Providence throws in our Way.

Friday, January the 1≈øt, 1741-2. Fre≈øh Gales, and fair Weather, with a great Sea. At Ten la≈øt Night ≈øhifting the Man at Helm, brought her by the Lee, broke the Boom, and lo≈øt a Seaman over-board. The greate≈øt Part of our Seal taken in at Port De≈øire, for want of Salt to cure it there, now ≈øtinks very much; but having nothing el≈øe, we are oblig'd to eat it. We are now mi≈øerable beyond De≈øcription, having nothing to feed on our≈øelves, and at the ≈øame Time almo≈øt eaten up with Vermin.

Wedne≈øday the 6th, Departed this Life Mr. Thomas Harvey, the Pur≈øer; he died a Skeleton for want of Food: This Gentleman probably was the fir≈øt Pur≈øer belonging to his Maje≈øty's Service, that ever peri≈øh'd with Hunger. We ≈øee daily a great Number of Whales.

Sunday the 10th, This Day at Noon, in working the Bearings and Di≈øtance to Cape St. Andrew, do find my≈øelf not above thirteen Leagues di≈øtant from the Land; there fore haul'd in N.W. to make it before Night. We ≈øaw To-day Abundance of Infects, particularly Butterflies and Hor≈øe-≈øtingers. We have nothing to eat but ≈øome ≈øtinking Seal, and not above twenty out of forty-three which
are now alive have even that; and ≈øuch hath been our Condition for this Week pa≈øt; nor are we better off in regard to Water, there not being above eighty Gallons aboard: Never were beheld a Parcel of more mi≈øerable Objects; there are not above fifteen of us healthy (if People may be call'd healthy that are ≈øcarce able to crawl.) I am reckon'd at pre≈øent one of the ≈øtronge≈øt Men in the Boat, yet can hardly ≈øtand on my Legs ten Minutes together, nor even that ≈øhort Space of Time without holding: Every Man of us hath had a new Coat of Skin from Head to Foot: We that are in the be≈øt State of Health, do all we can to encourage the re≈øt. At Four this Afternoon we were almo≈øt tran≈øported with Joy at the Sight of Land (having ≈øeen no Land for fourteen Days before) the Extreams of which bore N. W. about ≈øeven Leagues; we ran in with it, and at Eight anchor'd in eight Fathom; fine Sand about a League from the Shore; the Northmo≈øt Point bore about N. E. the Southmo≈øt Point about S. W. by S. This Day peri≈øh'd for want of Food Serjeant Ringall.

Monday the 11th, At Four this Morning weigh'd, and came to ≈øail, ≈øteering along ‚Ä¢ hore N. E. by E. This is a plea≈øant and delightful
Country to ≈øail by; we kept within a Mile of the Shore; we ≈øaw Hor≈øes and large Dogs in great Numbers, the Shore being perfectly cover'd with them. At Noon I had a good Ob≈øervation in the Latitude of 38:40 S. At the ≈øame Time ≈øaw a-head Land which I take for Cape St. Andrew's; it is a long ≈øandy Point, very low, where a Shoal runs off S. E. about three Leagues. Sounded, and had but two Fathom and half at High-water. When we got clear of this, we ≈øteer'd N. E. into a ≈øandy Bay, and anchor'd there in three Fathom and half, fine Sand; the North Point bore N. N. W. the South Point S. E. by E. Here is a great Swell, and ≈øhoal-water. This Bay we call Shoalwater Bay.

Tue≈øday the 12th, Lying in Shoalwater Bay, the Wind at S. E. and fair Weather. Having nothing on Board the Ve≈ø≈øel to eat, and but one Ca≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ of Water to drink, we put her in as nigh as we could venture; ≈øo that any Per≈øon, who had the lea≈øt ≈økill in ≈øwimming, might get a≈øhore: Here runs a pretty large Surf, which may endanger our Ve≈ø≈øel; this puts us to a Stand: To go from hence without Meat or Drink is certain Death. A few of the healthie≈øt were re≈øolv'd to ≈øwim on
Shore, to get Water and Provi≈øions; the Officers, viz. the Boat≈øwain, Carpenter and Lieutenant Ewers, to animate the re≈øt, fir≈øt leap'd into the Water; eleven of the People follow'd them; in this Attempt one of the Marines was unfortunately drown'd: We to≈øs'd over-board four Quarter-Ca≈øks to fill with Water: la≈øhing to the Ca≈øks two Fire-locks on each Side, with Ammunition for ≈øhooting. When the Officers and People got on Shore, they ≈øaw Thou≈øands of Hor≈øes and Dogs; the Dogs are of a mongrel Breed and very large. They al≈øo ≈øaw Abundance of Parrots and Seals on the rocks, but not a Bu≈øh growing on the Place; they made a Fire with Hor≈øe-dung, and ≈øhot a great many Seal, which they cut up in Quarters to bring aboard. One of the Water-Ca≈øks being leaky, they cut it up and converted it into Fuel to dre≈øs the Seal. They caught four Armadilloes, they are much larger than our Hedge-Hogs, and very like them; their Bodies are ca≈øed all over with Shells, ≈øhutting under one another like Shells of Armour. In this Country thirteen of his Maje≈øty's Briti≈øh Subjects put to Flight a thou≈øand Spani≈øh Hor≈øe. Hor≈øes are more Numerous here than Sheep are on the Plains in Dor≈øet and Wil ‚Ä¢ ≈øhire. We on
Board ≈øee Abundance of Seal lying on the Shore cut up in Pieces; but the Wind blows ≈øo hard we can by no Means get at it. We think our≈øelves now wor≈øe off than ever, for we are actually ≈øtarving in the Sight of Plenty. We have but two People on board that can ≈øwim; to give them all the A≈ø≈øi≈øtance we can the Lieutenant and my≈øelf with the re≈øt of the People, propo≈øed to haul the Ve≈ø≈øel nearer in, and make a raft for one of the two to ≈øwim a≈øhore on, and to carry a Line to haul ≈øome of the Seal a-board: With much Entreaty the≈øe two Swimmers were prevail'd on to ca≈øt Lots; the Lot falling on the weake≈øt of 'em, who was a young Lad about fifteen Years of Age, and ≈øearce able to ≈øtand, we would not ≈øuffer him to go. While our Brethren were regaling in the fulne≈øs of Plenty a≈øhore, we aboard were oblig'd to ≈øtrip the Hatches of a Seal-≈økin, which has been for ≈øome Time nail'd on, and made u≈øe of for a Tarpawlin; we burnt the Hair off the Skin, and for want of any Thing el≈øe fell to chewing the Seal-≈økin.

Wedne≈øday the 13th, Fine Weather, and calm. At Six this Morning the Boat≈øwain ≈øhot a Hor≈øe, and the People a wild Dog. The Hor≈øe was branded on the Le≈øt Buttock with the≈øe Letters AR ‚Ä¢ By this we conjecture
there are Inhabitants not far off. At Nine veer'd the Boat in, la≈øh'd the Oar's to the Hatches, and made a Stage to haul up the Seal. The People ≈øwam off three Ca≈øks of Water; ≈øent on Shore one Quarter-Ca≈øk more, and two Breakers. Came aboard the Boat≈øwain, Carpenter, and Lieutenant Ewers; and four Men more are getting the Seal and the Hor≈øe on Board; which was no ≈øooner in the Ve≈ø≈øel, than a Sea-Breeze came in, and blow'd ≈øo hard, that we were oblig'd to weigh; leaving a≈øhore one Quarter-Ca≈øk, two Breakers, and Eight of the People. The Wind at E. S. E. and a tumbling Sea, came to an Anchor about a League off the Shore; we ≈øhar'd the Provi≈øions among the Company; we ≈øtill ≈øee the People a≈øhore, but can't get them off.

Thur≈øday the 14th, Hard Gales at E. S. E. and fair Weather. La≈øt Night the Sea was ≈øo great, that it broke the rudder Head off; we were doubtful every Moment of the Ve≈ø≈øel's parting, which if ≈øhe had, we mu≈øt have been all of us inevitably lo≈øt. We were oblig'd to put to Sea, not being able to get the People off. We ≈øent a≈øhore in a ≈øcuttled Puncheon ≈øome wearing Apparel, four Mu≈økets, with Balls, Powder, Flints, Candles, and ≈øeveral Nece≈ø≈øaries; and al≈øo a Letter to acquaint
them of the Danger we were in, and of the Impo≈ø≈øibility of our riding it out till they could get off.

opener.dateline: In Fre≈øh-water Bay, dated on Board the Speedwell Schooner, on the Coa≈øt of South America, in the Latitude of 37: 25 S. Longitude from the Meridian of London, 65: 00 W. this 14th Day of January, 1741-2.

body.p:
THESE are to certify the Right Honourable the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners for Executing the Office of Lord High Admiral of Great-Britain, &c. That we, who≈øe Names are under-mention'd, having nothing left on Board the Ve≈ø≈øel but one Quarter-Ca≈øk of Water, were oblig'd to put into the fir≈øt Place we could for Sub≈øi≈øtence, which was in Fre≈øhwater Bay; where we came to an Anchor, as near the Shore as we could, without endangering the Ve≈ø≈øel, having no Boat aboard, and a large Surf on the Shore; therefore Mr. King the Boat≈øwain, Mr. Cummins the Carpenter, and Lieutenant Ewers, with eleven of the People, jump'd over-board, in order to ≈øwin ‚Ä¢ a≈øhore, with three Ca≈øks for Water; in which Attempt James Greenham was drown'd in the Surf, off the Shore: The Sea-Breeze coming
on, prevented the People getting on Board the ≈øame Night; therefore, on Wedne≈øday Morning, it being then calm, they brought to the Beach the Ca≈øks fill'd with Water, with Seal and other Provi≈øions in great Quantities, which we haul'd on Board. The Boat≈øwain, Carpenter, Lieut. Ewers, and three of the People ≈øwam off; but the Sea-breeze coming in, and the Surf ri≈øing, the re≈øt were di≈øcourag'd from coming off; we haul'd a good Birth off the Shore, where we lay the Remainder of the Day, and all the Night. The Greatne≈øs of the Sea broke off our Rudder-Head, and we expected every Minute the Ve≈ø≈øel would founder at her Anchor. Thur≈øday Morning we ≈øaw no Probability of the People coming aboard, and the Wind coming out of the Sea, and not one Stick of Fire-wood in the Ve≈ø≈øel to dre≈øs our Victuals, and it being every Man's Opinion that we mu≈øt put to Sea or peri≈øh, we got up a ≈øcuttled Ca≈øk, and put into it all Manner of Nece≈ø≈øaries, with four ≈ømall Arms la≈øh'd to the Ca≈øk, and a Letter to acquaint them of our Danger; which Ca≈øk we ≈øaw them receive, as al≈øo the Letter that was in it; they then fell on their Knees, and made Signals wi≈øhing us well; at which we got under
Sail, and left our Brethren, who≈øe Names are under-mention'd.

closer.signed:
Sign'd by
Robert Beans, Lieutenant
John King, Boat≈øwain
John Bulkeley, Gunner
Thomas Clark, Ma≈øter
John Cummins, Carpenter
Robert Elliot, Surgeon's Mate
John Jones, Ma≈øter's Mate
John Snow, ditto

div.p: The Names of the People left on Shore in the Lat. of 37: 25 S. Long. 65: 00 W.

Tho≈øe People had a good Pro≈øpect of geting Provi≈øions, and we believe Inhabitants are not far off: they have all Nece≈ø≈øaries for
≈øhooting; we hope to ≈øet them again, but at pre≈øent we leave 'em to the Care of Providence and the wide World. At Noon ≈øail'd hence; at Four in the Afternoon could not clear the Land, and were oblig'd to anchor in five Fathom, two Leagues from the Shore; the Northmo≈øt Point of Land bore N. E. by N. and the Southmo≈øt Point S. by W. Hard Gales at E. N. E. and a great Sea. At Noon Latitude in 38: 00 S.

Friday the 15th, Fre≈øh Gales at N. N. W. and a great Sea tumbling into the Bay. We are not able to ride it out; therefore, at Four in the Afternoon, got under ≈øail, and ≈øtood off to Sea; the Southmo≈øt Land bore S. W. by S. di≈øtant five Leagues.

Monday the 18th, In the Latitude of 36: 29 S. the North Point of Fre≈øh-water Bay bearing S. W. di≈øtant forty-four Leagues, we went to an Allowance of Water, at a Pint a Man per Day, having on Board not above twenty Gallons for thirty-three Souls.

Tue≈øday the 19th, Little Wind at S. and clear Weather. At Four this Morning ≈øaw Breakers right a-head; ≈øounded, and found five Fathom; ≈øaw the Land making like an I≈øland, bearing N. E. by E. di≈øtant twelve Leagues; ≈øteer'd N. for about a Mile or
two; ≈øhoal'd the Water from two Fathom to nine Feet; then ≈øteer'd N. N. E. and deepen'd the Water to five Fathom. By the Appearance of the Land, we are well up the river of Plate, and do take the Breakers for the Engli≈øh Bank. Steer'd and ≈øail'd all Day E. N. E. along Shore; in the Evening anchor'd in a fine ≈øandy Bay; ≈øaw two Men coming down on Hor≈øeback; the Boat≈øwain ≈øwam a≈øhore, and got up behind one of them, and rode away to their Caravans. When we made the Land, we had not one Drop of Water on Board: Several People ≈øwam a≈øhore to fill Water; one of 'em, when a≈øhore, drank very plentifully of Water; in attempting to come off, was ≈øo weak, that he could not reach the Ve≈ø≈øel, but was unfortunately drown'd. Got one Ca≈øk of Water aboard, which reviv'd us exceedingly.

Wedne≈øday the 20th, Mr. Cummins and my≈øelf went a≈øhore; four of the Inhabitants came down to us on Hor≈øeback. As I could talk Portugueze, I fell into Di≈øcour≈øe with them. They told me the Engli≈øh were ≈øtill at War with the Spaniards; that they had two fifty Gun Ships up the river of Plate, and one ≈øixty Gun Ship cruizing off Cape St. Mary's; and not above ≈øix Weeks ago a
≈øeventy Gun Ship lying at Anchor, parted from her Anchors and drove on ≈øhore; that the Ship was lo≈øt, and every Man peri≈øh'd. They al≈øo told me they were Spaniards, Ca≈øtilians, and Fi≈øhermen; that they came here a fi≈øhing; the Fi≈øh they took they ≈øalted and dried, then ≈øold them at Buenos Ayres. The Town they belong'd to they call'd the Mount de Vidia, two Days Journey from hence. I ask'd them how they came to live in the King of Portugal's Land. They ≈øaid there were a great many Spani≈øh Settlements on this ≈øide, and gave us an Invitation to their Caravan. We got up behind them, and rode about a Mile to it; where they entertain'd us with good Jurk-Beef, roa≈øted and boil'd, with good white Bread. We ≈øought to buy ≈øome Provi≈øions of them; but they had none but twenty-≈øix Loaves, about as big „Äà‚óä„Äâ Two-Penny Loaves in England; which they would not part with under four Guinea ‚Ä¢ . We being in a weak Condition, ≈øca ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ able to ≈øtand on our Legs, and without ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ead for a long Time, gave them their Price. Their Patroon told us at the ≈øame Time, if it ≈øhould be known that they had ≈øupplied us, they ≈øhould be all hang'd. He promis'd, if we would give him a Firelock, he would get us ≈øome
wild Fowl, and as many Ducks in an Hour or two as would ≈øerve all the People aboard. Mr. Cummins ≈øent for his Firelock, and gave it him, with ≈øome Powder and Sluggs. On our coming away, finding one of their Company mi≈ø≈øing with a Hor≈øe, we were apprehen≈øive of his being gone to betray us; therefore immediately went on Board, got our Water in, and made all ready for ≈øailing to the Rio Grand.

Thur≈øday the 21≈øt, little Wind at N. W. and fair Weather. At four this Morning got under Sail; ≈øteer'd E. N. E. At Twelve ≈øaw low Land ≈øtretch off to the Ea≈øtward, which bore E. by S. At Four the Tide of Flood flowing ≈øtrong in oblig'd us to come to an Anchor in a large Bay, in eight Fathom Water; the South Point bore S. S. W. the Ea≈øt Point E. S. E. at Eight at Night got under Sail, ≈øteering E. S. E.
Friday the 22d, Little Wind at N. and fair Weather. At Eight this Morning ≈øaw Cape St. Mary's, bearing N. W. di≈øtant ten Leagues; at Noon it bore W. S. W. and the North Land S. E. by E.

Saturday 23d, Little Wind, and calm. In the Morning, not ≈øeeing the Land, ≈øteer'd in N. at Noon ≈øaw Cape St. Mary's, bearing N. W. di≈øtant ten Leagues; Latitude per
Ob≈øervation 34: 53 S. At Seven in the Evening, being in Shore, and calm, anchored in fourteen Fathom Water, ≈øandy Ground; the Cape bearing W. by N. and the Northmo≈øt Land N. by E. This Day departed this Life Mr. Thomas Clark the Ma≈øter; as did al≈øo his Son the Day following.

Sunday the 24th, The Wind at S. and hazy Weather. At Two in the Morning weighed and came to ≈øail; ≈øteering N. E. within a League of the Shore. At Three in the Afternoon ≈øaw three I≈ølands; the Northmo≈øt of which is the mo≈øt remarkable one I ever beheld, appearing like a Church with a lofty Tower; at Four we ≈øaw three I≈ølands more, ≈øteer'd N. Quarter W. between tho≈øe I≈ølands, until we ≈øaw the main Land. The mo≈øt remarkable of the≈øe I≈ølands is about four Miles from the Main: They are all ≈øteep. At Eight anchor'd in fourteen Fathom, fine Sand.

Monday the 25th, A fre≈øh Gale at E. N. E. a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ cloudy Weather. At Nine this Morning got under Sail, in Order to go back to tho≈øe I≈ølands to get ≈øome Seal, there being great Numbers on the rocks, and we in great want of Provi≈øion, with the Wind again≈øt us. We took the Opportunity of the Wind back to the I≈ølands, but were di≈øappointed, being
not able to get a≈øhore for Provi≈øions, came to an Anchor in fourteen Fathom, ≈øandy Ground. Hard Gales at N. N. E. with Thunder, Lightning and rain all Night.

Tue≈øday the 26th, This Morning moderate Gales at N. W. and fair Weather, got under Sail; after clear of the I≈ølands, ≈øteer'd N.E. by N. keeping along Shore; it is a fine level Land, and regular Soundings fifteen Fathom, five Leagues off the Land. We have no Seal, nor any other kind of Food on Board. We have a fair Wind, and not far from our de≈øir'd Port: ≈øo that we are in pretty good Spirits. This Day died the olde≈øt Man belonging to us, Thomas Maclean, Cook, aged 82 Years.

Wedne≈øday the 27th, Moderate Gales at W. ≈øteer'd N. and ≈øail'd all Day within a Cable's length of the Shore in three Fathom Water. We have now nothing but a little Water to ≈øupport Nature. At Noon had an Ob≈øervation, Latitude in 32: 40 South: I reckon my≈øelf 18 Leagues from the Rio Grand, and hope to ≈øee it in the Morning.

Thur≈øday the 28th, Kept ≈øhe Shore clo≈øe a-board, and ≈øounded every half Hour, not caring to go within three Fathom, nor keep without five, ≈øailing along by the Lead all Night. At Six in the Morning ≈øaw the
Opening of the river Grand; kept within the Breakers of the Bar, having at ≈øometimes not above ≈øeven Feet Water at half Flood; ≈øteer'd N.E. by E. until the river's Mouth was fairly open; then ≈øteer'd N. and N. N. W. until a-brea≈øt of the Town; anchor'd on the Ea≈øt-≈øhore in two Fathom Water. There pre≈øently came a Boat from the Shore, with a Serjeant of the Army, and one Soldier. The Lieutenant, my≈øelf, and Mr. Gummins, with Captain Pemberton of the Land Forces, went on Shore with them. The Commandant, the Officers, and People of the Place, receiv'd us in a mo≈øt tender and friendly Manner. They in≈øtantly ≈øent on Board to the People four Quarters of Beef, and two Bags of Farine Bread. We were conducted to the Surgeon's Hou≈øe, the hand≈øome≈øt Habitation in the Place; where we were mo≈øt ho≈øpitably entertain'd. At Four in the Afternoon the Governor came to Town; after a ≈øtrict Enquiry into our Misfortunes, and the rea≈øons of our coming into this Port, being ≈øomewhat doubtful that we might be In≈øpectors of their Coa≈øt, he began to examine me, the Lieutenant having reported me to him as Pilot. He a≈øk'd me if there was a Chart of the Coa≈øt on Board; and, if not, how it was
po≈ø≈øible we ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ld hit the Bar, and venture into ≈øo hazardous a Place as this is? I told him, as for a Chart, we had none of any kind; but I had a good Ob≈øervation the Day before, that our Ve≈ø≈øel drew but a ≈ømall Draught of Water; that we kept the Lead always going, and in the Nece≈ø≈øity we were in, we were oblig'd, at all Events, to venture; and if we had not ≈øeen the Opening of the river before Night, we mu≈øt have been compell'd to run the Ve≈ø≈øel a≈øhore. He examin'd me al≈øo concerning the Places we ≈øtopt at, from Cape Virgin Mary to this Port, and more particularly relating to the river Plate. He was very nice in his Enquiry of our putting in at Cape St. Mary's, and of the Bearings and Di≈øtance along Shore from thence to this Port. When he throughly ≈øatisfy'd him≈øelf, he embraced us, and ble≈øt him≈øelf to think of our Deliverance, which he term'd a Miracle. He offer'd every Thing the Country could afford to our relief; the Sick were order'd to be taken Care of in the Ho≈øpital. He took the Lieutenant and the Land Officers home with him; and de≈øired the Commandant to ≈øee that the re≈øt of the Officers and People wanted for nothing. Before he went he inform'd us, that his Maje≈øty's Ships
the Severn and Pearl were at Rio Janeiro, in great Di≈øtre≈øs; that they had ≈øent to England for Men, and could not ≈øail from thence until the Arrival of the Flota, which would be in May or June. He al≈øo told us, that we ≈øhould be di≈øpatch'd in the fir≈øt Ve≈ø≈øel which arriv'd in this Port; for he did not think we could with Safety go any farther in our own; and that there could not be found twelve Seamen in the Brazils that would venture over the Bar in her to ≈øail to Rio Janeiro; therefore he order'd our little Speedwell a≈øhore; this Wonder the People are continually flocking to ≈øee: and it is now about nine Months ≈øince we were ca≈øt away in the Wager; in which Time, I believe, no Mortals have experienc'd more Difficulties and Mi≈øeries than we have. This Day may be ju≈øtly ≈øtiled the Day of our Deliverance, and ought to be remember'd accordingly.

Tue≈øday, February the 2d, 1741-2, Great Murmurings among the Soldiers; they detain'd the Brigadier from going back as he intended this Morning, till he promis'd to di≈øpatch the Money, Cloaths, and Provi≈øions, and to ≈øee their Grievances adju≈øted. On
tho≈øe Terms they have agreed he ≈øhall go; and this Evening he return'd for St. Catharine's. We apprehended, till now, that the right Officers were in Place; but we find our≈øelves mi≈øtaken. Some Time before we arrived here, there was an In≈øurrection among the Soldiers: Their De≈øign was again≈øt the Governor; but by his Addre≈øs, and fair Promi≈øes of ≈øeeing them righted, he diverted the Storm from him≈øelf, and got him≈øelf continued in his Station; as were al≈øo the Major and Commi≈ø≈øary. The Soldiers di≈ømi≈øs'd the re≈øt of the Officers, and ≈øupply'd their Places with their own People, tho' they were lately private Men; they appear'd very grand, and were not di≈øtingui≈øh'd in Dre≈øs from the proper Officers. The Di≈øturbance at Rio Grand is of no Service to us, for we feel the Effects of it; our Allowance is now ≈øo ≈ømall that it will hardly ≈øupport Nature; the People have been without Farina, which is their Bread, for ≈øome Days pa≈øt. We apply'd to the Governor, who promis'd to ≈øupply us the next Day; accordingly we went for a Supply, which created fre≈øh Murmurings among the Soldiers; however we got a ≈ømall Quantity of Bread to ≈øupply us for ten Days. The Store-keeper ≈øhow'd me all the Provi≈øions,
which, con≈øidering there were a thou≈øand to draw their Sub≈øi≈øtence from it, was a ≈ømall Stock indeed, and not above ≈øix Weeks at the pre≈øent Allowance. He told me we were ≈øerv'd equally with the Soldiers; and when more Stores came, which they ≈øhortly expected, our Allowance ≈øhould be encreas'd. I think, in rea≈øon, this is as much as we can expect. The Lieutenant not coming nigh us ≈øince our fir≈øt landing, I went with the People up to him at the Governor's, about two Miles from this Port, to endeavour to prevail with him to get us di≈øpatch'd, acquainting him of the Call and Nece≈ø≈øity there was for our A≈ø≈øi≈øtance on Board the two di≈øtre≈øs'd Ships at Rio Janeiro. He ≈øaid he had ≈øpoke to the Governor, and could not get us di≈øpatch'd till another Ve≈ø≈øel came in. I told him, as the Garri≈øon were in want of Provi≈øions, what we were living on here, would carry us off; and if any Misfortune ≈øhould attend the Ve≈ø≈øel expected in with the Provi≈øions, we ≈øhould be put very hard to it for a Sub≈øi≈øtence. He promis'd to acquaint the Governor; on which I took my Leave.

February the 17th, This Evening came into this Garri≈øon three Seamen, giving an Account of their belonging to a Ve≈ø≈øel with
Provi≈øions and Stores for this Place, from Rio Janeiro; that they had been from thence three Months, and had been off the Bar waiting an Opportunity to come in; that not having any fre≈øh Water aboard, they were oblig'd to come to an Anchor ten Leagues to the Southward of this Port; that a Canoe was ≈øent with tho≈øe three Men to fill the Water, but the Wind coming in from the Sea, and blowing hard, oblig'd the Ve≈ø≈øel to put to Sea, and leave them a≈øhore, from whence they travelled here, and believ'd the Ve≈ø≈øel was gone to St. Catharine's. The Governor, not ≈øatisfy'd with their report, took them for Spies, and kept them as ≈øuch. However, in a Day or two afterwards, he di≈øpatch'd a Pilot and two Seamen for the I≈øland St. Catharine, to bring the Ve≈ø≈øel round, in Ca≈øe ≈øhe ≈øhould be there.

I took this Opportunity of ≈øending a Letter by them to the Honourable Capt. Murray, Commander of his Maje≈øty's Ship the Pearl, at Rio Janeiro; de≈øiring them to order it to be di≈øpatch'd by the fir≈øt Ship from St. Catharine's to the Rio Janeiro.

body.p:
I Take it as a Duty incumbent on me to acquaint you, that his Maje≈øty's Ship the
Wager was wreck'd on a de≈øolate I≈øland on the Coa≈øt of Patagonia, in the Latitude of 47: 00 S. and W. Longitude from the Meridian of London 81: 30, on the 14th of May, 1741. After lengthning the Long-boat, and fitting her in the be≈øt Manner we could, launch'd her on the 13th of October, and embark'd and ≈øail'd on the 14th, with Barge and Cutter, to the Number of eighty-one Souls in all. Capt. Cheap‚Äî, at his own reque≈øt, tarried behind, with Lieutenant Hamilton, and Mr, Elliot the Surgeon. After a long and fatiguing Pa≈ø≈øage, coming through the Streights of Magellan, we arrived here the 28th of January, 1741-2; bringing into this Port alive to the Number of thirty, viz.

list.item: Capt. Robert Pemberton, of his Maje≈øty's Land Forces

body.p:
All which are living at pre≈øent, and waiting an Opportunity of a Pa≈ø≈øage in a Portugueze Ve≈ø≈øel, our own not being in a Condition to proceed any farther, having no Sails, and being ≈øo bad in all other re≈øpects, that the Governor will not ≈øuffer us to hazard our Lives in her; but hath promis'd to di≈øpatch us in the very fir≈øt Ve≈ø≈øel that arrives in this Port; where we, with Impatience, are oblig'd to
tarry. We humbly pay our Duty to Capt. Leg, praying the repre≈øentation of this to him.

div.p:
Saturday the 20th, La≈øt Night the three Seamen which came here, as mention'd before, with five more of this Place, attempted to run away with one of the large Boats; but they were pur≈øu'd and taken: Their De≈øign was for the river Plate, the Wind then favouring them. This is evident, that the Governor was right in his Conjecture, and did not ≈øu≈øpect them wrongfully; they are now Pri≈øoners in the Guard-Hou≈øe. The next Morning I went to the Lieutenant, de≈øiring him to apply to the Governor for a Pa≈øs and Hor≈øes for my≈øelf, Mr. Cummins, and John Young, to go by Land to St. Catharine's and St. Franci≈øco; where we need not doubt of a Pa≈ø≈øage to his Maje≈øty's di≈øtre≈øs'd Ships at Rio Janeiro: That it was our Duty to ha≈øten to their A≈ø≈øi≈øtance: That he, the Lieutenant, ought, the very Day after our Arrival into this Port, without any regard
to Expence and Charges, to have di≈øpatch'd „Äà‚óä„Äâ ≈øpecial Me≈ø≈øenger by Land; and then we might have been a≈ø≈øured of a Ve≈ø≈øel before now. The Lieutenant an≈øwer'd, he had a Thought of enquiring at fir≈øt coming about what I had mention'd, and of going him≈øelf, tho' it co≈øt him fifty Pounds; but he was inform'd it was impo≈ø≈øible to go by Land. I a≈øk'd him, if ≈øo, how came the Brigadier from St. Catharine's here? And how do People weekly go from hence thither? As for Fatigue or Trouble, whoever undertook to go, he mu≈øt expect that; but there was no Hard≈øhip to be encounter'd comparable to what we had already undergone. We lay here on Expence to the King, without doing any Service, and run the Hazard of not only lo≈øing the Opportunity of getting on Board our own Ships, but perhaps of mi≈ø≈øing the Flota, and of wintering here; therefore I beg'd he would entreat the Governor to let us have Hor≈øes and Guides; which he promis'd to mention to the Governor at Dinner, and ≈øend me his An≈øwer in the Afternoon without fail. I waited with Impatience for this An≈øwer; but the Lieutenant failing in his Promi≈øe, was the Occa≈øion of my ≈øending him this Letter.

body.p:
I Am ≈øorry you ≈øhould give me the Liberty of telling you, you have not di≈øcharg'd your Promi≈øe, by letting us know the Governor's An≈øwer to what we reque≈øted: Which was, at our Expence and Charge, to go to the A≈ø≈øi≈øtance of his Maje≈øty's Ships at Rio Janeiro; ≈øince which Time I am to inform you that we are in want of Provi≈øion, having none of any kind allow'd us Ye≈øterday, and but one ≈ømall Fi≈øh per Man for two Days before. The Meaning of which I believe is owing to you, by the endeavouring, through the Per≈øua≈øions of the Per≈øons you confide in, to blacken us, and in ≈øo vile a Manner, that you ≈øeem unacquainted with the ill Con≈øequence, which may attend the touching a Man's Character. We know, and are fully convinced, from what has been done already, that nothing will be allow'd or granted us but by your Means: Mr. Cummins and my≈øelf a≈øk no Favour from you, but to u≈øe your Endeavours to get us Di≈øpatches to the Ships at Rio Janeiro, where every Man mu≈øt give Account of his Actions, and Ju≈øtice take Place. If I am not mi≈øtaken, you told me that what we were ≈øupply'd with here, was a Bounty flowing from the
generous Spirit of the Governor, and the Gentlemen of the Place. If this be the Ca≈øe, we ought to be very thankful indeed. I am ≈øurprized, Sir, you don't ≈øee the Grievances of the Inhabitants here, and hear the Soldiers Murmurings for want of their Arrears. If they ≈øhould revolt at this Juncture, we ≈øhall ≈øtand a very bad Chance. I mu≈øt acquaint you, Sir, the Ve≈ø≈øel we came in, is not ≈øo much out of repair, but that, if you can get Canvas out of the Store for Sails, we can make 'em, and get ready for ≈øailing in ten Days Time. And if the Ve≈ø≈øel expected here with Supplies comes in a ≈øhorter Time, our Ve≈ø≈øel will be ready fix'd for the U≈øe of the Governor; and if one Ve≈ø≈øel ≈øhould not be large enough to carry us all off, we can go in Company. I imagine you know of the Stores being robb'd, and the Di≈øturbance among the Soldiers, which mu≈øt occa≈øion Unea≈øine≈øs enough, without repeating Grievances, where relief is not to be had. I beg, Sir, you'll get us di≈øpatch'd with all Expedition to his Maje≈øty's Service, that we may not lo≈øe the Opportunity of joining the two Ships and the Flota.

div.p: The next Morning the Lieutenaut came down on Hor≈øe-back, being the fir≈øt Time of his appearing among us ≈øince we have been here, which is above three Weeks; we went with him to the Commandant, who promi≈øed we ≈øhould not want fre≈øh Beef and Fi≈øh; but as for Bread, there is none to be got. William Oram, one of the Carpenter's Crew, died this Day in the Ho≈øpital.

March the 6th, For ≈øeveral Days the People very unea≈øy at the Ve≈ø≈øel's not arriving, the W ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ d ‚Ä¢ having been fair for above three Weeks pa≈øt, and little or no Provi≈øions in Store, which makes them doubtful of any to be di≈øpatch'd to their relief. This Day we are re≈øolv'd to go by Land, if the Governor will only allow us a Guide; we acquainted ‚Ä¢ he Lieutenant with our re≈øolution; he went with me and Mr. Jones to the Governor; we obtain'd Leave to go, with the Promi≈øe of a Guide. Captain Pemberton, being at the Governor's, de≈øired to go with us; the Governor told him the Journey was ≈øo difficult and tedious, it would be impo≈ø≈øible for him to encounter with it. The Captain an≈øwer'd, that he had a Company on Board his Maje≈øty's Ship the Severn, where his Duty call'd him, and was determin'd, with the Governor's
nor's Leave, to ≈øhare his Fate with us by Land; which was granted. The Governor told us, notwith≈øtanding the pre≈øent Scarcity of Provi≈øions in the Place, that he had ≈øo great a regard for an Engli≈øhman, that whil≈øt he had any thing for him≈øelf, we ≈øhould not want; for which we thank'd him heartily. This Governor is certainly a Gentleman of a noble generous Spirit of exceeding Humanity and Goodne≈øs, and I believe him to have a ≈øincere regard for an Engli≈øhman.

March the 9th, This Morning Mr. Jones went over with me to the North Side, to make an Agreement for ≈øix People to go to St. Catharine's; while we were here, the Governor received Letters from St. Catharine's, which gave an Account of four Ve≈ø≈øels on their Pa≈ø≈øage for this Port; on the News of this we put by our Journey: It was very lucky we had not ≈øet out on this Journey before we heard the News: For on the nineteenth the Ve≈ø≈øels from Rio Janeiro arrived, and brought an Account that the Severn and Pearl were ≈øail'd from thence for the I≈øland of Barbadoes. Tho≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels not only brought the Soldiers Provi≈øions, but al≈øo „Äà‚óä„Äâ Pardon.

On the 20th, The Brigadier arriv'd, and had all the Soldiers drawn up, where their Pardon was read to them: He acquainted them with what Money was come, which was not above a third Part of their Arrears, but the remainder was on the Pa≈ø≈øage. The Money he had for them ≈øhould be paid directly as far as it would go, if they would take it; but they cry'd out with one Voice, The Whole or none; and a great Di≈øturbance there was, ≈øome were for revolting to the King of Spain, ≈øome began to change their Notes, and were for taking Part of the Money, and the re≈øt in≈øi≈øted upon the Whole. To quell this Di≈øturbance, the Commandant, whom they look'd upon more than the Brigadier, or the Governor, u≈øed his utmo≈øt Endeavours. They told the Commandant they were no longer Soldiers than while they were in the King's Pay, and let tho≈øe who are for the King, draw off one Way by them≈øelves; you are our Commander, we tru≈øt in you to an≈øwer for us, what you do we will ≈øtand by with our Lives: On which the Commandant deliver'd his Command up, ≈øhouldering his Firelock, and took the Place of a common Soldier, telling
them, ≈øince the King was ≈øo good as to pardon them, he thought it his Duty to accept it; the Brigadier was ≈øo well plea≈øed with the Behaviour of the Commandant, that he ran to him, took him in his Arms, and embraced him; the re≈øt of the Soldiers follow'd the Example of their late Commandant, delivering their re≈øpective Commands up to their proper Officers. This Day put an End to the Di≈øturbance and Confu≈øion which had been ≈øome Time among them, and re≈øtor'd them to Tranquility, good Di≈øcipline, and Order.

March the 22d, This Morning went to the Lieutenant for Leave to go in the fir≈øt Ve≈ø≈øel, which was expected to ≈øail in four Days time; he told me he expected to go in her him≈øelf, and that we could not go off all in one Ve≈ø≈øel; there might be room for the Officers, but the People mu≈øt wait another Opportunity. I told him that it was a Duty incumbent on the Officers that were in Pay, particularly, to take Care of the People; you, Sir, have been ≈øure of half Pay ever ≈øince the Ship was lo≈øt; we are not, but I will tarry my≈øelf behind with the People, and be an≈øwerable for them, if you'll give me a Not ‚Ä¢ under your Hand to ≈øecure me the Value of my
Pay, from the Lo≈øs of the Ship; otherwi≈øe I don't know any Bu≈øine≈øs I have but to endeavour to get to England as ≈øoon as I can, and will put it out of your Power to prevent my going off in the fir≈øt Ve≈ø≈øel. I left the Lieutenant, and went with Mr. Cummins, Mr. Jones, Mr. Snow, Mr. King, and Dr. Oakley to the Governor, to obtain leave for our going; the Lieutenant follow'd us, and ≈øaid, but one half could go at a time. The Governor told us it was order'd that the Land Officers, my≈øelf and the re≈øt that apply'd to go by Land, ≈øhould be the fir≈øt di≈øpatch'd, and might go on board when we would; but as the Ve≈ø≈øel did not belong to the King, we mu≈øt buy Provi≈øions, and pay for our Pa≈ø≈øage. I ≈øaid, Sir, we have not Money to an≈øwer the Expence: He then a≈øk'd me whether I had not ≈øeveral Times apply'd to him for Leave to go by Land at my own Charges? I an≈øwer'd, we were oblig'd to di≈øpo≈øe of our Watches to rai≈øe that Money, which will barely be ≈øufficient to carry us ≈øix off that intended to go by Land, therefore what mu≈øt become of „Äà‚óä„Äâ
‚Ä¢ e≈øt who have not a ≈øingle Penny? And „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ , Sir, that you are not unacquainted „Äà‚óä„Äâ the King of Great-Britain allows to all
his Subjects, di≈øtre≈øs'd in this Manner, five Vintins per Day to each Man for Sub≈øi≈øtence. On my ≈øaying this, the Governor call'd the Commi≈ø≈øary and Major; he walk'd and talk'd with them a≈øide; then came back again, and told us the Account was ≈øo ≈ømall, that it was not worth charging the King of England with it; therefore we mu≈øt buy our own Provi≈øions, and pay our Pa≈ø≈øage; and as to what we had receiv'd from them, we were welcome; upon which we thank'd them, and came away. We then con≈øulted with the Lieutenant, to know what could be done with the People; and that as the Ve≈ø≈øel we came in was not fit to proceed in any farther, it was to no Purpo≈øe to leave her there; therefore we de≈øired his con≈øent to ≈øell her, believing the Money ≈øhe would bring, would be ≈øufficient to carry us all off. To this Propo≈øal the Lieutenant con≈øented. We then apply'd to the Ma≈øter of the Ve≈ø≈øel, to know what he would have for our Pa≈ø≈øage; his Demand was forty Shillings per Man; of which we acquainted the Lieutenant, who told us he could not ≈øee what we could do, and, on ≈øecond Con≈øideration, would not give his Con≈øent to ≈øell the Boat; for, when ≈øold, he did not think ≈øhe would fetch the Money.
Tho≈øe Words of the Lieutenant put us all to a Stand, e≈øpecially after he had but now given his Con≈øent to ≈øell her; and in ≈øo ≈øhort Time to declare the rever≈øe, was very odd; tho' indeed it did not much ≈øurprize us, becau≈øe this Gentleman was never known to be over ≈øtedfa≈øt to his Word. Seeing no Po≈ø≈øibility of carrying he People off without ≈øelling the Boat, I told the Lieutenant, if he left them behind, I could not think but ≈øo many of his Maje≈øty's Subjects were ≈øold; and believ'd he had made a Pre≈øent of the Ve≈ø≈øel to the Governor. At this the Lieutenant paus'd for a while; and then ≈øaid, he had not Money to carry him≈øelf off without ≈øelling his Coat. I reply'd, there was no Occa≈øion for that, when he had a Gold Watch. The next Morning went to the Lieutenant again about our going off; he acquainted us, that the Brigadier had order'd Things in another Manner; that myfelf, and nine more, being the Per≈øons di≈øirous of going, ≈øhould be di≈øpatch'd in the fir≈øt Ve≈ø≈øel, and every Thing found us; that he, the Lieutenant, was to tarry behind with the re≈øt of the People, and to come in the next Ve≈ø≈øel, an E≈øtimate of the Charges being made out; and al≈øo he told us, he had a ≈øevere Check for
reque≈øting to go fir≈øt him≈øelf, and offering to leave the People behind.

Sunday, March 28, I embark'd on Board the St. Catharine's Brigantine, with the Carpenter, Boat≈øwain, the two Mates, the Surgeon of Marines, the Cooper, and ≈øix of the People; the Provi≈øions laid in for us were two Ca≈øks of Salt Beef, and ten Alcadoes of Farina.

Wedne≈øday the 31≈øt, we ≈øail'd for Rio Janeiro, with the Wind at W. ≈øteer'd S. E. and S. E. by E. until over the Bar; then E. by N. and E. N. E. with a fine Gale and clear Weather; there is not above two Fathom and half Water on the Bar at High-Water; when you are in, it is a fine commodious Harbour for ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øels; it is a low Land of a ≈øandy Soil: Here is Abundance of fine Cattle; with Fre≈øh-water Fi≈øh, Melon ‚Ä¢ exceeding good, Plenty of Water, and the be≈øt Milk I ever ta≈øted.

Thur≈øday, April the 8th, Little Wind at S. W. and fair Weather. At ten this Morning anchor'd before the Town of St. Seba≈øtians. The Portugueze Pilots, who have been in England, call the Land here the I≈øle of Wight; and indeed it is very like it, tho' not ≈øo large, being only eight Miles in Length. This is a
very ≈øecure Harbour for Shipping; a Stranger may go in or out without any Difficulty. At this Place I was a≈øhore, and think it as delightful and plea≈øant a Place as ever I ≈øaw in America; abounding with Fruit, as Oranges, Lemons, Bonano's; al≈øo with Yams, Potatoes, Fi≈øh and Fowl.

Saturday the 10th, Sail'd from St. Seba≈øtians; little Wind at S. W. ≈øteer'd out S. E. between the I≈øland and the Main; and at Eight in the Morning, on the Monday following, we anchor'd before the City of Rio Janeiro.

Tue≈øday the 13th, This Morning we were all order'd before the Governor. A Dutch Surgeon was ≈øent for, who ≈øpoke very good Engli≈øh. After an Enquiry into our Misfortunes, the Governor order'd him to be our Con≈øul; telling us, that we ≈øhould have a convenient Hou≈øe, with Firing, and eight Vintins a Man per Day Sub≈øi≈øtence-Money: He al≈øo de≈øir'd we might make no Di≈øturbance among our≈øelves; which we promis'd to avoid. A Nobleman went with the Con≈øul to look out for our Habitation; they fix'd on a large magnificent Hou≈øe, fit for a Per≈øon of Quality. This being the fir≈øt Day of our coming a≈øhore, they were pleas'd to order a Dinner,
and Supper out of Doors, and ≈øent us where we were to eat all together. This was the fir≈øt Time of the Boat≈øwain's eating with the re≈øt of the Officers ≈øince we left Cheap I≈øland. The Con≈øul was ≈øo kind as to ≈øend us a Table, Benches, Water Pots, and ≈øeveral u≈øeful Things, from his own Hou≈øe; we thought our≈øelves very happily ≈øeated.

Wedne≈øday the 14th, This Morning the Con≈øul went with the Officers and People to the Trea≈øury for our Money. Mr. Oakley, Surgeon of his Maje≈øty's Land Forces, was de≈øired by the Con≈øul to ≈øign for it. The Boat≈øwain, who now look'd upon him≈øelf as our Captain, was not a little di≈øpleas'd at this.
