When the Money was received, the Con≈øul would have given it the Surgeon to pay us; but he excus'd him≈øelf, telling the Con≈øul the Boat≈øwain was a trouble≈øome Man, and it might occa≈øion a Di≈øturbance; on which the Con≈øul was ≈øo good as to come and pay it him≈øelf. Being all together, he told us the Governor had order'd us eight Vintins a Man per Day; but at the ≈øame Time had made a Di≈øtinction between the Officers and Seamen; that the Money received was to be paid in the Manner following, viz. to the Seamen ≈øix Vintins per Man,
and the Officers ten. The rea≈øon of this Di≈øtinction was, that the Seamen could go to work, and get Money by their Labour; when the Officers could not, but mu≈øt be obliged to live entirely on their Allowance. This Di≈øtinction cau≈øed great Unea≈øine≈øs, the Boat≈øwain in≈øi≈øting that the People had a right to an equal Share with us. The Officers, willing to make all Things ea≈øy, de≈øir'd the Con≈øul it might be ≈øo. The Con≈øul reply'd, the Money ≈øhould be di≈øpos'd of according to the Governor's Direction, or not at all. The Boat≈øwain then objected again≈øt the Cooper, becau≈øe he was no Office ‚Ä¢ . The Con≈øul ≈øaid, Ma≈øter! I believe the Cooper to be a very good quiet Man, and I dare ≈øay will take it as the Men do; but ≈øooner than this be an Objection, I will pay the Money out of my own Pocket. The Boat≈øwain then began at me, abu≈øing me in a very ≈øcandalous and abominable Manner; ≈øaying, among other Things; that the Cooper was got among the re≈øt of the Pirates, for ≈øo he term'd me and the re≈øt of the Officers. When the Money was paid, we acquainted the Con≈øul, that we had, till now, been ≈øeparated from the Boat≈øwain; that he was of ≈øo perver≈øe and turbulent a Temper, and ≈øo abu≈øive in Speech,
that we could not bear with him. The Boat≈øwain then cho≈øe to be with the People, and gave us the Preference of the Foreroom, where we de≈øired to be by our≈øelves. There were two Doors to our room; we look'd both of them, and went to take a Walk in the Country: At our return in the Evening, we found the Doors broke open, and a ≈ømall Sword belonging to me was broken an Inch off the Point, and the Scabbard all in Pieces. The Boat≈øwain had in his room an Iri≈øhman, whom he ≈øent in on Purpo≈øe to quarrel with us. This Iri≈øhman and Richard Ea≈øt, one of our own People, fell upon the Cooper and me: Ea≈øt cho≈øe to engage with me; he ≈øtruck me ≈øeveral Times; he compell'd me to ≈øtand in my own Defence, and I ≈øoon ma≈øter'd him. During this Quarrel the Carpenter call'd the Guards; at Sight of whom the Iri≈øhman made his E≈øcape. I de≈øir'd the Guards to ≈øecure Ea≈øt a Pri≈øoner, but the Officer told me he could not, unle≈øs I would go to Pri≈øon with him. I told him it was my de≈øire, and accordingly I went. The Pri≈øon was in the Governor's Hou≈øe. I had not been there but a few Minutes before the Governor ≈øent for me; he enquired of the Officer concerning the Di≈øturbance, and order'd
me to my Habitation; but detain'd Ea≈øt a Pri≈øoner. When I came Home I found the Boat≈øwain, and two renegadoes with him, all about the Cooper. On ≈øeeing me, he repeated his former abu≈øive Words. He made us ≈øo unea≈øy in our Lodging, that, to prevent Murder, we were oblig'd to lie out of the Hou≈øe. Next Morning Mr. Oakley and Mr. Cummins went to the Con≈øul; he came with them to the Hou≈øe, where we were all ≈øent for; he told us it was very ≈øtrange, that People who had undergone ≈øo many Hard≈øhips and Difficulties, could not agree lovingly together. We an≈øwer'd, we never us'd to me≈øs together; and ≈øooner than we would be with the Boat≈øwain, we would make it our Choice to take a Hou≈øe in the Country at our own Expence. The Boat≈øwain, on hearing this, fell again into his u≈øual Strain of Slander and abu≈øive Language, caling us rogues, Villains, and Pirates. It was the Governor's fir≈øt reque≈øt, that we might have no Di≈øturbance among us; yet the Boat≈øwain hath not ≈øuffer'd us to have a quiet Minute ≈øince we have been here. The Con≈øul went with us two Miles out of the City, at a ≈øi≈øhing Village; where we took a Hou≈øe, at our own Expence, to pay at the rate of
ten Shillings per Month, there being ≈øeven of us in all, viz. my≈øelf, the Carpenter, Surgeon, the two Mates, the Cooper, and a Seaman. Here we thought our≈øelves ≈øafe and ≈øecure. The next Day, in the Afternoon, two of the Boat≈øwain's Friends, which had lately de≈øerted from his Maje≈øty's Service, and an Iri≈øh Clerk with them, came to pay us a Vi≈øit. They were ≈øo impertinent, as not only to enquire into the rea≈øons of the Di≈øturbance among our≈øelves, but they al≈øo in≈øtructed us in our Duty, telling us, they came from our Commander the Boat≈øwain, with Orders to ≈øee our Journal. I told them the Journal ≈øhould not be a Secret to any Per≈øon who could read; but at the ≈øame Time I would never part with it to be copied out: They then drank a Gla≈øs of Punch with us and left us. This is a Place that a Man is oblig'd ≈øometimes to ≈øuffer him≈øelf to be u≈øed ill; if he re≈øents all Affronts, he runs a great Hazard of lo≈øing his Life; for here ruffians are to be hired at a ≈ømall Expence; and there is no Place in the World where People will commit Murder at ≈øo cheap a rate. Between Nine and Ten at Night, three People, came to our Door; one of which knock'd, telling us that he was the Per≈øon that was
with me and the Cooper in the Afternoon. Being apprehen≈øive that they came with no good Intent, we refus'd opening the Door; telling them, that it was an improper Sea≈øon of the Night, and that we did not know they had any Bu≈øine≈øs with us; if they had, we told them to come in the Morning: But they ≈øtill in≈øi≈øted upon the Door being open'd; ≈øaying, it would be better to do ≈øo, than to be taken away in three Hours Time. When they had ≈øaid this, they went away. We did not know the Meaning of their Words, but imagin'd they were gone to bring ≈øome A≈ø≈øociates to be≈øet the Hou≈øe; having nothing to defend our≈øelves with, we got over the Back-Wall of the Hou≈øe, and took to the Country for Safety: In the Morning apply'd to the Con≈øul, who remov'd us to a Hou≈øe in the Mid≈øt of the Village; he gave an Account to the Inhabitants of the De≈øign the Boat≈øwain had form'd again≈øt us, either to compel us to deliver up the Journal, or to take our Lives; he therefore de≈øired that the Journal and Papers might be depo≈øited in the Hands of a Neighbour there, till the Time of our going off. The People of the Place offer'd to ≈øtand by us with their Lives, in Oppo≈øition to any
Per≈øons who ≈øhould attempt to do us an Injury.

Sunday the 18th, Early this Morning we were ≈øent for to the Con≈øul. He ≈øaid to us, Gentlemen, as the Lives of three of you are in Danger, and I don't know what Villany your Boat≈øwain may be capable of acting, in regard to your Peace and Safety; I'll endeavour to get you three on Board a Ship bound for Bahia and Li≈øbon; accordingly he went to the Captain of the Ship, who con≈øented that we ≈øhould go with him, on the≈øe Conditions, that the Governor would give us a Pa≈øs, and that we would work for our Pa≈ø≈øage; this we agreed to: After this we reque≈øted the Governor for a Pa≈øs, which he was ≈øo good as to grant, and is as follows.

div.head: Nas Fortela≈øas ≈øedeixem pa≈ø≈øar.
div.p: Podem pa≈ø≈øar par Portugal eni qualquer Nao que ≈øelle ofre≈øer ≈øemque che ponha Impedimento algum Bahia, 19 Mayo, 1742.

p.hi:
DIZEM Joan Bocli, e Joan Cummins, e Joan Menino, Inglezes de Na≈øao, e Cazados em Inglaterra, em quetem ≈øuas Mulleres e Fillios, que ≈øeudo Officais de Calafate, e Conde≈øtavel, & Joneiro, de Imadas Fragatas Inglezas, dado a Co≈øta do Patagonia, che fe≈øivel a portarem, a Oporto do Rio Grande, donde ≈øel ‚Ä¢ edeo faculdade para pa≈ø≈øarem ae≈øta Cidade. E como Naferma do Regimendo de ≈øon ≈øoberano Nao ven≈øem ≈øodo, algum de≈øde otempo, que Nao Pagau detta Fragata, ≈øelhes fas pre≈øis a pa≈ø≈øarem a Inglaterra, para poderem tratar de ≈øua vida em Compania de ≈øuas Familias; para oghe pretendem na Naude Li≈øen≈øia pa≈ø≈øar a Citade da Bahia, para da hi Opoderem farer para Li≈øboa, na primera oca≈øiao, que che for
po ‚Ä¢ ivel, e ‚Ä¢ im de≈øda Nao podem intentar dito tran≈øporte.
Quaime ≈øedigne dar che Li≈øen≈øia que nas Fortale≈øas ≈øelhe nas ponha Impedimento a ≈øua Pa≈ø≈øagem, Come e Co≈øtume aos Nacionaes decte Reyne.

div.p: The foregoing in Engli≈øh thus.

div.head: From all the Forts let them pa≈øs.
div.p: That they may pa≈øs to Portugal in any Ve≈ø≈øel that offers it≈øelf, without any Hindrance whatever, to Bahia, May 19, 1742.

JOHN Bocli, [Bulkeley] John Cummins, and John Young, of the Engli≈øh Nation, and married in England, where they have
Wives and Children, the one being an Officer, the other a Carpenter, and the third Cooper of the Ship, being an Engli≈øh Frigate, arrived on the Coa≈øt of Patagonia; and at their Arrival in the Great river, i. e. Rio Grand, Leave was granted them to come to this City; and as in the Service of his Maje≈øty, they do not advance any Money, from the Time that they paid off the ≈øaid Ship, they are obliged to pa≈øs to England, that they may be enabled there to ≈øeek their Livelihood for their re≈øpective Families: Therefore they de≈øire that they may pa≈øs in the Licen≈øe Ship to the City of Bahia, that they may from thence go to Li≈øbon, by the fir≈øt Opportunity that ≈øhall offer; and that without the ≈øaid Ship they will not be able to perform their intended De≈øign.
Leave is hereby granted them to pa≈øs by the ≈øaid Ship for Bahia; and we command all the Forts to let them pa≈øs, and not hinder their Pa≈ø≈øage, as is the Cu≈øtom of the Nation of this Kingdom.
The following is a Copy of the Sollicitor's Certificate.

p.hi: IS TO he para que todos ≈øabem que os Senhores Abaixo Nomeados y bem mal afortunados, ne≈øta Cidade de Rio Janeiro ≈øe comportar ao com toda aboa Derey≈øao nao dando e≈øcandalo Ape≈øoa Alguma e Sao Dignos deque Joda p ‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øoa po≈øa os favore≈øer emoque for de Ajudo para Sigimento de ≈øua Viagem omais breve po≈ø≈øivel para Huropa.

closer.signed: A ≈øim que A≈ø≈øiney e≈øte Papel Como Procurador So≈øil da Na≈øao Britanica. Pedro Henriques Delaed.

div.p: In Engli≈øh thus.

BE it known to all Per≈øons, that the under-≈øigned are in a deplorable Condition in this City of Rio Janeiro; who have
behaved them≈øelves with Decency and good Decorum, not giving any Scandal to any Per≈øon what≈øoever, and are worthy that all People may have Compa≈ø≈øion, and ≈øuccour them in forwarding their Voyage with all Expedition to Europe.

closer.signed:
I have ≈øign'd this Paper as a Solicitor of the Briti≈øh Nation. Pedro Henri
que Delaed.

div.p: Tue≈øday, May the 20th, This Evening my≈øelf, the Carpenter, and Cooper, went on Board the St. Tubes, one of the Brazil Ships, carrying twenty-eight Guns, Theophilus Orego Ferrara Commander, bound for Bahia and Li≈øbon. The People left on Shore were.

Wedne≈øday the 21≈øt, Early this Morning the Captain came on Board; on ≈øeeing us, he a≈øk'd us, How we came on Board without his Leave? Notwith≈øtanding he gave Leave to the Con≈øul for our Pa≈ø≈øage, we ought to have waited on him a≈øhore. There was on Board the Ship a Spani≈øh Don, a Pa≈ø≈øenger, who told the Captain no Engli≈øhman ≈øhould go in the ≈øame Ship with him; therefore de≈øired we might be turn'd a≈øhore; but the Captain in≈øi≈øted upon doing what he pleas'd aboard his own Ship, and would not comply with his reque≈øt. The Spani≈øh Don, when we came to conver≈øe with him, was very much mov'd with the relation of our Mi≈øfortunes; and ≈øaid to us, though our royal Ma≈øters, the Kings of England and Spain, are at War, it was not our Fault; that we were now on Board a Neutral Ship belonging to a King who was a Friend to both Nations;
that he would not look upon us as Enemies, but do us all the Service he could. He extoll'd the Conduct and Bravery of Admiral Vernon at Porto-Bello; but, above all, applauded him for his Humanity and generous Treatment of his Enemies. He made great Encomiums on the Magnificence of the Briti≈øh Fleet, and the Boldne≈øs and Imtrepidity of the Sailors, ≈øtiling the Engli≈øh the Soldiers of the Sea. He ≈øupplied us in our Pa≈ø≈øage not only with Provi≈øions from his Table, but al≈øo with Wine and Brandy; and during the whole Voyage appear'd ≈øo different from an Enemy, that he took all Opportunities of giving us Proofs of his Genero≈øity and Goodne≈øs.

Friday the 7th of May 1742, This Morning anchor'd before the City of Bahia, went on Shore to the Vice-roy, ≈øhew'd him the Pa≈øs we had from the Governor of Rio Janeiro: He told us the Pa≈øs was to di≈øpatch us to Lisbon, and that the fir≈øt Ship which ≈øail'd from hence would be the Ship we came in; we petition'd him for Provi≈øions, acquainting him of our reception at Rio Grand, and Rio Janeiro, that we had hitherto been ≈øupply'd at the rate of eight Vintins each Man per Day. He refu≈øed ≈øupplying us with any Thing; upon which I told him,
we had better been Pri≈øoners to the King of Spain, who would allow us Bread and Water, than in a Friend's Country to be ≈øtarv'd. The Captain of the Ship we came in, hearing the Vice-roy would not ≈øupply us, was ≈øo kind as to go with us to him, acquainting him how we were provided for at Rio Janeiro, and that he would ≈øupply us him≈øelf, if he would ≈øign an Account to ≈øatisfy the Con≈øul General at Lisbon, ≈øo that he might be reimburs'd. The Vice-roy an≈øwer'd, he had no Orders concerning the Engli≈øh, that he had Letters from the King of Portugal his Ma≈øter to ≈øupply the French, but had no Orders about any other Nation, and if he gave us any thing, it mu≈øt be out of his own Pocket, therefore he would not ≈øupply us; The Captain then told him that we were Officers and Subjects to the King of England, and in Di≈øtre≈øs; that we did not want great Matters, only barely enough to ≈øupport Life, and begg'd that he would allow but four Vintins per Day, being but half the Sum hitherto allow'd us. The Captain's Intreaties avail'd nothing, the Vice-roy continuing as fix'd in his re≈øolution of giving us no relief; I don't believe there
ever was a wor≈øe repre≈øentative of royalty upon the Face of the Earth, than this Vice-roy; His royal Ma≈øter the King of Portugal is very well known to have a grateful Affection for the Briti≈øh Nation (nor can we believe he is ≈øo Frenchify'd as this Vice-roy makes him) his Deputy differs greatly from him, he has given a Proof of his Aver≈øion to the Engli≈øh. We think Per≈øons in the Di≈øtre≈øs we were repre≈øented in to him, could in no Part of the World, nay in an Enemy's Country, be treated with more Barbarity than we were here; We work'd here for our Victuals, and then could get but one Meal per Day, which was Farina and Caravances. At this Place we mu≈øt have ≈øtarv'd, if I had not by me ≈øome Mon ‚Ä¢ and a Silver Watch of my own, which I was oblig'd to turn into Money to ≈øupport us. I had „Äà‚óä„Äâ Money fourteen Guineas, which I exchang'd with the Captain who brought us here for Portugueze Money; He at the ≈øame time told me it would be hard upon me to be ≈øo much out of Pocket, and ≈øaid if I would draw a Bill on the Con≈øul General at Lisbon for the Sum, as if ≈øupply'd from him, upon the Payment of that
Bill, he would return me my fourteen Guineas, accordingly a Bill was drawn up by an Engli≈øh Merchant at Bahia, and ≈øign'd by us, being as follows:

NOS abaixo a≈øignados Joam Bulkeley, Joam Cummins, & Joam Young Va≈ø≈øalos de ≈øua Magg de Brittanica El-Rey Jorge Segundo, declaramos que temos recebido da mam do Snor' Cappam de Mar e Guerra Theodorio Rodrigues de Faria a coanthia de Corenta cloatro Mil e Oito Centos reis em dinheiro decontado comque por varias vezes nos Socorrco para o No≈ø≈øo Su≈øtento des o dia 17 de Mayo proximo pa≈ø≈øado athe odia Prezente, por Cuja caridade rogamos a Deos conceda m ‚Ä¢ ra ≈øaud Born ≈øucce≈øto e por e≈øte pedimos humildeme te ao Snor' Con≈øul Geral da Me≈øma Nacao' que Aprenzentado que e≈øte Seja nao' duvide em Mandar Sattis faze ‚Ä¢ as ≈øobredito ≈ønor' Cappam de Mar e Gucrra a refferida ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ anthia vi≈ø ‚Ä¢ o ≈øer expendida em Obra pia e que o E≈øtado da no≈ø≈øa Mizeria ‚Ä¢ pobreza tre nao' pode pagar e por pa≈ø≈øar na Verdade o Refferido e nao' ≈øabermos E≈øcrever pedimos a Gabriel Prynn homem de Negocio ne≈øta Cidade e Interprete de Ambas as Lingoas
ou Ido≈ømas que e≈øte por Nos ≈øize≈øe e Come Te≈øtemunha A≈øigna≈øe.

closer.signed: Come Te≈øtamunha que fiz a rogo dos Sebreditor, Gabriel Prynn.

div.p: The foregoing in Engli≈øh thus,

WE the under≈øign'd John Bulkeley, John Cummins, and John Young, Subjects of his Maje≈øty King George the Second, King of Great-Britain, do declare to have received from the Honourable Captain of Sea and Land, Theodore Rodriques of Faria, the Sum of forty-four-thou≈øand and eight hundred Rees, None of this Money was ever paid. in ready and lawful Money, by different Times, for our Support and Succour from the 17th of May In≈øtant to this pre≈øent Date: And, for the ≈øaid Charity, we implore the Almighty to grant him Health and Pro≈øperity. And on this Account, we humbly de≈øire the Con≈øul of the ≈øame Nation, that, by the≈øe Pre≈øents, he may not omit giving full Satisfaction to the above mention'd
Captain of Sea and Land, for the ≈øaid Sum, it being employed on a very Charitable Account, being in a deplorable Condition, and not able to repay the Same; And we not knowing in what Manner to write, to acknowledge the above Favours, have de≈øired Mr. Gabriel Pryn, a Merchant in this City and Interpreter of both Languages, that he may act for us; and we leave it to him to do in this Affair as it ≈øhall ≈øeem meet unto him; and as a Witne≈øs to this Matter he hath ≈øign'd his Name.

closer.signed: To the Veracity of the above A≈ø≈øertion I have ≈øign'd my Name. Gabriel Pryn.

div.p:
Since our being here, we have been inform'd of one of his Maje≈øty's Ships with three Store-Ships being arriv'd at Rio Janeiro, ≈øupply'd with Stores and Men for the relief and A≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Severn and Pearl (which were ≈øail'd before in January la≈øt for Barbadoes) and that our People were
gone on board of them, and bound for the We≈øt-Indies.

Here is a very good Bay for Ships to ride in, with the Wind from the E. S. E. to the Northward and We≈øtward back to the S. W. and Wind to the Southward, which blows in, and makes a very great Sea. At the Ea≈øt Side coming in, ≈øtandeth Point de Gloria, where is a very large Fortification, with a Tower in the mid≈øt; from this Point the Land ri≈øes gradually; about a League from hence is the City of Bahia; it is ≈øurrounded with Fortifications and equally capable of defending it again≈øt any Attempts from the Sea or Lands.

Provi≈øions her of all kinds are exce≈ø≈øive dear, e≈øpecially Fi≈øh, this we impute to the great Number of Whales that come into this Bay, even where the Ships lie at Anchor; the Whale Boats go off and kill ≈øometimes ‚Ä¢ even or eight Whales in a Day. The Fle≈øh of which is out up in ≈ømall Pieces, then brought to the Market Place, and ≈øold at the rate of a Vintin per Pound; it looks very much like coar≈øe Beef, but inferior to it in Ta≈øte. The Whales here are not at all equal in Size to the Whales in Greenland, being not larger than the Grampus.
After living here above four Months without any relief from the Governor or the Inhabitants, who behaved to us as if they were under a Combination to ≈øtarve us, we embark'd on board the St. Tubes with our good Friend the Captain who brought us from Rio Janeiro; we ≈øail'd from Bahia the 11th of September for Lisbon, in Company with one of the King of Portugal's Ships of War, and two Ea≈øt-India Ships; but the St. Tubas not being able to ≈øail ≈øo well as the other Ships, lo≈øt ≈øight of them the fir≈øt Night. About 70 Leagues from the We≈øtward of Madeira, we bent a new Fore≈øail; within two or three Days afterwards, we had a very hard Gale of Wind, ≈øcudding under the Fore≈øail, and no Danger happening to the Ship during this Gale. When the Wind had ceas'd, and we had fair Weather, the Captain, after the Evening Ma≈øs, made an Oration to the People, telling them that their Deliverance from Danger in the la≈øt Gale of Wind, and that the Ship though leaky making no more Water than before, was owing to their Prayers to Nue≈øtra Senhora Boa Mortua and her Interce≈ø≈øion. That in Gratitude they ought to make an Acknowledgment to that Saint for ≈øtanding their Friend
in time of Need. That he him≈øelf would ≈øhew the Example by giving the new Fore≈øail, which was bent to the Yard, to the Saint their Deliverer; accordingly one of the Seamen went forward and mark'd out the≈øe Words on the Sail, Deal e≈øta Trinckado pour no≈øtra Senhora Boa mortua (which is as much as to ≈øay) I give this Fore≈øail to our Saint the Deliverer from Death. The Sail and Money collected on this Occa≈øion amounted to upwards of twenty Moidores.

On Saturday the 28th of November, we arrived at Lisbon; and on the next Morning every Per≈øon who came in the Ship, (excepting the Carpenter, my≈øelf; and the Cooper) Officers, Pa≈ø≈øengers, the Spani≈øh Don him≈øelf, and all the People, Men and Boys, walk'd bare-footed, with the Fore-≈øail in Proce≈ø≈øion, to the Church of Nue≈øtra Senhora Boa Mortua; the Weather at that Time being very cold, and the Church a good Mile di≈øtant from the Landing-Place. We Engli≈øhmen, when we came a≈øhore, went immediately on the Change. I was pretty well known to ≈øome Gentlemen of the Engli≈øh Factory. When I inform'd them that we were three of the unfortunate People that were ca≈øt away in the Wager, and that we came here in one of the Brazil Ships, and wanted to embrace the fir≈øt Opportunity of going to England; they told me, that the Lieutenant had been before us; that he was gone home in the Packet Boat,
and left us a very indifferent Character. I an≈øwer'd, I believ'd the Lieutenant could give but a very bad Account of him≈øelf, having kept no Journal, nor made any remarks ≈øince the Lo≈øs of the Ship, nor perhaps before; that we doubted not but to acquit our≈øelves of any fal≈øe Accu≈øations, having with us a Journal, which gave an impartial relation of all our Proceedings. The Journal was read by ≈øeveral Gentlemen of the Factory, who treated us, during our Stay at Lisbon, with exceeding Kindne≈øs and Benevolence.

On the 20th of December, we embark'd on Board his Maje≈øty's Ship the Stirling-Ca≈øtle for England: Here we had again the Happine≈øs of experiencing the Difference between a Briti≈øh and a Foreign Ship, particularly in regard to Cleanline≈øs, Accomodation, Diet and Di≈øcipline. We met with nothing material in our Pa≈ø≈øage, and arrived at Spithead on the 1≈øt of January, 1742-3. Here we thought of nothing but going a≈øhore immediately to our Families; but were told by the Captain, we mu≈øt not ≈øtir out of the Ship till he knew the Plea≈øure of the Lords of the Admiralty, having already wrote to them con ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ rning us. This was a very great Affliction to us; and the more ≈øo becau≈øe
we thought our Troubles at an End. The Carpenter and my≈øelf were in View of our Habitations; our Families had long given us over for lo≈øt; and, on the News of our Safety, our relatives look'd upon us as Sons, Hu≈øbands, and Fathers, re≈øtor'd to them in a miraculous Manner. Our being detain'd on Board gave them great Anxiety; we endeavour'd to con≈øole 'em as well as we could; being a≈ø≈øured, that we had done nothing to offend their Lord≈øhips; that, if Things were not carried on with that Order and regularity which is ≈øtrictly ob≈øerv'd in the Navy, Nece≈ø≈øity drove us out of the common road. Our Ca≈øe was ≈øingular: Since the lo≈øs of the Ship, our chiefe≈øt Concern was for the Pre≈øervation of our Lives and Liberties; to accompli≈øh which we acted according to the Dictates of Nature, and the be≈øt of our Under≈øtanding.
Note, Here ends that Part of the Journal which was printed in London.

body.head: A Copy of a Letter ≈øent to their Lord≈øhips, whil≈øt under Confinement on board his Maje≈øty's Ship the Duke, lying at Spithead, in January, 1743.
body.p: WE Humbly beg leave to acquaint your Lord≈øhips, That as Subjects of England we are return'd to our Country, in order for Tryal: Had we been guilty of any Mi≈ødemeanors or Crimes on the High-Seas, or inferior Parts, as Subjects we ≈øhould be called to Account, try'd, acquitted or condemned. Which is all we want and reque≈øt.
body.closer: From your Lord≈øhips mo≈øt dutiful and Obedient Servant, J. B.

div.p:
Shortly after this came an Order for Liberty, at which I thought it my Duty to wait on their Lord≈øhips with the Journal; after it was ≈øent in, waited upwards of ten Days for an An≈øwer, at our own Expence and Charge; receiving none, we apply'd to the E‚Äîof W‚Äîwho told us the Journal was too ‚Ä¢ rge ever to be peru≈øed, and time would hardly per ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ t the looking of it over; therefore order ‚Ä¢ d it to be return'd again, and farther, order'd us to draw up a Narrative
from it, giving an Account of the Lo≈øs of the Ship, the Murder of the Mid≈øhipman, the Confining the Captain, and the leaving him behind; which was all that was wanted and reque≈øted.
This Narrative was drawn up, and concluded with the≈øe Words.

body.p: WE Have written this Narrative as ≈øhort as we could, in doing of which, we have ≈øtrictly complied with the De≈øire of the Unfortunate Capt. Cheap, who≈øe la≈øt Injunction was to give a faithful Narrative to your Lord≈øhips. We have writ it without Favour or Prejudice, and wherever it is deficient, do refer to the Journal. After the unfortunate Lo≈øs of the Wager, we knew if ever Providence ≈øhould bring us to our Country again, that we ≈øhould be call'd to Account, therefore have omitted nothing material, at lea≈øt, in our Journal.
body.closer: From. Your Lord≈øhips mo≈øt dutiful, und obedient.

div.p: Receiving no An≈øwer to this, I thought it my Duty to write to their Lord≈øhips for Tryal, and to this Purpo≈øe:

p.hi: WE Humbly pray your Lord≈øhips to admit us to Tryal whil≈øt the Witne≈ø≈øes are on the Spot, le≈øt they ≈øhould be ≈øeparated in ≈øeveral Ships and di≈øtant Parts, and we ≈øhould be called to Account in their Ab≈øence, which would be of the wor≈øt Con≈øequence to us.

closer.signed: From your Lord≈øhips mo≈øt dutiful and obedient Servant, John Bulkeley.

div.p: At which their Lord≈øhips were plea≈øed to fix a Day for examining all the Officers late belonging to the Wager. The Gentlemen appointed to make Enquiry into the whole Affair, were three Commanders of Ships, of di≈øtingui≈øh'd Merit and Honour. However it was afterwards concluded not to admit us to any Examination till the Arrival of the Commodore, or el≈øe Capt. Cheap, and to exclude us till that Time from ≈øerving his Maje≈øty, or receiving any Wages.

After this we were offer'd a con≈øiderable Sum by the Book≈øellers of London, to publi≈øh our Journal to the World; this we would not attempt nor pre≈øume to do, without acquainting their Lord≈øhips; for which Purpo≈øe I writ in the Manner following.

body.p: WE Humbly beg Leave to acquaint your Lord≈øhips, that we are offer'd a con≈øiderable Sum by the Book≈øellers of London, for the Copy of our Journal, to publi≈øh it to the World; notwith≈øtanding Money is a great Temptation to People in our Circum≈øtances, ≈øtill we are determined to abide by your Lord≈øhips Re≈øolutions.

closer.signed: From your Lord≈øhips mo≈øt obedient Servant, &c.

div.p:
I received for An≈øwer by one of the Me≈ø≈øengers, That the Journal was our own, and that their Lord≈øhips would have nothing to do with it, ≈øo you may do as you will with it. I thought this An≈øwer was Leave ≈øufficient, on which I went to publi≈øhing the Journal, which ≈øome People in the World have condemned me for; had I not wrote to their Lord≈øhips for Leave, they might have blamed me. After publi≈øhing the Work, we were told by many, that we were to be hang'd for Piracy in coming away with the King's Long-boat without the Capt. and al≈øo for mutinying, and not bringing him home with us. There was one great good Man that gave his Judgment in our Favour, ≈øo far as to ≈øay, She was not the King's Long-boat; giving the≈øe rea≈øons: At the fir≈øt
wrecking of the Wager, they cut their Ma≈øts away, which rendered them incapable of hoi≈øting her out; but ≈øome Time after the Captain gave Orders to his Officers and People to go off to the Wreck and bring the Long-boat on Shore. They obey his Orders, go off to the Wreck, ≈øaw the Gunnel down, launch the Boat, and bring her on Shore; when there, the Captain orders her to be haul'd up at a proper Place for lengthning; his Orders are obey'd; after which he orders the Carpenter to ≈øaw her a≈øunder; the Carpenter goes to work, obeys the Captain's Orders; now, it is to be ob≈øerved, that the Long-boat is in two Parts, and by Capt. Cheap's Orders; by which Orders, he has not only made her u≈øele≈øs to the whole Body of the People on the I≈øland, but as u≈øele≈øs to him≈øelf as the Wreck in the Sea, and by his own Orders: But the Carpenter, with the A≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the People, have gone into the Woods, out their own Timber, ≈øaw' ‚Ä¢ their own Plank, and brought her into a Po≈øition of 23 Tun ‚Ä¢ . I am farther to ob≈øerve, that at that Time, when the King's Ship was lo≈øt, that the Pay cea≈øed, and it might as well have been told them that they had no right to take up any Part of the Wreck of his Maje≈øty's Ship that floated
a long the Shore, in Order to be delivered from this I≈øland, becau≈øe it is the Wreck of the King's, Ship; and, if ≈øo, the Subject has not a right to ≈øave his life by it: In regard to Mutiny, it was de≈øired to be known, whether the Officers and Seamen belonging to his Maje≈øty's Ship Ruby, who ≈øeized their Captain on Board the Ship for the Murther of Sir John Dindly Goodyer, his Brother, and delivered him up to the Mayor of Bri≈øtol, where Mutineers? the≈øe People were in Pay to the Government; and whether the Officers and Seamen of the Wager on that de≈øolate I≈øland, out of Pay of the Government, had not as much rea≈øon to confine Captain Cheap for the Death of Mr. Cozens, and deliver him up to Captain Pemberton of His Maje≈øty's Land-forces? This I leave to the Candid to judge, which were the greate≈øt Mutineers of the two?

About two Years after the Journal was publi≈øhed, I had an Offer made me by ≈øome Gentlemen of the City of London, to go down to Plymouth in Order to bring up to London the old Saphire man of War, a forty Gun Ship, purcha≈ø≈øed by tho≈øe Gentlemen for a privateer: This was the fir≈øt offer made of getting into Bread ≈øince my Arrival in England which I thought it my Duty to accept; the ≈øame Duty bound me
to trouble their Lord≈øhips for Leave, and accordingly writ a Letter to this purpo≈øe.

body.p: I Humbly beg leave to acquaint your Lord≈øhips, that I have an Offer made me by ≈øome Gentlemen of this City, which I think my Duty to accept, and at the ≈øame Time would not accept or attempt to go abroad with out acquainting, your Lord≈øhips, le≈øt your Lord≈øhips ≈øhould imagine I had flown from Ju≈øtice; I am willing and de≈øirous of abiding by the ≈øtricte≈øt Tryal of my Conduct in Regard to Captain Cheap, and hope to live to ≈øee him Face to Face: But in the Mean-time do hope I am not to be left on the Earth to peri≈øh, when I can be of Service to my King, my Country, and Family.

closer.signed: Your Lord≈øhips mo≈øt dutiful, and obedient, &c. J. B.

div.p: On this I received their Lord≈øhips Protection, in the following Words, viz.

opener.signed: BY the Commi≈ø≈øioners for executing the Office of Lord High Admiral of Great Britain and Ireland, &c. and of all His Maje≈øty's Plantations, &c.

body.p:
You are hereby required and directed not to
impre≈øs into His Maje≈øty's Service Forty Men, to bring the Old Saphire Man of War from Plymouth to the River Thames, to fil out for a Privateer,
‚Ä¢ John Bulkeley, Commander, belonging to her, provided their Names, Ages, and De≈øcriptions be in≈øerted on the other Side hereof, and that they do not belong to any of His Maje≈øty's Ships; and in ca≈øe this Protection ≈øhall be found about any other Per≈øon, producing the ≈øame upon his own Account, then the Officer who finds it is hereby ≈øtrictly charged and required to impre≈øs the ≈øaid Per≈øon, and immediately to ≈øend the Protection to us. And we do hereby direct that this Protection, for the ≈øecuring the fore-mentioned Per≈øons, and them only, from the Pre≈øs, ≈øhall continue in force for Six Weeks (to Protect them in their Pa≈ø≈øage in the Ship from Plymouth to London) from the Date hereof, and no longer.

closer.dateline: Given under our Hands, and the Seal of the Office of Admiralty, this eleven ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Day of June, One Thou≈øand Seven Hundred and Forty Five.
closer.signed:
By Command of their Lord≈øhips,
Tho. Corbett.
A. Hamilton,
G. An≈øon,
H. Legge.

body.trailer: To all Commanders and Officers of His Maje≈øty's Ships, Pre≈øsma≈øters, and all others whom it doth or may concern.

div.p:
After receiving the above, I proceeded for Plymouth, there took charge and fix'd the Ship with Jury Ma≈øts, mu≈øter'd forty Men, and ten Guns. In the middle of July ≈øail'd in Company with three Sail bound for London, the Ma≈øters whereof engaged with me not to Part Company, being doubtful of falling in with two French Dogger Privateers, which had done a great Deal of Mi≈øchief in the Channel. The next Morning about Six o'Clock, it being little Wind, the Starts bearing N.N.W. ≈øaw the two Privateers in cha≈øe of three Ships to the S. in about two Hours after they left off their Chace, and haul'd their Wind, in order to ≈øpeak with us; at which the three Sail being within me, haul'd their Wind in order to run their Ve≈ø≈øels on ≈øhore: on this I bore down to the Privateers, run the ten Guns out of the ≈øtarboard Side, and as ≈øoon as within Gun ≈øhot hoi≈øted the King's Colours and fired a Shot, which they did not regard, by not hoi≈øting any Colours; at which I ordered the Men below to get all ready at once to haul all the lower Deck Ports up, by doing which we'll give them to believe we are in a Man of War, and by having Jury Ma≈øts, will think that we lo≈øt them in an Engagement or bad Weather; as ≈øoon as they acquainted me
they were ready, I order'd them to haul up, and fired another Shot, which had the de≈øired Effect, for they in≈øtantly hoi≈øted Swedi≈øh Colours, and tack'd from us; by which Scheme ≈øix Sail of Merchant Ve≈ø≈øels were ≈øaved from being taken; the Privateers had each a Hundred and Seventeen Men on Board. To the Fact of this I refer to the St. James's Evening Po≈øt, it being publi≈øhed there. In about ten Months after this Captain Cheap arrived in England from France: The Account he gave of his Proceedings, and the Perils and Dangers he went thro' after he was left by us, is as follows, viz.

WHEN the Long-boat and Cutter were gone, the Captain, and tho≈øe who were left with him, propo≈øed to pa≈øs to the Northward in the Barge and Yawl; But the Weather was ≈øo bad, and the Difficulty of ≈øub≈øi≈øting ≈øo great, that it was two Months after the Departure of the Long-boat before he was able to put to Sea. But as it has been already ≈øaid, the Place where the Wager was ca≈øt away, was not a Part of the Continent, but an I≈øland at ≈øome ≈øome di≈øtance from the Main, which afforded no other Sorts of Provi≈øion but Shell-fi≈øh, and a few Herbs; and as the greate≈øt Part of what they had
gotten from the Ship was carried off in the Long-boat, the Captain and his People were often in great Nece≈ø≈øity, e≈øpecially as they cho≈øe to pre≈øerve what little Sea-provi≈øions remained, for their Store when they ≈øhould go to the Northward. During their re≈øidence at this I≈øland, which was by the Seamen denominated Wager's I≈øland, they had now and then a ≈øtraggtling Canoe or two of Indians, which came and bartered their Fi≈øh and other Provi≈øions with our People. This was indeed ≈øome little Succour, and at another Sea≈øon might perhaps have been greater; for as there were ≈øeveral Indian Huts on the Shore, it was ≈øuppo≈øed that in ≈øome Years, during the height of Summer, many of the≈øe Savages might re≈øort thither to fi≈øh.

Upon the 14th of December, the Captain and his People embarked in the Barge and the Yawl, in order to proceed to the Northward, taking on board with them all the Provi≈øions they could ama≈øs from the Wreck of the Ship; but they had ≈øcarcely been an Hour at Sea, when the Wind began to blow hard, and the Sea ran ≈øo high, that they were obliged to throw the greate≈øt Part of their Provi≈øions over-board, to avoid immediate
De≈øtruction. This was a terrible Mi≈øfortune, in a Part of the World where Food is ≈øo hard to be got: However, they ≈øtill per≈øi≈øted in their De≈øign, putting on Shore as often as they could to ≈øeek Sub≈øi≈øtance. But about a Fortnight after, another dreadful Accident befel them, for the Yawl ≈øunk at an Anchor, and one of the Men in her was drowned; and as the Barge was incapable of carrying the whole Company, they were now reduced to the hard Nece≈ø≈øity of leaving four Marines behind them on that de≈øolate Shore. But they ≈øtill kept on their Cour≈øe to the Northward, ≈øtruggling with their Di≈øa≈øters, and greatly delayed by the Perver≈øene≈øs of the Winds, and the frequent Interruptions which their Search after Food occa≈øioned; Till at la≈øt, about the End of January, having made three un≈øucce≈øsful Attempts to double a Head-land, which they ≈øuppo≈øed to be what the Spaniards called Cape Tres Montes, it was unanimou≈øly re≈øolved to give over this Expedition, the Difficulties of which appeared in≈øuperable, and to return again to Wager I≈øland, where they got back about the Middle of February, quite di≈øheartned and dejected with their reiterated Di≈øappointments, and almo≈øt peri≈øhing with Hunger and Fatigue.

However, on their return they had the good Luck to meet with ≈øeveral Pieces of Beef, which had been wa≈øhed out of the Ship, and were ≈øwimming in the Sea. This was a mo≈øt ≈øea≈øonable relief to them, after the Hard≈øhips they had endured: And to compleat their good Fortune, there came, in a ≈øhort Time, two Canoes of Indians, among≈øt which was a Native of Chiloe, who ≈øpoke a little Spani≈øh; and the Surgeon, who was with Captain Cheap, under≈øtanding that Language, he made a Bargain with the Indian, that if he would carry the Captain and his People to Chiloe in the Barge, he ≈øhould have her, and all that belonged to her for his Pains. Accordingly, on the 6th of March, the eleven Per≈øons to which the Company was now reduced, embark'd in the Barge on this new Expedition; but after having proceeded for a few Days, the Captain and four of his principal Officers being on Shore, the Six, who together with an Indian remained in the Barge, put off with her to Sea, and did not return.

By this Means there were left on Shore Captain Cheap, Mr. Hamilton, Lieutenant of Marines, the Honourable Mr. Byron, and Mr. Campbel, Mid≈øhipmen, and Mr. Elliot, the Surgeon.
One would have thought their Di≈øtre≈ø≈øes had long before this Time been incapable of Augmentation; but they found, on reflection, that their pre≈øent Situation was much more di≈ømaying than any Thing they had yet gone through, being left on a de≈øolate Coa≈øt, without any Provi≈øion, or the Means of procuring any; for their Arms, Ammunition, and every Conveniency they were Ma≈øters of, except the tattered Habits they had on, were all carried away in the Barge.

But when they had ≈øufficiently revolved in their own Minds the various Circum≈øtances of this unexpected Calamity, and were per≈øwaded that they had no relief to hope for, they perceived a Canoe at a Di≈øtance, which proved to be that of the Indian, who had undertaken to carry them to Chiloe, he and his Family being then on Board it. He made no Difficulty of coming to them; for it ≈øeems he had left Captain Cheap and his People a little before to go a fi≈øhing, and had in the mean Time committed them to the Care of the other Indian, whom the Sailors had carried to Sea in the Barge. But when he found the Barge gone and his Companion mi≈ø≈øing, he was extreamly concerned,
and could with Difficulty be per≈øwaded that the other Indian was not murdered; but, being at la≈øt ≈øatisfied with the Account that was given him, he ≈øtill undertook to carry them to the Spani≈øh Settlements, and (as the Indians are well ≈økilled in fi≈øhing and fowling) to procure them Provi≈øions by the Way.

About the middle of March Captain Cheap and the Four that were left with him, ≈øet out for Chiloe, the Indian having procured a Number of Canoes, and gotten many of his Neighbours together for that Purpo≈øe. Soon after they embarked, Mr Elliot the Surgeon died, ≈øo that there now remained only Four of the whole Company. At la≈øt, after a very complicated Pa≈ø≈øage by Land and Water, Captain Cheap, Mr. Byron, and Mr. Campbel, arrived in the Beginning of June at the I≈øland of Chiloe, where they were received by the Spaniards with great Humanity; but, on Account of ≈øome Quarrel among the Indians, Mr. Hamilton did not get there till two Months after. Thus, above a Twelvemonth after the Lo≈øs of the Wager ended this fatiguing Peregrination, which by a Variety of Misfortunes dimini≈øhed the Company from Twenty to no more than Four, and tho≈øe too brought ≈øo low, that, had their Di≈øtre≈ø≈øes continued
but a few Days longer, in all Probability none of them would have ≈øurvive ‚Ä¢ . For the Captain him≈øelf was with Difficulty recovered; and the re≈øt were ≈øo reduced by the Severity of the Weather, their Labour, and their Want of all kinds of Nece≈ø≈øaries, that it was wonderful how they ≈øupported them≈øelves ≈øo long. After ≈øome Stay at Chiloe, the Captain and the Three who were ≈øent to Valparai≈øo, and thence to St. Jago, the Capital of Chili, where they continued above a Year: But on the Advice of a Cartel being ≈øettled betwixt Great-Britain and Spain, Captain Cheap, Mr. Byron, and Mr. Hamilton, were permitted to return to Europe on board a French Ship. The other Mid≈øhipman, Mr. Campbel, having changed his religion, whil≈øt at St. Jago, cho≈øe to go back to Buenos Ayres with Pizarro and his Officers, with whom he went afterwards to Spain on board the A≈øia; and there having failed in his Endeavours to procure a Commi≈ø≈øion from the Court of Spain, he returned to England, and attempted to get rein≈øtated in the Briti≈øh Navy; and has ≈øince publi≈øhed a Narration of his Adventures, in which he complains of the Inju≈øtice that had been done him, and ≈øtrongly di≈øavows his ever being in
the Spani≈øh Service: But as the Change of his religion, and his offering him≈øelf to the Court of Spain, (though not accepted) are Matters which, he is con≈øcious, are capable of being inconte≈øtably proved; on the≈øe two Heads, he has been entirely ≈øilent."

After Capt. Cheap's Arrival as above related, on reading an Adverti≈øement in the News-Paper, I found there was an Order for all the Officers and People of the Wager that were in England to repair on board Admiral Steward, in order to give their Depo≈øitions in for a Court-Martial, to be held concerning the Lo≈øs of his Maje≈øty's Ship the Wager. I being then in London, ≈øent into their Lord≈øhips to acquaint them that on reading the Adverti≈øement, I was going to Port≈ømouth, in order to comply with their Directions. I was an≈øwer'd by one of the Me≈ø≈øengers, it was very well. The next Day being on the Royal-Exchange, a Gentleman which was one of the Procters of Doctors-Commons, a≈øk'd me what News now our Captain was come home? I told him I was going to Port≈ømouth to the Court-Martial: He then a≈øk'd me if I knew nothing more than the Adverti≈øement for the Court-Martial? I told him no; at which he told me,
that the Monday before the Adverti≈øement was publi≈øhed, there were four Me≈ø≈øengers di≈øpatch'd from the Mar≈øhal of the Admiralty, in order to take up the Lieutenant, Boat≈øwain, My≈øelf and Carpenter. On this I reply'd, if that is Fact, I will go and deliver my ≈øelf up to the Mar≈øhal here in Town; finding me ‚Ä¢ ix'd in my re≈øolution, he de≈øired me to go and dine at the Paul's-Head Tavern in St. Paul's Church-Yard, where the Deputy Mar≈øhal was to dine that Day, accordingly I went, and after Dinner apply'd to him, de≈øiring to know his Opinion in regard to the Officers of the Wager, as their Captain was come home; for that I had a near relation which was an Officer that came in that Long-boat to the Brazil, and it would give me Concern if he ≈øhould ≈øuffer: His An≈øwer was, that he believ'd we ≈øhould be hang'd; to which I replied, for God's Sake for what, for not being drown'd? And is a Murderer at la≈øt come Home to be their Accu≈øer? I have carefully peru≈øed the Journal, and can't conceive that they have been guilty of Piracy, Mutiny, not any Thing el≈øe to de≈øerve it. It looks to me, if ≈øo, that their Adver≈øaries have taken up Arms again≈øt the Power of the Almighty, for delivering them. At which he ≈øaid, Sir, they
have been guilty of ≈øuch Things to Captain Cheap whil≈øt a Pri≈øoner, that I believe the Gunner and Carpenter will be hang'd, if no Body el≈øe. As I was not known to him, on the≈øe Words, I told him, then I was one of the Men that mu≈øt ≈øuffer, for that I was the unfortunate Gunner of the Wager: After he was convinced, he told me, I was then become his Pri≈øoner; he had me to his Hou≈øe, where I was confined until the re≈øt of the Officers were brought up to Town, which, as ≈øoon as they came up, he wrote to their Lord≈øhips to inform them, that he had us all in Cu≈øtody; but that I had delivered my ≈øelf up to him here in Town; de≈øiring their Lord≈øhips farther Directions concerning us. The An≈øwer received was, to ≈øend us to Port≈ømouth and there to deliver us up on Board Admiral Steward, to take a receipt, and to take particular Care that the Gunner and Carpenter did not make their e≈øcape. After on Board of Admiral Steward, we were told we were to be hang'd, nay, not a Letter came from any of our Friends, but there were the≈øe Words mentioned, you are to be hang'd! When the Captain came down to Port≈ømouth, ≈øome of my Friends waited on him, de≈øiring to know what he had to alledge again≈øt us? His An≈øwer was, Gentlemen, I have nothing to ≈øay for nor
again≈øt the Villains, until the Day of Tryal, and then it is not in my Power to be off from hanging them. This Expre≈ø≈øion occa≈øioned the whole Place to believe it would be ≈øo. On the Sunday following we were had up ‚Ä¢ o Prayers, where there was a great Congregation, the Text was taken out of the P≈øalms, Them that go down to the Deep, and occupy their Bu≈øine≈øs in great Waters, ≈øee the Works of the Lord.

In the Latter Part of this Sermon, the≈øe Words were apply'd; Men ≈øhould not feed them≈øelves up in vain Notions or Expectations of a reprieve or Pardon, for how often are Men deceived even at their la≈øt Moments? And Men that have ≈øeen ≈øo many Providences of the Divine Being, it's not to be doubted but they are prepared, &c.

Hearing this Sermon gave us ≈øome rea≈øon to think, that we were to fall by the Violence of Power, contrary to the Laws of our Country. In the Evening of the ≈øame Day we were informed by the Ma≈øter and Gunner of the ≈øaid Ship, that a certain Gentleman had ≈øent Word that we might have the Privilege of Pen, Ink and Paper until the Day of Tryal, which was to be on the Tue≈øday following, and that he had made a re≈øolution, that no Man after Sentence
of Death ≈øhould be indulged with it on any Account.

All this we imagined was done on purpo≈øe to intimidate us, to retract from the Truth which was publi≈øhed to the World: But our great, good and ju≈øt God ≈øupported and ≈øtrengthened our Faith to bear with the≈øe In≈øults from Men. The next Day in the Morning came on Board the Judge Advocate, in order to take our Depo≈øitions for Trayl. When I was ≈øent for, I was a≈øked for a Depo≈øition concerning the Lo≈øs, of His Maje≈øty's Ship the Wager; I made An≈øwer, Sir, I am ≈øurpri≈øed that you ≈øhould offer to a≈øk me for a Depo≈øition whil≈øt a Pri≈øoner. Sir, this is not the fir≈øt, but the ≈øecond Time to your Knowledge, that I have been confined on this very Occa≈øion; I always thought, or at lea≈øt the Laws of my Country tell me, that when a Man is a Pri≈øoner, he mu≈øt be accu≈øed; and I take my Accu≈øer to be Captain Cheap, expecting you was come here on purpo≈øe to have given me his Charge, to prepare my≈øelf for Tryal again≈øt him. The Mar≈øhal's An≈øwer was, Sir, this Court-Martial is only to know how the Ship was lo≈øt, therefore you mu≈øt give me your Depo≈øition in Regard to it. I an≈øwered, Sir, that is made mention of in a very particular Manner in the
Journal that is publi≈øhed, and by the Truth of which Book I ≈øtand or fall. He made An≈øwer, Sir, that does not avail, you mu≈øt give it us from under your own Hand Writing, I reply'd, if I do, Sir, I mu≈øt take it from the Journal; which I did. The next Day came on the Tryal, where Captain Cheap alledged the Lo≈øs of the Ship on Lieutenant Robert Beans by not ≈øetting the Main-top-≈øail, and letting go the Anchor, according to his Orders. However it was proved by ≈øome of the Officers there, the Impo≈ø≈øibility of it. After being examined about the Lo≈øs of the Ship, was order'd by the Court to withdraw; ≈øome time after was order'd into Court again, where was read, We do Honourably acquit Captain David Cheap, with the Re≈øt of his Officers, from the Lo≈øs of His Maje≈øty's Ship the Wager, excepting Lieutenant Robert Beans, who has di≈øobey'd his Captain's Orders, by not ≈øetting the Main-top-≈øail, and letting go the Anchor, as ordered; however, in Regard to his Hard≈øhips and Misfortunes, do al≈øo acquit him with a Reprimand from the Court.

In this Day's Proceedings we beheld the great and glorious Power of the Almighty, in plead-our Cau≈øe, and defending us from falling by the Violence of Men. In about a Week's time after, I went to London, and writ unto their
Lord≈øhips for Wages, receiving no An≈øwer, apply'd to ≈øome of their Lord≈øhips in Per≈øon, one of which was plea≈øed to a≈øk me if I was not one of the Men that publi≈øhed the Book? I made An≈øwer, I was; to this he replyed, How dare you pre≈øume to touch a Gentleman's Character in ≈øo publick a Manner as you have done? Do you think that Captain Cheap has nothing to ≈øay in Vindication of his Character? He will no doubt call you to an Account for it: We have not heard as yet, what he has to Charge you with, therefore no Wages, nor any Thing el≈øe can be done for you, unle≈øs a Hearing from him. I made An≈øwer, My Lord, I was honourably acquitted with him, and the Book that is publi≈øhed has put it out of the Power of Captain Cheap to alledge any Thing again≈øt us. His Lord≈øhip an≈øwer'd, I wi≈øh you may clear your Point in it.
The next Morning I delivered a Letter to his Lord≈øhip, as follows,

body.p:
AS your Lord≈øhip's Goodne≈øs was plea≈øed to tell me Ye≈øterday, that no Wages could be paid, nor any Thing el≈øe done for me, until a Hearing from Captain Cheap; therefore do mo≈øt humbly pray and be≈øeech your Lord≈øhip; to intercede
with their Lord≈øhips, if there is to be a ≈øecond Tryal, that I may not be kept in Su≈øpence, being prepared for every Thing that Captain Cheap has to alledge again≈øt me; praying Leave to ≈øub≈øcribe my≈øelf,

closer.signed: Your Lord≈øhips mo≈øt dutiful and Obedient humble Servant, J. B.

div.p: On this Letter their Lord≈øhips were plea≈øed to order the Wages to be paid to the Time the Ship was lo≈øt.

I take this Opportunity, to recommend to the candid reader, the peru≈øal of that excellent Book, entitled, The Chri≈øtian Patern, or, The Imitation of Je≈øus Chri≈øt, by Thomas a Kempis; which Book I brought with me through the various Scenes, Changes, and Chances of the Voyage, and Providence made it, the Means of comforting me. One Thing more, I pray to recommend to the Natives of N. America, who are troubled with ≈øo many terrible Gu≈øts of Wind, Thunder and Lightning, being convinced (notwith≈øtanding I have heard ≈øeveral ≈øay to the contrary) that they mu≈øt have a panick Fear, which, whether they have or not, let me de≈øire that they would make u≈øe of this ≈øhort Prayer.

O God! mo≈øt Mighty, O Lord! mo≈øt Holy, and mo≈øt merciful Father, Thou mo≈øt worthy Judge eternal, ≈øuffer us not, at our la≈øt Moments, for any Pains of Death, to depart from Thee. The≈øe Words, ≈øincerely u≈øed, will bring a Man's Thoughts home to his Maker.

Shortly after receiving the Wages for the Wager, I was made Ma≈øter of the Royal George Cutter, employed in his Maje≈øty's Service. I think it my Duty to make publick the following Order, in order to convince ≈øome People in the World, that I was not thought altogether unworthy to ≈øerve, giving full Satisfaction to the Gentlemen my Employers. This Cutter was about ≈øeventy Tuns, had 60 Men, 10 Carriage Guns, 1 ‚Ä¢ Swivels, and rowed with 18 Oars.

body.p:
I HAVE received and read to My Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners of the Admiralty your Letter of Ye≈øterday's Date, repre≈øenting that the Royal-George Cutter has been ready for the Sea ≈øome Time, and am commanded by their Lord≈øhips to ≈øignify their Direction to you to proceed with her to Plymouth, and on your Arrival
there, to apply to Commi≈ø≈øioner Vanbrugh for further Orders.
body.closer: I am your Servant, C. O≈øborn, d.

div.p: Notwith≈øtanding my thus being appointed to the Command of the ≈øaid Cutter, yet, I afterwards, upon maturely con≈øidering it, declined the Service; ≈øhe being too ≈ømall to bear the Sea; which was verify'd in her Crui≈øe, for ≈øhe founder'd in the Bay of Bi≈øcay, and every Man in her was drowned.

About this Time arrived in England Samuel Cooper, John Andrews, and I≈øaac Morris, three of the Men left on the Coa≈øt of Patagonia, as mentioned Page 160 the Narrative they gave of their Sufferings, is as follows:
div.q: A NARRATIVE of the Di≈øtre≈ø≈øes, &c. of Eight of the Crew of the Long Boat, who were left on Shore by the Lieutenant of the Wager on an uninhabited Part of Patagonia, mentioned in this Book, Page 160, and taken from the Account of I≈øaac Morris (one of the Men) who arrived in England, July, 1746.
div.p:
ON the 14th of January, 1741-2, the Wind blew hard at E. S. E. and we ≈øaw our Ve≈ø≈øel ≈øtretching further off, and ≈øoon after we received, in a ≈øcuttled Ca≈øk, a few Nece≈ø≈øaries,
with Ammunition, and a Letter See p. 162, for the Rea≈øons for leaving the≈øe unhappy Men a≈øhore.to acquaint us of the ri≈øque they ≈øhould run in lying near the Shore, and that they were obliged to ≈øtand farther off for their own Safety till the Weather ≈øhould be more favourable. Next Morning we expected they would have ≈øtretch'd in for the Land; but, to our great Surprize, we ≈øaw the Schooner with her En≈øign hoi≈øted at the Topping-lift, and under Sail from us.

The di≈ømal Apprehen≈øion we were under at ≈øuch an unexpected Stroke, appeared plainly in our Countenances, and are much ea≈øier to be imagin'd than de≈øcribed. We found our≈øelves on a wild de≈øolate Part of th ‚Ä¢ World, fatigued, ≈øickly, and de≈øtitute of Provi≈øions. 'Tis true we had Arms and Ammunition, and, whil≈øt that la≈øted, made a tolerable Shift for a Livelihood. The neare≈øt inhabited Place we knew of was Buenos-Ayres, about three hundred Miles to the N. W. but at pre≈øent we were in a very poor Condition to undertake ≈øuch an hazardous Journey, being ≈øo mi≈øerably reduced by our tedious Pa≈ø≈øage thro' the Streights of Magellan. Nothing remained but to commit our≈øelves to
kind Providence, and make the be≈øt of our melancholy Situation, till we had recruited our≈øelves.

We were in Number eight who were thus abandoned by our Crew, for who≈øe Pre≈øervation we ri≈øqued our Lives, in ≈øwimming a≈øhore for Provi≈øions. Our Names were Guy Broadwater, Samuel Cooper, Benjamin Smith, John Duck, Jo≈ø. Clinch, John Andrews, John Allen, and my≈øelf. After deliberating upon our unhappy Circum≈øtances, and comforting each other with imaginary Hopes, we came to a re≈øolution of taking up our Quarters on the Beach where we landed, till we ≈øhould grow ≈øtrong enough to undergo the Fatigue of a Journey to Buenos-Ayres. The Weather being very favourable, we took up our Lodging in a Trench near the Sea-≈øide, quite expo≈øed, without any Covering but the Heavens. Here we ≈øtay'd about a Month, during which Time we lived upon Seal, which were very plenty, and which we knocked down with Stones after we had cut off their retreat, by getting between them and the Sea. Here was likewi≈øe plenty of fre≈øh Water, from a ≈ømall Spring which ro≈øe out of the Trench; ≈øo that, at the Month's End, we had pretty well recover'd our≈øelves, and
concluded upon laying in a Stock of Provi≈øions for our Journey to Buenos-Ayres.

Having provided our≈øelves each with a Knap≈øack, which we made of Seal-≈økin, in the be≈øt Manner we could, we put into it as much dried Seal as we could carry, and their Bladders we filled with Fre≈øh Water, which ≈øerved us for Bottles. We took our Mu≈økets and Ammunition with us, and, thus accoutred, we ≈øet out on our Journey about the Middle of February; and, that we might proceed with the more Certainty, we were determined to keep clo≈øe to the Sea-≈øide till we ≈øhould come to the Mouth of the River Plate. The fir≈øt two Days we travelled about ≈øixty Miles, but could meet with no fre≈øh Water, be≈øides what we brought with us, the Country being ≈øcorch'd with Drought, and the rains not yet ≈øet in. Our Water being near expended, we were afraid to proceed, le≈øt we ≈øhould peri≈øh for want of more; ≈øo, after a few Debates, we agreed to return back to our old Quarters, and wait till the rainy Sea≈øon. We were two Days and a half on our return, after which we employ'd our≈øelves in building a Sort of Hut under a Cliff adjoining the Sea-≈øide, to ≈øecure us from the Inclemencies of the Weather. Here we tarried three Months, during which Time
our Food was Seals and Armadillos, which was the only Provi≈øion to be met with here, except Sea-weed, which we ≈øometimes made u≈øe of with our Meat in≈øtead of Bread. The Seal here differ from tho≈øe which I have ≈øeen in other Parts, both in Size and Make. The Males are the Bigne≈øs of a good Calf; their Neck is ≈øhaggy; their Head and Face is ≈øomewhat like a Lion's. The Females are like Lione≈ø≈øes before, but their Hair is ≈ømooth all over like an Hor≈øe's, whereas the Male is ≈ømooth only on his hinder Parts. From the hinder Part grow two large Fins like Feet, and two more out of the Brea≈øt, by Means of which they can climb rocks and Precipices, tho' they delight chiefly to lie a≈øleep near the Shore. Some are fourteen Feet long, and very fat; but in general they are about eight Feet: The Fle≈øh of the young ones is almo≈øt as white as Lamb, and tolerable good Eating. From the Shoulders to the Tail they grow tapering like Fi≈øh; and when the Females give ≈øuck to their Young they ≈øit upon their Fins, which grow out of their hinder Part. Their Hair is of different Colours, looking very ≈øleek when they come fir≈øt out of the Sea.

The Armadillo is as big nearly as a ≈ømall Sucking-Pig, the Body of it pretty large.
It is inclo≈øed in a thick Shell, which guards all its Back, and comes down on both Sides, meeting under the Belly, leaving room for the four Legs; the Head is ≈ømall, with a No≈øe like a Hedgehog, and a pretty long Neck, which it thru≈øts out before its Body when it walks, but on any Danger ≈øhe draws it in under the Shell, and, thru≈øting in her Feet, ≈øhe lies ≈øtock-≈øtill like a Land Turtle, and tho' you kick her about ≈øhe will not move her≈øelf. The Shell is jointed in the Middle of the Back, ≈øo that ≈øhe can turn the fore Part of her Body which Way ≈øhe plea≈øes; the Feet are like tho≈øe of a Land Turtle, and it has ≈øtrong Claws, with which it digs Holes in the Ground, and burrows in them like a rabbit. Its Fle≈øh is very good Eating, and ta≈øtes much like a Turtle.

Nothing remarkable happen'd to us in the≈øe three Months. Our Provi≈øions, ≈øuch as they were, were not very difficult to be procured, and we were ≈øupplied with Fire-wood enough from a ≈ømall Wood or Coppice about ≈øeven Miles from us. We ≈øeldom failed of bringing home ≈øomething every Night, and generally had a hot Supper. We pa≈ø≈øed our Time as chearful as poor Fellows in our Circum≈øtances could. But we knew we could not take up this Place for our ≈øettled
Abode; and there was no Likelihood of any Inhabitants near us, nor for many Miles round could we perceive the lea≈øt Traces of any ever having been there; and 'twas to no Purpo≈øe to expect the Sight of any Ve≈ø≈øel off at Sea; for, it being a deep Bay, and ≈øhoal Water, no Ships ever put in there, unle≈øs forced by Stre≈øs of Weather, and then they mu≈øt be wrecked. Nothing remain'd for us but to make a ≈øecond Attempt for the river Plate; for, if we ≈øhould march to the Inland Country in que≈øt of Inhabitants, po≈ø≈øibly we ≈øhould meet with in≈øuperable Difficulties in finding the Way back again to what I may call our Home; whereas if we kept our Cour≈øe along the Sea-≈øhore we could not err. For which rea≈øons we re≈øolved upon another Attempt by the ≈øame rout, and, having laid in our Stock of Seal, Armadillos, and fre≈øh Water, towards the latter End of May, we ≈øet forward once more.

In three Days we travelled about ≈øeventy Miles; when towards Night, there came on a violent Storm of rain, Thunder and Lightning, which continued the whole Night: We had a plain open Country, and no Place of Shelter could be found; we had nothing to cover us but a Seal-≈økin Jacket, were half dead with Cold, and afraid how our Provi≈øions
would hold out; for we met with no Supplies of any Kind by the Way. To proceed farther was only lengthening our Journey back again, which we feared, would be the Con≈øequence at la≈øt, even tho' we ≈øhould ≈øtill pu≈øh on. There had been the ≈øtricte≈øt Harmony and Good-nature between us till now; but now we were like to have di≈øagreed even to parting. Some were for pu≈øhing forward, be the Event what it might; and 'twas with Difficulty they were per≈øwaded not to divide. However, upon a repre≈øentation of the great Di≈øtance we were as yet from the Mouth of the river, and the Improbability of meeting with Supplies of Provi≈øion by the Way, our Debates ended, and we jointly concluded on making the be≈øt of our Way back to our Hut, having been a ≈øecond Time di≈øappointed in our Attempt.

After being arrived at our old Quarters, we began to con≈øult what Mea≈øures to take for our Security from the Inclemencies of the Weather, and to provide for our Sub≈øi≈øtence, till it ≈øhould plea≈øe God, one Way or other, to deliver us out of this Melancholy Situation. In order to avoid Di≈øputes about the laborious Part of getting Provi≈øions, we agreed to divide our≈øelves into two Parties,
who were, alternately, to provide for the Whole: Four were appointed to ≈øcour the Country one Day, and the other four the next. And we had bound our≈øelves by an Oath never to quit each other, unle≈øs obliged by a ≈øuperior Force; for tho' we had as yet ≈øeen no Foot≈øteps of Inhabitants, we could not be certain there were none on this Part of the Globe. We had killed ≈øuch a Number of Seal, that they now became very ≈øhy of us, and had lived upon them ≈øo long that we were almo≈øt ≈øurfeited; yet there was hardly any thing el≈øe to be met with. We ≈øaw a great Number of wild Dogs, but could never come near enough to kill any; tho' now and then we chanced to ≈øhoot a Puppy, which, as it was change of Diet, we thought delicious Fare. We ≈øaw al≈øo ≈øome Deer, but could contrive no Method to take them. One Day in our rambles, we met with a Litter of young Puppies: they were but three, and ≈øeemed to be about two Months old, and taken Shelter in a Hole of one of the Sand-hills. We took 'em out, and brought 'em home to our Hut. Having di≈øcover'd that the≈øe Puppies were whelped in Holes like tho≈øe of rabbits but larger, we went all out the next Day in que≈øt of more, and had the good Luck to find three Litters, in
Number thirteen, which we carried home with us, de≈øigning if po≈ø≈øible, to bring them up tame. We fed them with Broth made of Seals, and ≈øometimes with the Fle≈øh minced ≈ømall; and they afterwards became very ≈øerviceable to us. Each of us had his Brace of Dogs, which were brought up under as much Command as an Engli≈øh Spaniel, nor would they leave us to a≈ø≈øociate with the wild Ones; they often ≈øupplied us with Armadillos, and once they killed us a Deer. Being one Day hunting, we ≈øaw ≈øome wild Hogs, with their Young; our Dogs pur≈øued them, and took two of the Young, which we ≈øaved alive; and we ≈øhot one of the old Ones, which afforded us many dainty Suppers. The young ones proved to be a Boar and a Sow, which was very fortunate, and we de≈øigned to rear them for Breeding, le≈øt we ≈øhould be obliged to a long re≈øidence in this de≈øolate Country. We brought them up very tame, in≈øomuch that they followed our Dogs when ever we went a hunting; and at Night both Dogs and Pigs, took up their Lodging with us in our Hut.

For the pre≈øent our Condition ≈øeemed tolerable; nay, we thought our≈øelves in very comfortable Circum≈øtances: We wanted for nothing, and, if we could have confined our
Thoughts to pre≈øent Enjoyments, our Situation was very agreeable. But our Views were farther, and the Fears of what might happen frequently ≈øtruck a Damp on our Plea≈øures. Winter was now approaching; we had the Inclemencies of the Sea≈øon to guard again≈øt, and if po≈ø≈øible, a Stock of Provi≈øions to be laid up again≈øt future Emergencies. but we could not be much beforehand with Provi≈øions, having no Salt to cure them, and at pre≈øent not Sun enough to dry them; for with Winter came on continual Storms, with rains, in≈øomuch that ≈øome Days we could not ≈øtir out of our Hut.

'Twas now more than ≈øeven Months ≈øince the Long-boat left us. Winter came on very fa≈øt, and we were but badly ≈øecured from the Severity of the Weather. We re≈øolved immediatety to put our Habitation in Order, and to ≈øecure our Hut in the be≈øt Manner we could. Accordingly it was agreed that ≈øix ≈øhould ≈øtay at home next Day to prepare Materials, and two only to go out after Provi≈øions, the Lot „Äà‚óä„Äâ upon my≈øelf and John Duck, to go ab ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ d: All the Game we could meet with w ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e three Armadillos, tho's we travelled many Miles. 'Twas ≈øo dark before we returned, that we de≈øpaired of finding our Hut, and were like to have taken up our
Lodging in the open Plain, if our Comrades had not come out in que≈øt of us, and, by making a Fire, directed us towards them. After we had broiled our Game, and fed heartily, about Twelve we went to ≈øleep. But, about Two in the Morning, a violent Storm, with rain, Thunder, and Lightning, threw down Part of the Cliff upon us, under which we had built our Hut, and was very near proving fatal to us all; but, thro' Providence, none were hurt. With Day-light came on tolerable Weather; and now the fir≈øt Thing we had to do was to rebuild our Hut. We immediately went to the Coppice where we u≈øed to ≈øeek our Fire-wood, in order to fell ≈øome Poles. As we had but one Hatchet betwixt us, one only could fell them, and the re≈øt of us brought them out and bundled 'em. We had cut ≈øeveral, and were bundling them, when we ≈øaw Jo≈ø. Clinch running out of the Wood, and crying, Lord have Mercy upon us, here's a great Tyger. We were in the utmo≈øt Con≈øternation; for having been frequently there before, and never once ≈øeeing any Foot≈øteps of Wild Bea≈øts, we came without our Arms, ≈øu≈øpecting no Danger from that Quarter. We all took to our Heels, and ≈øoon ≈øaw him running out of the Wood in Pur≈øuit of us. When he was come within twenty
Yards of us, finding it impo≈ø≈øible to e≈øcape him, we all turned towards him, clapping our Hands, and making a loud Holo, in order to frighten him, which had the de≈øired Effect; for he immediately ≈øat back on his Tail, gazing at us. What to do we knew not, whether 'twas be≈øt to fly, or wait for his turning; but Fear prevailed, and we walked gently off, without his pur≈øuing us. Next Day we all went with our Mu≈økets in Chace of him, but could not meet with him. We brought home our Poles, and fitted up our Hut in the be≈øt Manner we could, ≈øufficient to guard us from the rain.

About three Weeks after, when we were hunting on the Plain, about four Miles from home, we ≈øaw a Lion couched on the Ground, watching his Prey, as we imagin'd, it being clo≈øe by a wild Cat's Hole. We joined clo≈øe together in a Body, with our Mu≈økets ready; and Jo≈ø. Clinch fired a Ball at him at twenty Yards Di≈øtance, re≈øting his Piece on my Shoulder, but mi≈øs'd him: The Lion took no Notice of the report of the Gun, nor ≈øtirred from his Po≈øture. He charged a ≈øecond Time, ours being kept in readine≈øs in Ca≈øe he ≈øhould advance towards us; he fired, and ≈øhot him in the right Shoulder; he fell on his Back, and we ran to him, and knock'd him in the
Head with the Bones of a dead Hor≈øe which lay near him. We carried him to our Hut, dre≈øs'd his Heart and Part of his ribs; but 'twas very indifferent Eating.

Finding our≈øelves beginning to be ≈øurrounded with wild Bea≈øts, and every Day and Night in continual Danger (for we now ≈øeldom went abroad without meeting ≈øome Bea≈øt of Prey; this being, I ≈øuppo≈øe, the Time of Year when they take their Haunts towards the Sea-coa≈øt), we determin'd to make another Pu≈øh for our Deliverance, and try our Fortune once more in an Expedition to Buenos Ayres. In order hereto we provided our≈øelves Shoes and Jackets of Seal-≈økins, and made our≈øelves Knap≈øacks of the ≈øame to carry our Provender. The Weather was ≈øet in fair, and we were fully determin'd to lay in ≈øuch a Stock of Provi≈øions as ≈øhould la≈øt us to the End of our Journey, if we ≈øhould be a Month in performing it. To this End we divided our≈øelves into two Parties; four of us were to go to the rocks for Seal, and the other four to hunt on the Plain. Accordingly we ≈øet out early in the Morning: 'twas my Lot, with Sam. Cooper, John Andrews, and John Duck, to go to the rocks. Our u≈øual Way in killing Seal being with Stones or Clubs, we never carried our Mu≈økets with us, we had been out all Day,
and killed three; and in the Du≈øk of the Evening, when we were got within a Stone's Ca≈øt of our Hut, I perceiv'd our Dogs very bu≈øy at a ≈ømall Di≈øtance, wagging their Tails in a very fondling Manner. Being a-head of my Companions, I pa≈ø≈øed on without much regarding it, thinking they had lighted on a dead Colt. But when I came to the Hut, I was quite confounded: The Hut was rifled, and all our Nece≈ø≈øaries taken away. In the utmo≈øt Con≈øternation I ran back to my Comrades, whom I ≈øaw ≈øtanding where I had left the Dogs: Seeing me running eagerly towards them, they cry'd out, What's the Matter, I≈øaac? I told them our Hut was pull'd down, and every thing taken away. Ay, ≈øaid they, and ≈øomething wor≈øe has happened; for yonder lie poor Guy Broad-water and Ben. Smith murder'd. 'Twas a mo≈øt ≈øhocking Sight: One had his Throat cut and the other was ≈øtabb'd in the Brea≈øt; they were hardly cold, ≈øo we thought the Murderers could not be far off. And we were under no ≈ømall Apprehen≈øion of ≈øharing a like Fate. We went to the Hut to in≈øpect more narrowly, and found every thing taken away; our Powder, Ball, and Mu≈økets gone, the Fire extingui≈øh'd, and not the lea≈øt Uten≈øil left. Where to go or what to do we knew not. We dur≈øt not tru≈øt our≈øelves another
Night on this fatal Spot, and yet were afraid to venture farther. At la≈øt we came to a re≈øolution of going to the next ≈øandy Bay, about a Mile off, and take up our Quarters there for that Night: But, when there, we could find no Shelter, not ≈øo much as a Cliff to lie under; ≈øo were obliged to return to our old Place, and pa≈øs the Night there, happen what would. Next Morning the Dogs which belonged to our Comrades ≈øtood on the Top of the Cliff barking at us, and would not come down, tho' we called them by their Names; and 'twas with Difficulty we enticed them down in the Evening. What became of Jo≈ø. Clinch and John Allen we knew not, nor could we afterwards learn any Account of them: What ≈øeem'd mo≈øt probable to us was, that the Indians had carried them off, and murder'd the other two, who po≈ø≈øibly might make ≈øome re≈øi≈øtance, as we had all agreed to do, in Ca≈øe we ≈øhould be attack'd; but, if ≈øo, we might probably have expected to have found ≈øome or other of their Enemies killed, as our People had Fire-Arms with them. And it was impo≈ø≈øible it could be the re≈øult of a Quarrel among≈øt them≈øelves, from the Manner of their Death; for one was ≈øtabb'd, and the other had his Throat cut, both very plainly done with a Knife, an In≈øtrument which none of
us had the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of. We buried 'em in the the be≈øt Manner we could, by ≈øcraping away the light Sand with our Hands two Feet deep, and rai≈øing a Bed of Sand over the Corp≈øes.

This was the mo≈øt afflicting Stroke of any we received ≈øince our re≈øidence in this unhappy Country. I won't pretend to de≈øcribe the Horrors we felt; the compa≈ø≈øionate reader will paint our Di≈øtre≈øs in his Imagination in ≈øtronger Colours than can be de≈øcribed by Words. To ≈øee four of our Companions ≈ønatched from us ≈øuddenly we knew not how, our≈øelves deprived of our Arms and Uten≈øils, left without Fire, or any Method of procuring it, expecting every Moment to ≈øhare their Fate, or to be ≈øtarved to Death, filled us with un≈øpeakable Terrors.

In this melancholy State the only thing that remain'd to be done was immediately to quit this unhappy Place, and make one Attempt more for Buenos Ayres. We had no Time to lo≈øe, but in≈øtantly ≈øet about tearing up the Seal in ≈ømall Pieces, raw as it was, with which we filled our Knap≈øacks, and their Bladders we filled with Water, le≈øt we ≈øhould find none on our Journey. Having furni≈øh'd our≈øelves with as much Provi≈øion as we could carry, we ≈øet forward on our Journey, with
our ≈øixteen Dogs and two Pigs; praying the Almighty to be our Guide. We kept clo≈øe along the Sea Coa≈øt, as we had done before, by which Means we could not mi≈øs the River Plate; where when we ≈øhould arrive our De≈øign was to travel along the Side of that river till we ≈øhould come to ≈øome inhabited Place: A Scheme ea≈øy enough in Imagination, but in Practice attended, as we found, with in≈øuperable Difficulties.

The Sea Coa≈øt all along is a plain ≈øandy Beach; on the Land Side are here and there very high Sand-hills: In the Valleys of tho≈øe Hills we repo≈øed our≈øelves at Night. On the Beach we ≈øometimes found ≈øome Cockles, which the Sea had wa≈øh'd in; the≈øe were a great Dainty to us. We met with Part of the Wreck of a large Ship which was drove upon the Beach, particularly a Man of War's Gangboard, and a Piece of Plank mark'd fifteen Foot. In the Valleys of the Sand-hills was Plenty of Water, which had been ponded up after the rains; and we frequently met with dead Fi≈øh thrown in upon the Beach; ≈øo that we had a Variety of raw Meat to feed upon. We al≈øo found by the Sea-≈øide a very large dead Whale which was a Fea≈øt for our Dogs and Pigs, and at a little Di≈øtance a Parcel of fine Whale-bone.

At the End of ten Days we made the Cape of the river, having travelled very hard every Day, and met with tolerable Weather, but when we got there we found a Multitude of ≈ømall rivers and muddy Swamps to ob≈øtruct us. We ≈øwam over ≈øeveral of them, with our Knap≈øacks acro≈øs our Shoulders; and when Night came on we cover'd our≈øelves with the ru≈øhes, but were almo≈øt devour'd by Mu≈øketoes. Next Day we made ≈øeveral Attempts to proceed farther, but found it impo≈ø≈øible to accompli≈øh our Journey; the farther we went the greater Difficulties we met with.
