there was a geat Deficiency of Hands, for which rea≈øon Orders were given to impre≈øs what Men they could at Monte Vedio. The≈øe, with the 11 Indians whom they had four Months before taken Pri≈øoners in a Skirmi≈øh at a Di≈øtance from Buenos Ayres, whom they de≈øign'd for their Row Gallies, were ≈øent on board; and ≈øoon after I had the Plea≈øure of ≈øeeing my Brother Mid≈øhipman Mr Campbell, who was lo≈øt in the Wager with us, but chu≈øing to follow the Fortune of Capt. Cheap, arrived with him at Chili. He came by Land from Chili with ≈øome Officers belonging to the Spani≈øh Admiral, and arrived in March at Buenos Ayres. The latter End of October following, 1745, we ≈øet ≈øail from Monte Vedio in the A≈øia bound for Spain.

Three Days after we ≈øailed, an Affair happened on board, which was like to have proved fatal to the whole Crew; for about Nine at Night, we were alarmed with the Cry of a Mutiny; and ≈øo indeed it proved: But ≈øuch a one as would never have been ≈øu≈øpected by any of the Ship's Crew, or perhaps credited by Po≈øterity, if ≈øuch a Number of Per≈øons were not ≈øtill living to atte≈øt the Fact. But, le≈øt I ≈øhould do Inju≈øtice to the Memory of ≈øuch a ≈øurpri≈øing Event, I ≈øhall beg Leave to relate it in the Language of Mr.
Walters, a≈ø≈øuring the reader that I was a Witne≈øs to the whole Affair.

"Pizarro had not yet compleated the Series of his Adventures; for when he and Mendinuetta came back by Land from Chili to Buenos Ayres, in the Year 1745, they found at Monte Vedio the A≈øia, which near three Years before they had left there. This Ship they re≈øolved, if po≈ø≈øible, to carry to Europe; and with this View they refitted her in the be≈øt manner they could. But their great Difficulty was to procure a ≈øufficient Number of Hands to navigate her; for all the remaining Sailors of the Squadron to be met with in the Neighbourhood of Buenos Ayres, did not amount to an hundred Men. They endeavoured to ≈øupply this Defect by pre≈ø≈øing and putting on board many of the Inhabitants of Buenos Ayres, be≈øides all the Engli≈øh Pri≈øoners then in their Cu≈øtody, together with a Number of Portugue≈øe Smugglers, whom they had taken at different Times, and ≈øome of the Indians of the Country. Among the≈øe la≈øt was a Chief and ten of his Followers, who had been ≈øurprized by a Party of Spani≈øh Soldiers about three Months before. The Name of this Chief was Orellana. He belonged to a very powerful Tribe which had committed great ravages in the Neighbourhood of Buenos Ayres.
With this motley Crew (all of them, except the European Spaniards, extremely aver≈øe to the Voyage) Pizarro ≈øet ≈øail from Monte Vedio, in the River of Plate, about the beginning of November, 1745. And the native Spaniards, being no Strangers to the Di≈ø≈øatisfaction of their forced Men, treated both the≈øe, the Engli≈øh Pri≈øoners, and the Indians, with great In≈øolence and Barbarity; but more particularly the Indians: For it was common for the meane≈øt Officers in the Ship to beat them mo≈øt cruelly, on the ≈ølighte≈øt Pretences, and oftentimes only to exert their Superiority. Orellana and his Followers, tho' in Appearance ≈øufficiently patient and ≈øubmi≈ø≈øive, meditated a ≈øevere revenge for all the≈øe Inhumanities. As he conver≈øed very well in Spani≈øh (the≈øe Indians having in Times of Peace, a good Intercour≈øe with Buenos Ayres) he affected to talk with ≈øuch of the Engli≈øh as under≈øtood that Language, and ≈øeemed very de≈øirous of being informed how many Engli≈øhmen there were on board, and which they were. As he knew that the Engli≈øh were as much Enemies to the Spaniards as him≈øelf, he had doubtle≈øs an Intention of di≈øclo≈øing his Purpo≈øe to them, and making them Partners in the Scheme he had projected for revenging his Wrongs and recovering his Liberty. But having ≈øounded
them at a Di≈øtance, and not finding them ≈øo precipitate and vindictive as he expected, he proceeded no further with them; but re≈øolved to tru≈øt alone to the re≈øolution of his ten faithful Followers. The≈øe, it ≈øhould ≈øeem, readily engaged to ob≈øerve his Directions, and to execute whatever Commands he gave them. And, having agreed on the Mea≈øures nece≈ø≈øary to be taken, they fir≈øt furni≈øhed them≈øelves with Dutch Knives, ≈øharp at the Point, which being the common Knives u≈øed in the Ship, they found no Difficulty in procuring. Be≈øides this, they employed their Lei≈øure in ≈øecretly cutting out Thongs from raw Hides, of which there were great Numbers on board, and in fiting to each End of the≈øe Thongs the double headed Shot of the ≈ømall Quarter-Deck Guns. This, when ≈øwung round their Heads, according to the Practice of their Country, was a mo≈øt mi≈øchievous Weapon, in the U≈øe of which the Indians about Buenos Ayres are train'd from their Infancy, and con≈øequently are extremely expert. The≈øe Particulars being in good Forwardne≈øs, the Execution of their Scheme was perhaps precipitated by a particular Outrage committed on Orellana him≈øelf. For one of the Officers, who was a very brutal Fellow, ordered Orellana aloft, which being what he was incapable of performing,
the Officer, under Pretence of his Di≈øobedience, beat him with ≈øuch Violence that he left him bleeding on the Deck, and ≈øtupified for ≈øome Time with his Brui≈øes and Wounds. This U≈øage undoubtedly heightened his Thir≈øt for revenge, and made him eager and impatient till the Means of executing it were in his Power; ≈øo that, within a Day or two after this Incident, he and his Followers opened their de≈øperate re≈øolves in the en≈øuing Manner.

"It was about Nine in the Evening, when many of the principal Officers were on ‚Ä¢ he Quarter-Deck, indulging in the Fre≈øhne≈øs of the Night Air; the Wai≈øt of the Ship was filled with live Cattle; and the Foreca≈øtle was manned with its cu≈øtomary Watch. Orellana and his Companions under Cover of the Night, having prepared their Weapons, and thrown off their Trow≈øers and the more cumberous Part of their Dre≈øs, came altogether on the Quarter-Deck, and drew towards the Door of the Great Cabbin. The Boat≈øwain immediately reprimanded them, and order'd them to be gone. On this Orellana ≈øpoke to his Followers in his Native Language; when four of them drew off, two towards each Gang-way, and the Chief and the ≈øix remaining Indians ≈øeemed to be ≈ølowly quitting the
Quarter Deck. When the detached Indians had taken Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Gang-way, Orellana placed his Hands hollow to his Mouth, and bellowed out the War-Cry u≈øed by the≈øe Savages, which is the har≈øhe≈øt and mo≈øt terrifying Sound known in Nature. This hideous Yell was the Signal for beginning the Ma≈ø≈øacre: For on this they all drew their Knives, and brandi≈øh'd their prepared double Headed Shot; and the ≈øix, with their Chief, which remained on the Quarter-Deck, immediately fell on the Spaniards, who were intermingled with them, and laid near forty of them at their Feet; of which about twenty were killed on the Spot, and the re≈øt di≈øabled. Many of the Officers in the Beginning of the Tumult, pu≈øhed into the great Cabin; where they put out the Lights, and barricadoed the Door; and of the others, who had avoided the fir≈øt Fury of the Indians, ≈øome endeavoured to e≈øcape along the Gangways into the Foreca≈øtle; but the Indians, placed there on Purpo≈øe, ≈øtabbed the greate≈øt Part of them as they attempted to pa≈øs by, or forced them off the Gangways into the Wai≈øt: Others threw them≈øelves voluntarily over the Barricadoes into the Wai≈øt, and thought them≈øelves happy to lie concealed among the Cattle: But the greate≈øt Part e≈øcaped up the Main Shrowds,
and ≈øheltered them≈øelves either in the Tops or rigging. And tho' the Indians attacked only the Quarter-Deck, yet the Watch in the Foreca≈øtle, finding the Communication cut off, and being terrified by the Wounds of the few who, not being killed on the Spot, had Strength ≈øufficient to force their Pa≈ø≈øage along the Gangways, and not knowing either who their Enemies were, or what were their Numbers, they likewi≈øe gave all over for lo≈øt, and, in great Confu≈øion, ran up into the rigging of the Forema≈øt and Bow≈øprit.

"Thus, the≈øe eleven Indians, with a re≈øolution perhaps without Example, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed them≈øelves, almo≈øt in an In≈øtant, of the Quarter-Deck of a Ship mounting ≈øixty ≈øix Guns, with a Crew of near five hundred Men, and continued in peaceable Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of this Po≈øt a con≈øiderable Time: For the Officers in the Great Cabin (among whom were Pizarro and Mindinuetta) the Crew between Decks, and tho≈øe who had e≈øcaped into the Tops and rigging, were only anxious for their own Safety, and were for a long Time incapable of forming any Project for ≈øuppre≈ø≈øing the In≈øurrection, and recovering the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Ship. It is true, the Yells of the Indians, the Groans of the Wounded, and the confu≈øed Clamours of the Crew, all heighten'd by the
Ob≈øcurity of the Night, had at fir≈øt greatly magnify'd their Danger, and had filled them with the imaginary Terrors which Darkne≈øs, Di≈øorder, and an Ignorance of the real Strength of an Enemy, never fail to produce. For as the Spaniards were ≈øen≈øible of the Di≈øaffection of their pre≈øt Hands, and were al≈øo con≈øcious of their Barbarity to their Pri≈øoners, they imagined the Con≈øpiracy was general, and con≈øider'd their own De≈øtruction as infallible; ≈øo that, it is ≈øaid, ≈øome of them had once taken the re≈øolution of leaping into the Sea, but were prevented by their Companions.

"However, when the Indians had entirely clear'd the Quarter-Deck, the Tumult in a great mea≈øure ≈øub≈øided; for tho≈øe who had e≈øcaped were kept ≈øilent by their Fears, and the Indians were incapable of pur≈øuing them, to renew the Di≈øorder. Orellana, when he ≈øaw him≈øelf Ma≈øter of the Quarter-Deck, broke open the Arm-Che≈øt, which, on a ≈ølight Su≈øpicion of Mutiny, had been ordered there a few Days before, as to a Place of the greate≈øt Security. Here he took it for granted he ≈øhould find Cutla≈ø≈øes ≈øufficient for him≈øelf and his Companions, in the U≈øe of which they were all extremely ≈økilful; and with the≈øe, it was imagined, they purpo≈øed to force the Great Cabin. But on opening the Che≈øt,
there appeared nothing but Fire-Arms, which to them were of no U≈øe. There were indeed Cutla≈ø≈øes in the Che≈øt, but they were hid by the Fire Arms being laid over them. This was a ≈øen≈øible Di≈øappointment to them; and by this Tme Pizarro and his Companions in the Great Cabin were capable of conver≈øing aloud, thro' the Cabin Windows and Portholes, with tho≈øe in the Gun-room and between Decks; and from hence they learnt that the Engli≈øh (whom they principally ≈øu≈øpected) were all ≈øafe below, and had not intermeddled in this Mutiny; and by other Particulars they at la≈øt di≈øcover'd, that none were concern'd in it but Orellana and his People. On this Pizarro and the Officers re≈øolved to atta ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ them on the Quarter Deck, before any of the Di≈øcontented on board ≈øhould ≈øo far recover their fir≈øt Surprize as to reflect on the Facility and Certainty of ≈øeizing the Ship, by a Junction with the Indians, in the pre≈øent Emergency. With this View Pizarro got together what Arms were in the Cabin, and di≈øtributed them to tho≈øe who were with him; but there were no other Fire-Arms to be met with but Pi≈øtols, and for the≈øe they had neither Powder nor Ball. However, having now ≈øettled a Corre≈øpondence with the Gun-room, they lowered down a Bucket out of the Cabin Window,
into which the Gunner, out of one of the Gun-room Ports, put a Quantity of Pi≈øtol Cartriges. When they had thus procured Ammunition, and had loaded their Pi≈øtols, they ≈øet the Cabin Door partly open, and fired ≈øome Shot among the Indians on the Quarter-Deck, at fir≈øt without Effect; but at la≈øt Mendinuetta, whom we have often mentioned, ha ‚Ä¢ the good Fortune to ≈øhoot Orellana dead on the Spot. On which his faithful Companions, abandoning all Thoughts of farther re≈øi≈øtance, in≈øtantly leaped into the Sea; where they every Man peri≈øhed. Thus was the In≈øurrection quelled, and the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Quarter-Deck regained, after it had been full two Hours in the Power of this Great and daring Chief, and his gallant and unhappy Countrymen."

After this all was quiet; and the Admiral, finding that none of the Engli≈øh were engaged in this In≈øurrection, for a few Days treated us with a little Humanity, endeavouring to engage us, by large Promi≈øes of Preferment, to enter into the Spani≈øh Service. But finding nothing would work on us, we afterwards felt the Smart of his re≈øentment by a ≈øevere U≈øage.

Nothing remarkable happened afterwards, more than what commonly happens at Sea, till
we arrived at Concubene, a Harbour about Five Leagues to the South of Cape Fini≈øterre; which was the latter End of February, 1745-6.

We begged to be ≈øent a≈øhore as Pri≈øoners of War, but were told we mu≈øt go in the Ship to the Groyne. Whereupon we all went in a Body on the Quarter Deck, and told the Admiral, if he would not ≈øend us a≈øhore, we would be no longer Slaves on board. Next Day we were ≈øent a≈øhore, and confined fifteen Days in a Pri≈øon, with an Allowance only of Bread and Water, and chained together as Criminals, till the Ship ≈øail'd for the Groyne; when we were relea≈øed from our Dungeon, and guarded to the Groyne by Land with a File of Mu≈øqueteers. Where, as ≈øoon as we arrived, we were put into the Guard-Hou≈ø ‚Ä¢ for two Days; from whence we were ≈øent to the Ca≈øtle of St. Antonio, which is on an I≈øland at the Entrance of the Harbour; a Pri≈øon for Thieves and Felons. In this di≈ømal Place we were kept Fourteen Weeks, among the wor≈øt of Malefactors, till an Order came from the Court of Spain to ≈øend us to Portugal; allowing us a Guide, and a Real per Day.

In Eight Days we got to Oporto, and made Application to the Engli≈øh Con≈øul, who, after hearing the Hard≈øhips we had gone
through, gave us each Three Days Maintenance and a Quarter of a Moidore.

On April 28, 1746, we embarked on board the Charlotta Snow, Capt. Henry Miller, bound for London, under Convoy of the York, and Folk≈øtone Men of War, and arrived at London on the 8th of July following: Three only of the Eight left on the Patagonian Coa≈øt being ≈øo happy as to ≈øee once more their native Country, viz. Samuel Cooper, John Andrews, and My≈øelf." [Here ends Morris's Relation.]
Two Years after this having ≈øome Inclination to ≈øettle in London, I ≈øent a Petition to the Lords of the Admiralty as follows.

body.head: To the Honourable the Principal Officers and Commi≈ø≈øioners of his Maje≈øty's Navy.
body.p:
HAVING ≈øerved ever ≈øince the Year 1728 in the Royal Navy on board ≈øeveral of the King's Ships, and in the Station of an Officer, and being now de≈øirous to enter into ≈øome Bu≈øine≈øs in the City of London, and it being nece≈ø≈øary to produce a Certificate of the Time of my Servitude in the Navy, in order to my obtaining the Freedom of the ≈øaid City. I mo≈øt humbly pray your Honours to order the proper
Clerk to write me out a Certificate accordingly, which will infinitely oblige, Honourable Sirs,

div.p: I ≈øhall now conclude my Narrative with remarking, that I believe few, if any, of late Years, have gone thro' more Di≈øtre≈ø≈øes, and Mi≈øeries than my≈øelf; yet, in all my Trials, I was in ≈øome Degree ble≈øs'd with the Patience of holy Job, knowing, that as the Lord giveth, he can take away, and ble≈ø≈øed be his holy Name.

lg.l: "Pre≈øence of Mind, and Courage in Di≈øtre≈øs
